explanations: The French metaphorical request 'recommencez un peu... à me parler Caldéen' (begin again a little... to speak Chaldean to me) is simplified to a direct desire for instruction: 'you must teach me their Rules, if you would have me improve in their Science', making the meaning more explicit and less figurative.
The formal French interrogative 'de quoy fut-il question?' (of what was it a question?) is simplified to the more direct and common English question 'pray, what is the next Question?'.

The formal French 'il faut que vous remarquiez, s'il vous plaist' (it is necessary that you remark, if you please) which uses a subjunctive, is simplified to the more direct 'I would have you observe'. Additionally, the elaborate 'qui s'estoit mis dans la fantaisie, que...' (who had put it into his fantasy, that...) is simplified to the more common 'who fancy'd...'.

The complex French structure 'on ne manqua pas d'abord de s'imaginer qu'il falloit que la Terre fust en repos' (one did not fail at first to imagine that it was necessary that the Earth be at rest), involving double negation and subjunctive, is significantly simplified to the direct statement 'they imagin'd the Earth rested'.

The French cleft sentence 'Ce fut donc au dessus de la Terre qu'on plaça la Lune' (It was thus above the Earth that one placed the Moon) is simplified to a standard Subject-Verb-Object structure: 'They plac'd the Moon above the Earth'.

The Marquise's full statement of contentment in French 'il me paroist aussi net qu'intelligible, & pour moy je vous declare que je m'en contente' is reduced in the English translation, omitting the clause '& pour moy je vous declare que je m'en contente', thereby simplifying by reducing the length and the emphasis of her personal satisfaction.

The French 'il vous jetteroit dans une épouvante horrible' (it would throw you into a horrible fright/terror) is simplified to 'I should fright you', using a more common verb and less intense phrasing.

The French text details planetary irregularities: 'qu'elles n'aillent tantost plus viste, tantost plus lentement, tantost en un sens, tantost en un autre'. The English translation omits 'tantost en un sens, tantost en un autre' (sometimes in one direction, sometimes in another), simplifying the description by removing a specific detail about retrograde motion.
The French 'apparemment fort peu devot' (apparently very little devout/very un-devout) is simplified to the more colloquial and slightly softer English euphemism 'not much troubled with Religion'.

The French 'La pensée est trop libertine, mais cela mesme est assez plaisant, que ce Sistême fust alors une occasion de peché, parce qu'il estoit trop confus' is simplified. 'Trop libertine' becomes 'very Atheistical', a more direct term. More significantly, the nuanced humorous remark 'mais cela mesme est assez plaisant...' about the system being an occasion for sin due to its confusion is omitted, reducing textual density.

The French conditional perfect question 'N'eussent-ils pas esté bons de quelque autre matiere?' (Would they not have been good of some other material?) is simplified to the more common English idiom 'would nothing else serve as well?'.

The French subjunctive constructions 'il faloit que la lumiere passast' and 'il faloit que le Cieux fussent solides' are simplified to 'the Light was to come' and 'they were to be solid'. Also, 'la solidité estoit une chose attachée à la noblesse de leur nature' is simplified to 'Solidity to be one of their Excellencies', using less abstract vocabulary. The complex 'on n'avoit garde d'en vouloir douter' is simplified to 'no body would be so rude as to question it'.

The formal French '& il a falu se resoudre à faire les Cieux d'une matiere fluide' (and it was necessary to resolve to make the Heavens of a fluid matter) is simplified and made more colloquial with the introductory phrase 'But to make the best of a bad Market, they presently melt down their broken Glass... made the heavens fluid'.

The formal French statement 'l'ancien Sistême est absolument insoûtenable par cet endroit' (the ancient System is absolutely unsustainable in this respect) is replaced by the more emphatic and colloquial English dismissal 'which is now every where exploded, and all the Ipse Dixits not worth a rush'.

The French phrase 'qui mettroit le Roy d'Aragon hors d'estat de donner des avis' (which would put the King of Aragon out of state [unable] to give advice) is simplified to the more idiomatic 'that the King of Arragon himself may spare his Advice.' The subsequent reason 'car il est d'une simplicité charmante, & qui seule le feroit préferer' is omitted, reducing text length.

The abstract French 'ce n'est que par là qu'on peut attraper le Plan sur lequel la Nature a fait son Ouvrage' and the complex following sentence detailing Nature's economy are simplified into the concrete analogy 'Nature is a great Huswife, she always makes use of what costs least, let the difference be never so inconsiderable;', making the concept more accessible.

The Marquise's polite expression of desire 'Je serai bien-aise... que le Sistême... imite...' and her elaborate reasoning about her imagination ('car ce grand ménage-là tournera au profit de mon imagination, qui n'aura pas tant de peine à comprendre...') are drastically simplified to a direct command and request: 'Imitate Nature then... and give me as little trouble as you can to comprehend you.'

The strong French idiom 'fait main-basse sur' (makes a clean sweep/ransacks) is rendered by the more descriptive and perhaps accessible 'confounding every thing, earing in pieces... and shattering...'. The addition of the simile 'like so many Glass Windows' simplifies by making the destructive action more concrete.
The formal French 'du long repos qu'elle s'estoit attribué' (for the long rest she had attributed to herself) is simplified to the more common and personified 'for her former Lazyness'.

The Marquise's polite interjection and detailed reason for her confusion ('il vient de vous prendre un enthousiasme qui vous a fait expliquer les choses si pompeusement, que je ne croy pas les avoir entenduës') is simplified to the more direct 'Fair and softly... I fancy you your self are seiz'd with the Noble Fury of Astronomy; a little less Rapture, and I shall understand you the better.'

The formal French 'Je vous jure que je ne m'en estime pas moins' (I swear to you that I do not esteem myself less for it) is simplified to the more colloquial English 'For my part I do not think my self at all the worse for't.'

The general French statement 'on sera moins jaloux du rang qu'on tient dans l'Univers, que de celuy qu'on croit devoir tenir dans une chambre' is simplified by making the comparison concrete and specific: 'a Fair Lady would be much more concern'd for her place at a Ball, than for her rank in the Universe'.

The French 'Il fut tres-long-temps à ne la vouloir pas publier' (He was a very long time in not wanting to publish it) is rephrased into more fluent English 'he was a long time before he would venture to publish it'. 'À la priere de Gens tres-considerables' (at the request of very considerable People) is simplified to 'without the importunity of his Friends,' using simpler vocabulary ('Friends') and a more common term ('importunity').

The French 'Il ne voulut point essuyer toutes les contradictions qu'il prévoyoit, & se tira habilement d'affaire' (He did not want to endure... & cleverly got himself out of the affair) is simplified using more common vocabulary and idioms: 'he foresaw he should never be able to clear all the contradictions, and very wisely slipt out of the way.'

The Marquise's elaborate and tentative phrasing 'Je voy, ce me semble, à vostre air, que vous m'allez dire, que...' (I see, it seems to me, by your air/look, that you are going to tell me, that...) is drastically simplified to the concise 'Perhaps you will tell me...'.

The French conditional 'je trouverois à mon réveil le rivage changé' (I would find...) and 'cela me feroit bien voir que mon Bateau auroit changé de place' (that would make me see that my boat would have changed place) are simplified to simple present and present perfect tenses: 'when I awake I find another shoar, and that shows me, my Boat hath chang'd place', making the structure less complex.

The French construction 'il faut que je le voye répondre à d'autres' (it is necessary that I see it correspond to others), which uses a subjunctive, is simplified to the more direct 'the Sun must answer to other Stars'.

The French rhetorical question 'N'ay-je pas oüy dire qu'un Philosophe...' (Have I not heard it said that a Philosopher...) is simplified into a direct statement: 'For I have heard of a certain Philosopher...'.

The somewhat formal French 'Vous jugez bien qu'il ne m'appartient point de faire ces pas-là, & qu'il ne faut pas qu'on en voye icy' is simplified to the direct command 'But you may spare your Figures' and the simpler social reason 'such Footsteps are not decent here.'

chunks.source_manual: <P009>Il vaut mieux en effet, répondis-je, qu'on n'y voye que des pas d'Amans, c'est à dire, vostre nom & vos chiffres gravez sur l'écorce des arbres par la main de vos Adorateurs. Laissons-là, je vous prie, les Adorateurs, reprit-elle, & parlons du Soleil. J'entends bien comment nous nous imaginons qu'il décrit le Cercle que nous décrivons nous-mesmes, mais ce tour ne s'acheve qu'en un an, & celuy que le Soleil fait tous les jours sur nostre teste, comment se fait-il? Avez-vous remarqué, luy répondis-je, qu'une boule qui roule sur la Terre, a deux mouvemens? Elle va vers le but où elle est envoyée, & en mesme temps elle tourne un grand nombre de fois sur elle-mesme, en sorte que les parties d'en haut viennent en bas, & que celles d'en bas montent en haut. La Terre fait la mesme chose. Dans le temps qu'elle avance sur le Cercle qu'elle décrit en un an autour du Soleil, elle tourne <RW>sur elle-mesme</RW> en <RW>vingt-quatre</RW> heures. Ainsi en <RW>vingt-quatre</RW> heures chaque partie de la Terre perd le Soleil, & le recouvre, & à mesure qu'en tourne vers le costé où est le Soleil, <IIM>il</IIM> semble qu'il s'élève, & quand on commence à s'en éloigner, il semble qu'il s'abaisse. Cela est assez plaisant, dit-elle, la Terre prend tout sur soy, & ce Soleil ne fait rien. Et quand la Lune & les autres Planetes, les Etoiles Fixes paroissent faire un tour sur nostre teste en vingt-quatre heures, c'est donc aussi une imagination <SC>?</SC> Imagination pure, repris-je, qui vient de la mesme cause. Les Planetes font seulement leurs Cercles autour du Soleil en des temps inégaux selon leurs distances inégales, & celle que nous voyons aujourd'huy répondre à un certain point du Zodiaque, ou de ce Cercle d'Etoiles Fixes, nous la voyons demain répondre à un autre point, tant parce qu'elle a avancé <SC>sur son Cercle</SC>, que parce que nous avons avancé sur le nostre. Nous marchons, & les autres Planetes marchent aussi; cela nous met dans diferens points de veüe à leur égard, & nous fait paroistre dans leur cours des bizarreries dont il n'est pas necessaire que je vous parle. Il suffit que vous sçachiez que ce qu'il y a d'irregulier dans les Planetes ne vient que de la diverse maniere dont nostre mouvement nous les fait rencontrer, & qu'au fonds elles sont toutes tres-reglées. Je consens qu'elles le soient, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, mais je voudrois bien que leur regularité <UP>coûtast moins à la Terre</UP>, on ne l'a guere ménagée, & pour une grosse masse aussi pesante qu'elle est, on luy demande bien de l'agilité. <SC>.</SC> Mais, luy répondis-je, aimeriez-vous mieux que le Soleil, & tous les autres Astres qui sont de tres-grands Corps, fissent tous les jours en vingt-quatre heures autour de la Terre un tour immense, & un nombre infini de lieües? Car il faudroit qu'ils le fissent si la Terra ne tournoit pas sur elle-mesme en 24 heures.</P009> <P010>Oh! repliqua-t-elle, le Soleil & les Astres sont tout de feu, le mouvement ne leur coúte rien; mais la Terre ne paroît guere portative. Et croiriez-vous, repris-je, si vous n'en aviez point l'experience, que ce fust quelque chose de bien portatif, qu'un gros Navire monté de cent-cinquante pieces de Canon, chargé de plus de trois mille hommes, & d'une tres-grande nombre de Marchãdises? Cependant il ne faut qu'un petit soufle de vent pour le faire aller sur l'eau, parce que l'eau est liquide, & que se laissant diviser avec facilité, elle résiste peu au mouvement du Navire. Ainsi la Terre, toute massive qu'elle est, est aisément portée dans la matiere celeste, qui est mille fois plus fluide que l'eau, & qui remplit tout ce grand espace où nagent les Planetes. Et où faudroit-il que la Terre fust cramponnée pour résister au mouvement de cette matiere celeste, & ne s'y pas laisser emporter? C'est comme si une petite boule de bois pouvoit ne pas suivre le courant d'une Riviere.</P010> <P011>Mais, repliqua-t-elle encore, comment la Terre avec tout son poids se soûtient-elle sur vostre matiere celeste, qui doit estre bien legere, puis qu'elle est si fluide? Ce n'est pas à dire, répondis-je, que ce qui est fluide, soit plus leger. Que dites-vous de nostre gros Vaisseau, qui avec tout son poids est plus léger que l'eau, puis qu'il y surnage? Je ne veux plus vous dire rien, dit-elle comme en colere, tant que vous aurez le gros Vaisseau. Mais m'assurez-vous bien qu'il n'y ait rien à craindre sur une piroüette aussi legere que vous me faites la Terre? Et bien, luy repondis-je, faisons porter la Terre par quatre Elephans, comme font les Indiens. Voicy bien un autre Systême, s'écria-t-elle. Du moins j'aime ces Gens-là d'avoir pourveu à leur seureté, & fait de bons fondemens, au lieu que nous autres Coperniciens, nous sommes assez inconsiderez pour vouloir bien nager à l'avanture dans cette matiere celeste. Je gage que si les Indiens sçavoient que la Terre fust le moins du monde en peril de se mouvoir, ils doubleroient les Elephans.</P011> <P012>Cela le meriteroit bien, repris-je, <NCP>en riant de sa pensée</NCP>, il ne faut point s'épargner les Elephans pour dormir en assurance, & si vous en avez besoin pour cette nuit, nous en mettrons dans nostre Systême autant qu'il vous plaira; ensuite nous les retrancherons peu à peu, à mesure que vous vous rassurerez. Serieusement, reprit-elle, je ne croy pas dés à present qu'ils me soient fort necessaires, & je me sens assez de courage pour oser tourner. Vous irez bien-tost encore plus loin, repliquay-je, vous tournerez avec plaisir, & vous vous ferez sur ce Systême des idées réjoüissantes. Quelquefois, par exemple, je me figure que je suis suspendu en l'air, & que j'y demeure sans mouvement pendant que la Terre tourne sous moy en vingt-quatre heures, & que je vois passer sous mes yeux tous ces visages differens, les uns blancs, les autres noirs, les autres bazannez, les autres olivâtres, que je voy d'abord des Chapeaux, & puis des Turbans, & puis des Testes cheveluës, & puis des Testes rases; tantost des Villes à clochers, tantost des Villes à longues aiguilles qui ont des Croissans, tantost des Villes à Tours de Porcelaine, tantost de grands Païs qui n'ont que des Cabanes; icy, des vastes Mers; là des Deserts épouvantables; enfin toute cette variesté infinie qui est sur la surface de la Terre.</P012> <P013>En verité, dit-elle, tout cela meriteroit bien que l'on donnast vingt-quatre heures de son temps à le voir. Ainsi donc dans le mesme lieu où nous sommes à present, je ne dis pas dans ce Parc, mais dans ce mesme lieu à le prendre dans l'air, il y passe continuellement d'autres Peuples qui prennent nostre place, & au bout de vingt-quatre heures nous y revenons.</P013>
chunks.target_manual: <P007>I confess, said I, Madam, the footsteps of Lovers would better become this Place; that is, your Name and Cypher grav'd on the Trees by your Adorers. Tell not me, said she, of Lovers and Adorers, I am for my beloved Sun and Planets. But how comes it to pass that the Sun as to the fixed Stars compleats his course but in a year, and yet goes over our Heads every day? Did you never, I reply'd, observe a Bowl on a Bowling-green? It runs towards the Block, and at the same time turns very often round it self, so that the Parts which were above are below, and those which were below are above; just so it is with the Earth, at the same time that she advanceth on the Circle which in a years space she makes round the Sun, in twenty four hours she turns round her self; so that in twenty four hours every part of the Earth loseth the Sun, and recovers him again, and as it turns towards the Sun, it seems to rise, and as it turns from him, it seems to fall. It is very pleasant, said she, that the Earth must take all upon her self, and the Sun do nothing. And when the Moon, the other Planets, and the fix'd Stars seem to go over our Heads every twenty four hours, you'll say that too is only Fancy? Pure Fancy, said I, which proceeds from the same cause, for the Planets compleat their courses round the Sun at unequal times, according to their unequal distances, and that which we see to day answer to a certain Point in the Zodiack or Circle of the fix'd Stars, to morrow we see answer to another Point, because it is advanced on its own Circle as well as we are advanced upon ours. We move, and the Planets move too, which must make a great alteration; so that what seems irregular in the Planets, proceeds only from our motion, when in truth they are all very regular: I will suppose 'em so, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, but I would not have their Regularity put the Earth to so great trouble; methinks you exact too much Activity from so ponderous a Mass. But, said I, had you rather that the Sun and all the Stars, which are vast great Bodies, should in twenty four hours travel such an infinity of Miles, and make so prodigious a Tour as they needs must, if the Earth did not turn round it self every twenty four hours? Oh, said she, the Sun and the Stars are all Fire, their Motion is not very difficult; but the Earth, I fancy, is a little unweildy: That signifies nothing, I reply'd, for what do you think of a first rate Ship, which carries near an hundred Guns, and a thousand Men, beside her Provisions and other Furniture? you see one puff of Wind makes it sail on the Water, because the Water is liquid, and being easily separated doth very little resist the motion of the Ship: So the Earth tho' never so Massive is as easily born up by the Celestial Matter, which is a thousand times more fluid than the Water, and fills all that great Space where the Planets float; for where would you the Earth should be fastned to resist the motion of the Celestial Matter, and not be driven by it? You may as well fancy a little block of Wood can withstand the current of a River. But pray, said she, how can the Earth with all its weight be born up by your Celestial Matter, which must be very light, because it is so fluid? It doth not argue, said I, that what is most fluid is most light: for what think you of the great Vessel I mention'd but now, which with all its Burthen is yet lighter than the Water it floats on? I will have nothing to do with that great Vessel, said she, and I begin to apprehend my self in some danger on such a whirlegigg as you have made of the Earth: There is no danger, I reply'd; but Madam, if you are afraid, we will have the Earth supported by four Elephants, as the Indians believe it. Hey day, cry'd she, here's another Systeme; however I love those People for taking care of themselves, they have a good Foundation to trust to, while you Copernicans are a little too venturous with the Celestial Matter; and yet I fancy if the Indians thought the Earth in the least danger of sinking, they would double their number of Elephants. They do well, said I, laughing at her fancy, who would sleep in Fear? and if you have occasion for 'em to night, we will put as many as you please in our Systeme, we can take 'em away again by degrees as you grow better confirm'd. I do not think 'em very necessary, said she, I have courage enough to turn. You shall turn with pleasure, Madam, said I, and shall find delightful Ideas in this Systeme. For Example, sometimes I fancy my self suspended in the Air, without any motion, while the Earth turns round me in twenty four hours; I see I know not how many different Faces pass under me, some white, some black, and some tauny; sometimes I see Hats, and sometimes Turbants, now Heads with Hair, and then shav'd Heads; here I see Cities with Steeples, others with Spires and Crescents, others with Towers of Purcelain, and anon great Countreys with nothing but Cottages; here. I see vast Oceans, and there most horrible Desarts; in short, I discover the infinite variety which is upon the surface of the Earth. I confess, said she, twenty four hours would thus be very well bestow'd, so that in the same Place where we are now, I do not mean in the Park, but we will suppose our selves in the Air, other People continually pass by who take up our Place, and at the end of twenty four hours we return to it again.</P007>

explanations: The French impersonal construction 'qu'on n'y voye que' (that one sees there only) is simplified to a more direct statement about what 'would better become this Place,' enhancing readability.

The initial clause 'J'entends bien comment nous nous imaginons qu'il décrit le Cercle que nous décrivons nous-mesmes' (I understand well how we imagine that it describes the circle that we ourselves describe) is omitted in the English translation. This reduces the text's density by removing the Marquise's affirmation of understanding before she poses her question, simplifying the conversational flow.

The French correlative conjunction 'tant parce que... que parce que' (as much because... as because) is simplified to the more straightforward English construction 'because... as well as,' making the sentence structure less complex.

The specific French phrase 'cela nous met dans diferens points de veüe à leur égard' (that puts us in different points of view with regard to them) is generalized to 'which must make a great alteration.' Furthermore, the statement that detailing 'bizarreries' is unnecessary is replaced by a direct explanation of their cause ('proceeds only from our motion'), simplifying the argument by making it more direct and less meta-discursive.

The introductory French phrase 'Il suffit que vous sçachiez que...' (It is enough that you know that...), which frames the subsequent explanation, is omitted. The core information is integrated directly into the preceding clause in English, simplifying the rhetorical structure by removing this framing device.

The French clause 'on ne l'a guere ménagée' (one has hardly spared it/treated it gently), which adds a nuance about the Earth's treatment, is omitted or its sense is very loosely absorbed into 'put the Earth to so great trouble'. This omission simplifies by reducing density and a layer of personification.

The impersonal French construction 'on luy demande bien de l'agilité' (one demands much agility from it) is simplified to a more personal and direct phrasing 'methinks you exact too much Activity,' attributing the demand directly to the philosopher.

The formal French subjunctive construction 'Car il faudroit qu'ils le fissent' (For it would be necessary that they do it) is simplified to the more concise and common English phrasal 'as they needs must,' reducing syntactic complexity.

The translator prefaces the analogy with 'That signifies nothing,' directly dismissing the Marquise's prior concern, which simplifies the transition. Additionally, the specific quantities 'cent-cinquante pieces de Canon' (150 cannons) and 'plus de trois mille hommes' (more than 3000 men) are reduced to 'near an hundred Guns' and 'a thousand Men,' a simplification of numerical detail.

The explicit logical connector 'puis qu'il y surnage' (since it floats on it) is simplified by making the causal link implicit; the English states that the vessel floats, rather than using 'since' or 'because' to explicitly mark it as the reason for its lightness relative to water.

The French phrase 'dit-elle comme en colere' (she said as if angry), which explicitly marks the Marquise's emotion, is omitted in the English translation. This simplifies the text by removing a layer of character's emotional nuance.

The phrase 'avoir pourveu à leur seureté' (having provided for their safety) is simplified to the more common English idiom 'taking care of themselves.' The vivid French imagery 'vouloir bien nager à l'avanture dans cette matiere celeste' (to want to swim haphazardly/at random in this celestial matter) is simplified to the more abstract 'are a little too venturous with the Celestial Matter,' reducing both the imagery and the complexity of the phrasing.

The French 'Cela le meriteroit bien' (That would well deserve it), referring to the idea of doubling elephants, is replaced by the less specific 'They do well.' The subsequent specific argument 'il ne faut point s'épargner les Elephans pour dormir en assurance' (one must not spare the elephants to sleep in safety) is omitted and substituted with the general rhetorical question 'who would sleep in Fear?', simplifying the specific reasoning into a general aphorism.

The introductory adverb 'Serieusement' (Seriously), which signals a shift in the Marquise's tone, is omitted. The temporal specifier 'dés à present' (from now on/already) is also omitted, simplifying the statement by reducing nuance and specificity.

The philosopher's encouraging prediction 'Vous irez bien-tost encore plus loin' (You will soon go even further) is omitted from the English translation. This simplifies the dialogue by removing this prospective element of the Marquise's intellectual journey.

The French text lists four distinct skin tones: 'blancs' (white), 'noirs' (black), 'bazannez' (swarthy/tanned), and 'olivâtres' (olive-skinned). The English translation simplifies this to three: 'white,' 'black,' and 'tauny,' omitting 'olivâtres' and thereby reducing the richness of ethnographic detail.

The complex French sentence structure 'tout cela meriteroit bien que l'on donnast vingt-quatre heures de son temps à le voir' (all that would well deserve that one give twenty-four hours of one's time to see it), involving an impersonal subjunctive, is simplified to the more direct passive-like English construction 'twenty four hours would thus be very well bestow'd,' making the sentence more concise and structurally simpler.

The abstract French conceptual phrase 'à le prendre dans l'air' (taking it/considering it in the air), used to specify a viewpoint, is simplified to the more concrete and direct imaginative instruction 'we will suppose our selves in the Air,' making the idea more accessible.

chunks.source_manual: <P014>Copernic, luy répondis-je, ne le comprendroit pas mieux. D'abord il passera par icy des Anglois qui raisonneront peut-estre de quelque dessein de Politique avec moins de gayeté que nous ne raisonnons de nostre Philosophie; ensuite viendra une grànde Mer, & il se pourra trouver en ce lieu-là quelque Vaisseau qui n'y sera pas si à son aise que nous. Après cela Paroistront des <IIM>Iroquois</IIM>, qui mangeront tout vif quelque prisonnier de guerre, qui fera semblant de ne s'en pas soucier; des Femmes de la Terre de Jesso, qui n'employeront tout leur temps qu'à préparer le Repas de leurs Maris, & à se peindre de bleu les lévres & les sourcils, pour plaire aux plus <IIM> vilains Hommes du monde</IIM>; des Tartares qui iront fort devotement en Pelerinage vers ce Grand Prestre, qui ne sort jamais d'un lieu obscur où il n'est éclairé que par des Lampes, à la lumiere desquelles on l'adore; de belles Circassiennes qui ne feront aucune façon d'accorder tout au premier venu, horsmis ce qu'elles croyent qui appartient essentiellement à leurs Maris; de petits Tartares qui iront voler des Femmes pour les Turcs & pour les <IIM>Persans</IIM>; enfin, nous qui debiterons peut-estre encore des <NCE>resveries</NCE>.</P014> <P015>Il est assez plaisant, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, d'imaginer ce que vous venez de me dire; mais si je voyois tout cela d'en haut, je voudrais avoir la liberté de hâter ou d'arrêter le mouvement de la Terre, selon que les objets me plairoient plus ou moins, & je vous assure que je ferais passer bien viste ceux qui s'embarrassent de Politique, ou qui mangent leurs Ennemis; mais il y en a d'autres pour qui j'aurois de la curiosité. J'en aurais pour ces Belles Circassiennes, par exemple, elles ont un usage qui me paroist assez particulier. C'est qu'elle sont si belles, luy dis-je, que leurs Maris trovent dans leurs faveurs un superflu qu'ils abandonnent aux Etrangers. Les Femmes de ces Païs-cy sont donc bien laides aux prix d'elles, reprit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, car le Maris ne relâchent rien. Cela est cause qu'on prend davantage, repliquay-je, au lieu que...Taisez-vous, interrompit-elle, je ne veux plus dire de folies, aussi bien il me vient une difficulté sérieuse. Si la Terre tourne, nous changeons d'air à chaque moment, & nous respirons toûjours celuy d'un autre Païs. Nullement, Madame, répondis-je, l'air qui environne la Terre ne s'étend que jusqu'à une certaine hauteur, peut-estre jusqu'à 20 lieües, il nous suit, & tourne avec nous. Vous avez veu mille fois l'ouvrage d'un Ver à Soye, ou ces Coques que ces petits animaux travaillent avec tant d'art pour s'y emprisonner. Elles sont d'une soye fort serrée, mais elles sont couvertes d'un certain duvet fort leger & fort lâche. C'est ainsi que la Terre, qui est assez solide, est couverte depuis sa surface jusqu'à vinght lieües de hauteur tout au plus, d'une espece de duvet, qui est l'air, & toute la Coque de Ver à Soye tourne en mesme temps. Au-delà de l'air est la matiere celeste, incomparablement plus pure, plus subtile, & mesme plus agitée que luy.</P015> <P016>Vous me présentez la Terre sous des idées bien méprisables, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. C'est pourtant sur cette Coque de Ver à Soye qu'il se fait de si grands Travaux, de si grandes Guerres, & qu'il regne de tous costez une si grande agitation. Oüy, répondis-je, & pendant ce temps-là la Nature qui n'entre point en connoissance de tous ces petits mouvemens particuliers, nous emporte tous ensemble d'un mouvement général, & se joüe de la petite boule.</P016> <P017>Il me semble, reprit-elle, qu'il est ridicule d'estre sur quelque chose qui tourne, & de se tourmenter tant; mais le malheur est qu'on n'est pas assez assuré qu'on tourne; car enfin, à ne vous rien celer, toutes les précautions que vous prenez pour empêcher qu'on ne s'apperçoive du mouvement de la Terre, me sont un peu suspectes. Est-il possible qu'il ne laissera pas quelque petite marque sensible à laquelle on le reconnoisse?</P017>
chunks.target_manual: <P008>Copernicus himself, said I, could not have comprehended it better: First then, we see some of our Neighbours passing by us, up to the Ears in Politicks, yet settling their Nation no better than we do the World in the Moon; then follows a great Sea, perhaps a Fleet of Ships, perhaps a Makrel-Boat, no matter whether; then come some of the Iroquois going to eat a Prisoner for their Breakfast, who seems as little concern'd as his Devourers: After appear the Women of the Land of Jesso, who spend all their time in dressing their Husbands Dinners and Suppers, and painting their Lips and Eye-brows blue, only to please the greatest Villains in the World: Then the fair Circassians, who are very free of their Favours, and grant all to the first Comer, except a little they reserve for their Husbands; then the Tartars going to steal Concubines for the Turks and Persians; and at last our own dear Countrymen, it may be in some points as ridiculous as the best of 'em. It is very pleasant, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, but to imagine what you tell me, tho' if I was above, and saw all this, I would have the Liberty to hasten or retard the motion of the Earth, according as the Objects pleas'd me more or less, and I assure you I should quickly send packing the Polititians and Maneaters, but should have a great curiosity for the Fair Circassians, for methinks they have a custom very particular. They are so extreamly Beautiful, said I, that their Husbands have enough, and to spare to a Stranger. I fear then, said she, the Women of our Country are very ugly, in respect of those Fair Ladies, for the Husbands part with nothing here, but keep all to themselves. 'Tis because they make more use, I reply'd, of-Hold your peace, said she, and no more of your Fooleries, I have a difficulty to clear, and you must be serious. As the Earth moves, the Air changeth every moment, so we breathe the Air of another Country: Not at all, I reply'd, for the Air which encompasseth the Earth, doth not extend above a certain height, perhaps 20 leagues it follows us and turns with us: Have you not seen the work of a Silk-Worm, the Shells which those little Animals imprison themselves in, and weave with so much Art; they are made of a Silk very close, but are covered with a Down very slack and soft: So the Earth which is solid, is covered from the surface 20 Leagues upwards, with a kind of Down, which is the Air, and all the Shell of the Silk-Worm turns at the same time: Beyond the Air is the Celestial Matter, incomparably more pure and subtile, and much more agitated than the Air: Your comparison, said, she, is somewhat mean, and yet what wonders are wrought, what Wars, what Changes in this little Shell? 'Tis true, I reply'd, but Nature takes no notice of such little particular Motions, but drives us along with the general motion, as if she were at Bouls. Methinks, said she, 'tis very ridiculous to be upon a thing that turns, and yet not be well assur'd that it doth turn; and to tell you the Truth, I begin to distrust the Reasons you give, why we should not be sensible of the Motion of the Earth; for is it possible there should not some little mark be left, by which we might perceive it?</P008>

explanations: The original's reflective observation about a vessel's potential discomfort ("qui n'y sera pas si à son aise que nous") is replaced by concrete, somewhat flippant examples ("perhaps a Fleet of Ships, perhaps a Makrel-Boat, no matter whether"), simplifying the abstract idea by replacing nuanced reflection with a list of specific, less thematically rich items.

The original "qui fera semblant de ne s'en pas soucier" (who will pretend not to care) implies a conscious act of stoicism. The translation "who seems as little concern'd" simplifies this psychological nuance to mere outward appearance, losing the complexity of pretense.

The English translation omits the entire clause describing the Tartar pilgrimage ("des Tartares qui iront fort devotement en Pelerinage vers ce Grand Prestre, qui ne sort jamais d'un lieu obscur où il n'est éclairé que par des Lampes, à la lumiere desquelles on l'adore"), which was present between the description of the Jesso women and the Circassians in the original. This omission simplifies the text by reducing its length, density, and the range of cultural examples presented.

The nuanced phrase "ce qu'elles croyent qui appartient essentiellement à leurs Maris" (what they believe essentially belongs to their husbands) is simplified to the more concrete and less subjective "a little they reserve for their Husbands." This reduces the psychological and abstract complexity of the original.

The original "de petits Tartares" (little Tartars) is simplified to "the Tartars." The omission of the adjective "petits" removes a layer of description or potential nuance (e.g., youth, or a slightly diminutive/condescending tone), thereby simplifying the characterization.

The original's self-referential and philosophical "nous qui debiterons peut-estre encore des resveries" (we who will perhaps still be uttering daydreams) is simplified into an external social commentary about "our own dear Countrymen" being "ridiculous." This shift changes the tone from nuanced self-mockery to a more direct and common type of observation.

The descriptive clauses "ceux qui s'embarrassent de Politique" (those who get entangled in politics) and "ceux qui mangent leurs Ennemis" (those who eat their enemies) are simplified by using more direct nominalizations ("the Polititians," "Maneaters") and a more colloquial idiom ("send packing"), resulting in less formal and more common vocabulary.

The somewhat abstract and elegant French "trovent dans leurs faveurs un superflu" (find in their favors a surplus) is simplified to the more common, concrete, and idiomatic English phrase "have enough, and to spare."

The French "Cela est cause qu'on prend davantage" (That is why one takes more/indulges more), a complete though euphemistic statement, is simplified by truncation and reformulation into an obscure, incomplete phrase "'Tis because they make more use... of-", effectively omitting the risqué implication and reducing the clarity and completeness of the original idea.

The impersonal French construction "il me vient une difficulté sérieuse" (a serious difficulty occurs to me) is simplified to the more direct, agentive English "I have a difficulty to clear." The explicit addition "and you must be serious" simplifies by making an implicit social expectation patent.

The French "d'un certain duvet" (of a certain down) is simplified to "with a Down." The omission of "un certain" (a certain) removes a subtle qualifier that suggests a specific but perhaps not easily definable quality, making the English description slightly more generic.

The qualifiers in "assez solide" (rather/quite solid) and "jusqu'à vinght lieües de hauteur tout au plus" (up to twenty leagues in height at the most) are omitted or reduced in the translation ("solid," "20 Leagues upwards"). This simplification makes the statements more absolute and less nuanced than the original French.

The Marquise's stronger statement "Vous me présentez la Terre sous des idées bien méprisables" (You present the Earth to me under very contemptible ideas) is simplified. The translation shifts the object of criticism from "ideas about Earth" to "Your comparison" and softens "bien méprisables" (very contemptible) to "somewhat mean," reducing the intensity and specificity of the original critique.

The vivid phrase "qu'il regne de tous costez une si grande agitation" (that such great agitation/turmoil reigns on all sides) is significantly simplified to the far more general and neutral term "what Changes." This simplification reduces the descriptive richness and emotional force of the original.

The direct metaphor "se joüe de la petite boule" (Nature makes sport of/plays with the little ball [Earth], implying mockery) is simplified by transformation into a more concrete simile: "as if she were at Bouls." This makes the image more specific and game-like but lessens the directness of Nature's disdainful interaction with the Earth.

The original connects the ridicule of being on a spinning Earth with "de se tourmenter tant" (to torment oneself so much about earthly matters). The translation omits this philosophical reflection on human anxiety, replacing it with uncertainty about Earth's motion ("and yet not be well assur'd that it doth turn"). This simplification narrows the scope of the Marquise's observation by removing a layer of existential commentary.

The phrase "toutes les précautions que vous prenez pour empêcher qu'on ne s'apperçoive" (all the precautions you take to prevent one from perceiving), suggesting active measures, is simplified to "the Reasons you give." This vocabulary shift ("précautions" to "Reasons") simplifies the nuance of the Marquise's suspicion, making it sound like a critique of arguments rather than potentially deliberate obfuscation.

chunks.source_manual: <P018>Les mouvemens les plus naturels, répondis-je, & les plus ordinaires sont ceux qui se font le moins sentir, & cela est vray jusque dans la Morale. Le mouvement de l'Amour propre nous est si naturel, que le plus souvent nous ne le sentons pas, & que nous croyons agir par d'autres principes. Ah! vous <IIM>moralisez</IIM>, dit- elle, quand il est question de <RW>Phisique</RW>, cela s'appelle baailler. Retirons-nous, aussi bien en Voila assez pour la premiere fois. Demain nous reviendrons icy, vous avec vos Systêmes, & moy avec mon Ignorance.</P018>
chunks.target_manual: <P009>All Motions, said I, the more common and Natural they are, are the less perceptible, and this holds true even in Morality; the motion of self Love is so natural to us, that for the most part we are not sensible of it, and we believe we act by other Principles: You are Moralizing, said she, to a question of <RW>Natural Philosophy</RW>: But 'tis enough for the first time, let us now go home, and meet here again to Morrow; you with your Systemes, and I with my ignorance.</P009>

explanations: The French phrase "sont ceux qui se font le moins sentir" (literally, "are those that make themselves felt the least") uses a periphrastic construction with a relative clause. The English "are the less perceptible" simplifies this structure to a more direct adjectival phrase, making the sentence slightly more concise and syntactically straightforward.

The English translation omits the final clause of the French sentence, "cela s'appelle baailler" (which means "that's called yawning," a figurative expression of boredom or inappropriateness). This omission shortens the sentence and removes a layer of idiomatic meaning, thereby simplifying the Marquise's retort and reducing its stylistic complexity and density.

The translation simplifies the French in several ways. "Retirons-nous" (Let's withdraw/retire) is rendered as the more common and concrete "let us now go home." The French phrase "aussi bien en Voila assez pour la premiere fois" (which loosely links "it's enough" to "let's withdraw" using "aussi bien" - besides/also) is rephrased and its components reordered into "But 'tis enough for the first time...". The conjunction "aussi bien" is omitted, and the introduction of "But" creates a different, more direct linkage to the preceding dialogue. This restructuring and vocabulary choice simplify the original expression and its flow.

chunks.source_manual: <P019>En retournant au Château je luy dis pour épuiser la matiere des Systêmes, qu'il y en avoit un troisiéme inventé par Ticho- Brahé qui, voulant absolument que la Terre fust immobile, la plaçoit au centre du Monde, & faisoit tourner autour d'elle le Soleil, autour duquel tournoient toutes les autres Planetes, parce que depuis les nouvelles Découvertes, il n'y avoit pas moyen de faire tourner les Planetes autour de la Terre. Mais la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, qui a le discernement vif & prompt, jugea qu'il y avoit trop d'affectation à exempter la Terre de tourner autour du Soleil, puis qu'on n'en pouvait pas exempter tant d'autres grands Corps; que le Soleil n'estoit plus si propre à tourner autour de la Terre, depuis que toutes les Planetes tournoient autour de luy; que ce Systême ne pouvoit estre propre tout au plus qu'à soûtenir l'Immobilité de la Terre, quand on avoit bien envie de la soûtenir, & nullement à la persuader; & enfin il fut résolu que nous nous en tiendrions à celuy de Copernic, qui est plus uniforme & plus riant, & n'a aucun mélange de préjugé. En effet la simplicité dont il est, vous persuade, & sa hardiesse vous fait plaisir.</P019>
chunks.target_manual: <P010>In returning back to the Castle, that I might say all I could on the Subject, I told her of a third Systeme, invented by Ticho Brahe, who had fix'd the Earth in the Centre of the World, turn'd the Sun round the Earth, and the rest of the Planets round the Sun; for since the new discoveries, there was no way left to have the Planets turn round the Earth. But the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, who had a quick apprehension, said, she thought it was too affected, among so many great Bodies, to exempt the Earth only from turning round the Sun; that it was improper to make the Sun turn round the Earth, when all the Planets turn round the Sun; and that tho' this Systeme was to prove the immobility of the Earth, yet she thought it very improbable: So we resolv'd to stick to Copernicus, whose opinion we thought most Uniform, Probable, and Diverting.</P010>

explanations: The French idiomatic and somewhat formal phrase "pour épuiser la matiere des Systêmes" (to exhaust the subject of Systems) is translated into the more common and straightforward English expression "that I might say all I could on the Subject," simplifying the vocabulary and reducing its stylistic formality.

The French phrase "qui a le discernement vif & prompt" (who has sharp and quick discernment) uses more elaborate vocabulary. The English translation "who had a quick apprehension" simplifies this to more common terms, reducing the richness of the original description of the Marquise's intellect.

The French "voulant absolument que la Terre fust immobile, la plaçoit au centre du Monde" (absolutely wanting the Earth to be immobile, placed it at the center of the world) highlights Tycho Brahe's strong insistence. The English "who had fix'd the Earth in the Centre of the World" simplifies this by presenting it as a descriptive feature of his system, downplaying the emphasis on his forceful motivation and the nuance of the subjunctive "fust."

The original French presents a nuanced argument: "que ce Systême ne pouvoit estre propre tout au plus qu'à soûtenir l'Immobilité de la Terre, quand on avoit bien envie de la soûtenir, & nullement à la persuader" (that this System could at best be suitable only for supporting the Earth's immobility, when one really wanted to support it, and not at all for persuading). The English translation "and that tho' this Systeme was to prove the immobility of the Earth, yet she thought it very improbable" drastically simplifies this complex critique into a more direct judgment of improbability, reducing the density and intricacy of the original reasoning.

The French description of Copernicus's system, "qui est plus uniforme & plus riant, & n'a aucun mélange de préjugé" (which is more uniform and more pleasing/attractive, and has no mixture of prejudice), is simplified. The English "whose opinion we thought most Uniform, Probable, and Diverting" omits the distinct point about the system having "no mixture of prejudice" and introduces "Probable," thereby altering and reducing the specific justifications offered in the original.

chunks.source_manual: <P021>Le lendemain au matin dés que l'on pût entrer dans l'Appartement de la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, j'envoyay sçavoir de ses nouvelles, & luy demander si elle avoit pû dormir en tournant. Elle me fit répondre qu'elle estoit déjà toute accoûtumée à cette allûre de la Terre, & qu'elle avoit passé la nuit aussi tranquillement qu'auroit pû faire Copernic luy-mesme. Quelque temps après il vint chez elle du monde qui y demeura jusqu'au soir, selon l'ennuyeuse coutume de la Campagne. Encore leur fut-on bien obligé, car la Campagne leur donnoit aussi le droit de pousser leur visite jusqu'au lendemain, s'ils eussent voulu, & ils eurent l'honnesteté de ne le pas faire. Ainsi la <IIM>Marquise</IIM> & moy nous nous retrouvâmes libres le Soir. Nous allâmes encore dans le Parc, & la Conversation ne manqua pas de tourneraussi-tost sur nos Sistêmes. Elle les avoit si bien conceus, qu'elle dédaigna d'en parler une seconde fois, & elle voulut que je la menasse a quelque chose de nouveau. Et bien donc, luy dis-je, puis que le Soleil, qui est presentement immobile, a cessé d'estre Planete, & que la Terre qui se meut autour de luy, a commencé d'en estre une, vous ne serez pas si surprise d'entendre dire que la Lune est une Terre comme celle-cy, & qu'apparemment elle est habitée. Je n'ay pourtant jamais oüy parler de la Lune habitée, dit-elle, que comme d'une <IIM>folie & d'une vision</IIM>. C'en est peut-estre une aussi, répondis-je. Je ne prens party dans ces choses-là que comme on en prend dans les Guerres Civiles, où l'incertitude de ce qui peut arriver, fait qu'on entretient toûjours des <IIM>intelligences</IIM> dans le party opposé, & <IIM>qu'on a des ménagemens avec ses Ennemis mesmes</IIM>. Pour moy, quoyque je voye la Lune habitée, je ne laisse pas de vivre civilement avec ceux qui ne le croyent pas, <SC></SC> & je me tiens toûjours en estat de me pouvoir ranger à leur opinion avec honneur, si elle avoit le dessus; mais en attendant qu'ils ayent sur nous quelque avantage considérable, voyci ce qui m'a mis du côté des Habitans de la Lune.</P021>
chunks.target_manual: <P012>IN the Morning, I sent to the <IIM>Countess's</IIM> Apartment, to know how she had rested, and whether the Motion of the Earth had not disturb'd her? she answer'd, she began to be accustom'd to it, and that she had slept as well as Copernicus himself: Soon after there came some Neighbours to dine with her, but they went away in the Evening; so that after Supper we walk'd again into the Park, and immediately fell upon our Systemes. She so well conceiv'd what I told her the night before, that she desir'd I would proceed without any repetition. Well, Madam, said I, Since the Sun, which is now immoveable, hath left off being a Planet; and the Earth, which turns round him, is now become one, you will not be surprized when you hear that the Moon is an Earth too, and that she is inhabited as ours is. I confess, said she, I have often heard talk of the World in the Moon, but I always look'd upon it as Visionary and meer Fancy. And it may be so still, said I. I am in this case as People in a Civil War, where the uncertainty of what may happen makes 'em hold intelligence with the opposite Party; for tho' I verily believe the Moon is inhabited, I live civilly vvith those who do not believe it; and I am <RW>(as some honest Gentlemen in point of Religion)</RW> still ready to embrace the prevailing Opinion, but till the Unbelievers have a more considerable Advantage, I am for the People in the Moon.</P012>

explanations: The French temporal clause "dés que l'on pût entrer dans l'Appartement de la Marquise" (as soon as one could enter the Marquise's Apartment) is effectively omitted, simplifying the introduction by reducing specificity about the timing. Additionally, the inquiry "si elle avoit pû dormir en tournant" (if she had been able to sleep while turning) is rephrased to the more explicit "whether the Motion of the Earth had not disturb'd her?", simplifying the implied connection for the reader.

The French "Elle me fit répondre" (She had [someone] reply / She sent word), implying an indirect response, is simplified to the direct "she answer'd". "déjà toute accoûtumée" (already completely accustomed) is rendered as the less emphatic "began to be accustom'd". The specific phrase "cette allûre de la Terre" (this gait/pace of the Earth) is simplified to the pronoun "it", relying more on context.

The translator omits the narrator's subjective commentary "selon l'ennuyeuse coutume de la Campagne" (according to the tiresome custom of the countryside). This removal simplifies the text by stripping away a layer of authorial voice and social observation, reducing stylistic richness and making the sentence more purely factual.

The French idiomatic and slightly periphrastic construction "ne manqua pas de tourner aussi-tost sur" (did not fail to turn immediately upon) is simplified to the more direct and concise English phrasal verb "immediately fell upon."

The strong French verb "dédaigna" (disdained), which implies scorn or looking down upon repeating the topic, is simplified to the much milder "desir'd I would proceed without any repetition." This reduces the intensity of the Marquise's expressed sentiment and simplifies her character's assertiveness.

The French "d'entendre dire" (to hear it said), with its slightly impersonal nuance, is simplified to the more direct "when you hear". Concurrently, the descriptive phrase "comme celle-cy" (like this one, i.e., Earth) is condensed to the simpler adverb "too", making the sentence more concise.

The French "n'ay ... jamais oüy parler ... que comme ..." (have never heard ... except as ...) is a somewhat complex negative construction emphasizing she *only* heard of it in a certain negative way. The English simplifies this to a more common structure: "I have often heard ... but I always look'd upon it as ...", also changing the frequency of her exposure from 'never except as' to 'often'. The introductory "pourtant" (however/yet) is replaced by "I confess", shifting the tone.

The French construction "Je ne prens party ... que comme ..." (I only take sides ... as ...) is simplified to "I am in this case as ...". The adverb "toûjours" (always) is omitted, reducing emphasis on the constancy of maintaining intelligences. Furthermore, the entire final clause "& qu'on a des ménagemens avec ses Ennemis mesmes" (and that one shows consideration/maintains careful relations even with one's Enemies) is omitted, reducing sentence length and the analogy's detail.

The French idiomatic construction "je ne laisse pas de vivre" (I do not fail/cease to live) is simplified to the more direct affirmative "I live civilly", removing the periphrasis and making the statement more straightforward.

The complex French expression of cautious political readiness, "je me tiens toûjours en estat de me pouvoir ranger à leur opinion avec honneur, si elle avoit le dessus", is simplified. The specific condition "si elle avoit le dessus" (if it [their opinion] had the upper hand) is condensed into the adjective "prevailing" modifying "Opinion." Crucially, the qualifier "avec honneur" (with honor), which conveys the philosopher's concern for his reputation, is omitted, reducing nuance.

The phrase "sur nous" (over us), indicating whom the advantage is over, is omitted, slightly simplifying the comparison. More significantly, the somewhat formal and periphrastic introductory statement "voyci ce qui m'a mis du côté des Habitans de la Lune" (here is what has put me on the side of the Inhabitants of the Moon) is simplified to the very direct and concise "I am for the People in the Moon."

chunks.source_manual: <P022>Suposons qu'il n'y ait jamais eu nul commerce entre <NCE>Paris & Saint-Denis</NCE>, & qu'un Bourgeois de Paris qui ne sera jamais sorty de sa Ville, soit sur les Tours de <NCE>Nostre Dame</NCE>, & voye <NCE>Saint Denis</NCE> de loin, on luy demandera s'il croit que <NCE>Saint Denis</NCE> soit habité <SC>comme Paris</SC>. Il répondra hardiment que non; car, dira- t-il, je voy bien les Habitans de Paris, mais ceux de Saint Denis, je ne les voy point, & on n'en a jamais entendu parler. Il y aura quelqu'un qui luy representera qu'à la verité quand on est sur les <NCE>Tours de Nostre Dame</NCE>, on ne voit pas les Habitans de Saint Denis, mais que l'éloignement en est cause; que tout ce qu'on peut voir de Saint Denis ressemble fort à Paris: que Saint Denis a des Clochers, des Maisons, des Murailles, & qu'il pourroit bien encore ressembler à Paris pour ce qui est d'estre habité. Tout cela ne gagnera rien sur mon Bourgeois, il s'obstinera toûjours à soûtenir que Saint Denis n'est point habité, puis qu'il n'y voit personne. Nostre Saint Denis c'est la Lune, & chacun de nous est ce Bourgeois de Paris, qui n'est jamais sorty de sa Ville.</P022> <P023>Ah! interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, vous nous faites tort, nous ne sommes point si sots que vostre Bourgeois. Puis qu'il voit que Saint Denis est tout fait comme Paris, il faut qu'il ait perdu la raison pour ne le pas croire habité; mais la Lune n'est point du tout faite comme la Terre. Prenez garde, Madame, repris-je, car s'il faut que la Lune ressemble en tout à la Terre, vous Voila dans l'obligation de croire la Lune habitée. J'avoüe, répondit-elle, qu'il n'y aura pas moyen de s'en dispenser, & je vous vois un air de confiance qui me fait déjà peur. Les deux mouvemens de la Terre dont je ne me fusse jamais doutée, me <IIM>rendent timide sur tout le reste</IIM>, mais pourtant seroit-il bien possible que la Terre fût lumineuse comme la Lune? Car il faut cela pour leur ressemblance. Helas! Madame, repliquay-je, estre lumineux n'est pas si grand-chose que vous pensez. Il n'y a que le Soleil en qui cela soit une qualité considérable. Il est lumineux par luy-mesme, & en vertu d'une nature particuliere qu'il a, mais les Planetes n'éclairent que parce qu'elles sont éclairées de luy. Il envoye sa lumiere à la Lune, elle nous la renvoye, & il faut que la Terre renvoye aussi à la Lune la lumiere du Soleil; il n'y a pas plus loin de la Terre à la Lune, que de la Lune à la Terre.</P023> <P024>Mais, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, la Terre est-elle aussi propre que la Lune à renvoyer la lumiere au Soleil? Je vous vois toûjours pour la Lune, repris-je, un reste d'estime dont vous ne sçauriez vous défaire. La lumiere est composée de petites balles qui bondissent sur ce qui est solide <UP></UP>, & retournent d'un autre costé, au lieu qu'elles passent au travers de ce qui leur presente des ouvertures en ligne droite, comme l'air ou le verre. Ainsi ce qui fait que la Lune nous éclaire, c'est qu'elle est un Corps dur & solide, qui nous renvoye ces petites balles. Or je croy que vous ne contesterez pas à la Terre cette mesme dureté & cette mesme solidité. Admirez donc ce que c'est que d'estre posté avantageusement. Parce que la Lune est éloignée de nous, nous ne la voyons que comme un Corps lumineux, & nous ignorons que ce soit une grosse masse, toute semblable à la Terre. <IIM>Au contraire,</IIM> parce que la Terre a le malheur que nous la voyons de trop prés, elle ne nous paroist qu'une grosse masse, propre seulement à fournir de la pasture aux Animaux, & nous ne nous apercevons pas qu'elle est lumineuse, faute de nous pouvoir mettre à quelque distance d'elle. Cela va de la mesme maniere, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que quand nous sommes frapez de l'éclat des Conditions élevées au-dessus des nostres, & que nous ne voyons pas qu'au fond elles se ressemblent toutes extremement.</P024> <P025>C'est la mesme chose, répondis-je. Nous voulons juger de tout, & nous sommes toûjours dans un mauvais point de veüe. Nous voulons juger de nous, nous en sommes trop près; nous voulons juger des autres, nous en sommes trop loin. Qui serait entre la Lune & la Terre, ce seroit la vraye place pour les bien voir. Il faudroit estre simplement Spectateur du Monde, & non pas Habitant. Je ne me consoleray jamais, dit-elle, de l'injustice que nous faisons à la Terre, & de la préoccupation trop favorable où nous sommes pour la Lune, si vous ne m'assurez que les Gens de la Lune ne connaissent pas mieux leurs avantages que nous connoissons les nostres, & qu'ils prennent nostre Terre pour un Astre, sans sçavoir que leur habitation en est un aussi. Pour cela, repris-je, je vous le garantis. Nous leur paroissons faire assez regulierement nos fonctions d'Astres. Il est vray qu'ils ne nous voyent pas décrire un Cercle autour d'eux, mais il n'importe, voicy ce que c'est. La moitié de la Lune qui se trouva tournée vers nous au commencement du Monde, y a toûjours esté tournée depuis; elle ne nous presente jamais que ces yeux, cette bouche, & le reste de ce visage que nostre imagination luy compose sur le fondement des tâches qu'elle nous montre. Si l'autre moitié opposée se presentoit à nous, d'autres tâches differemment arrangées, nous feroient sans doute imaginer quelque autre figure. Ce n'est pas que la Lune ne tourne sur elle-mesme, elle y tourne en autant de temps qu'autour de la Terre, c'est à dire, en un mois; mais lors qu'elle fait une partie de ce tremblement <RW></RW>, & de s'imaginer que nous avons dans le Ciel comme un mouvement de Pendule qui va & vient.</P025>
chunks.target_manual: <P013>Suppose there had never been any Communication between <NCE>London and Greenwich</NCE>, and a Cockney, who was never beyond the Walls of London, saw Greenwich from the top of the Pyramid; you ask him if he believes Greenwich is inhabited as London is? He presently answers, No; for, saith he, I see People at London, but none at Greenwich; nor did I ever hear of any there: 'Tis true, you tell him, that from the Pyramid he cannot perceive any Inhabitants at Greenwich, because of the distance; but all that he doth discover of Greenwich very much resembleth what he sees at London, the Steeples, Houses, Walls; so that it may very well be inhabited as London is; all this signifies nothing, my Cockney still persists Greenwich is not inhabited, because he sees no body there. The Moon is our Greenwich, and every one of us as meer Cockneys as he that never was out of the sound of Bow-Bell. You are too severe, said she, upon your Fellow-Citizens; we are not all sure so silly as your Cockney; since Greenwich is just as London is, he is a Fool if he doth not think it inhabited: But the Moon is not at all like the Earth. Have a care what you say, I reply'd, for if the Moon resembleth the Earth, you are under a necessity to believe it inhabited. If it be so, said she, I own I cannot be dispens'd from believing it, and you seem so confident of it, that I fear I must, whether I will or no. 'Tis true, the two Motions of the Earth (which I could never imagine till now) do a little stagger me as to all the rest: But yet how is it possible the Earth should enlighten as the Moon doth, without which they cannot be alike? If that be all, said I, the difference is not great, for 'tis the Sun which is the sole Fountain of Light; that Quality proceeds only from him, and if the Planets give Light to us, it is because they first receive it from the Sun; the Sun sends Light to the Moon, and she reflects it back on the Earth; the Earth in the same manner receives Light from the Sun, and sends it to the Moon; for the Distance is the same between the Earth and the Moon, as between the Moon and the Earth. But is the Earth, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, as fit to send back the Light of the Sun as the Moon is? You are altogether for the Moon, said I, she is much oblig'd to you; but you must know that Light is made up of certain little Balls, which rebound from what is solid, but pass through what admits of an entrance in a right Line, as Air or Glass: So that, that which makes the Moon enlighten us, is that she is a Firm and Solid Body, from which the little Balls rebound; and we must deny our Senses, if we will not allow the Earth the same Solidity; in short, the Difference is how we are seated, for the Moon being at so vast a Distance from us, we can only discover her to be a Body of Light, and do not perceive that she is a great Masse, altogether like the Earth: Whereas on the contrary, because we are so near the Earth, we know her to be a great Masse, but do not discover her to be a Body of Light, for want of the due distance: It is just so with us all, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, we are dazled with the Quality and Fortune of those who are above us, when, do but look to the Bottom, and we are all alike.</P013> <P014>Very true, said I, we would judge of all things, but still stand in the wrong place; we are too near to judge of our selves, and too far off to know others: So that the true way to see things as they are, is to be between the Moon and the Earth, to be purely a Spectator of this World, and not an Inhabitant. I shall never be satisfy'd, said she, for the Injustice we do the Earth, and the too favourable opinion we have of the Moon, till you assure me that the People in the Moon are as little acquainted with their Advantages, as we are with ours, and that they take our Earth for a Planet, without knowing theirs is one too. Do not doubt it, said I, we appear to them to perform very regularly our function of a Planet: 'Tis true, they do not see us make a Circle round them, but that is no great matter. That half of the Moon which was turn'd towards us at the beginning of the World, hath been turn'd towards us ever since; the Eyes, Mouth, and Face which we have fancy'd of the Spots in her, are still the same, and if the other opposite half should appear to us, we should no doubt fancy another Figure from the different Spots that are in it: Not but that the Moon turns upon her self, and in the same time that she turns round the Earth, that is in a Month; but while she is making that turn upon her self, and that she should hide a cheek for Example, and appear somewhat else to us, she makes a like part of her Circle round the Earth, and still presents to us the same Cheek; so that the Moon, who in respect of the Sun and Stars turns round her self, in respect of us doth not turn at all; they seem to her to rise and set in the space of fifteen Days; but for our Earth, it appears to her to be held up in the same place of the Heavens: 'Tis true, this apparent Immobility is not very agreeable for a Body which should pass for a Planet, but it is not altogether perfect, the Moon hath a kind of trembling, which causeth a little corner of her Face to be sometimes hid from us, and a little corner of the opposite half appears; but then upon my word, she attributes that trembling to us, and fancies that we have in the Heavens the motion of a Pendulum, which vibrates to and fro.</P014>

explanations: The impersonal French construction "Il y aura quelqu'un qui luy representera" (There will be someone who will point out to him) is simplified to a direct address "you tell him," making the narrative more immediate and less formal. The complex sentence with multiple subordinate clauses beginning with "que" is anchored by this more direct address.

The original French "il faut qu'il ait perdu la raison" (it must be that he has lost his reason), a more formal and complex modal construction, is simplified to the direct and colloquial English phrase "he is a Fool." This simplifies both vocabulary and sentence structure.

The phrase "& en vertu d'une nature particuliere qu'il a" (by virtue of a particular nature that it has), which suggests a specific, inherent quality, is simplified to the more general statement "that Quality proceeds only from him," reducing some of the philosophical nuance for a more straightforward assertion.

The nuanced psychological observation in French, "un reste d'estime dont vous ne sçauriez vous défaire" (a remnant of esteem of which you cannot rid yourself), is replaced by the simpler, more direct, and somewhat ironic social phrase "she is much oblig'd to you." This simplification omits a layer of character insight and subtle interaction.

The philosopher's polite but direct challenge, "Or je croy que vous ne contesterez pas à la Terre cette mesme dureté & cette mesme solidité" (Now I believe that you will not contest for the Earth this same hardness and this same solidity), is transformed into a stronger, more impersonal rhetorical appeal: "and we must deny our Senses, if we will not allow the Earth the same Solidity." This simplifies the direct conversational engagement into a universalized argument and also reduces "cette mesme dureté & cette mesme solidité" to the singular "the same Solidity" in the direct comparison.

The evocative French imperative "Admirez donc ce que c'est que d'estre posté avantageusement" (Admire then what it is to be advantageously positioned) is reduced to the plainer, more functional statement "in short, the Difference is how we are seated." This simplifies the figurative language and the direct call to admiration.

The anthropomorphic phrase "la Terre a le malheur que nous la voyons de trop prés" (the Earth has the misfortune that we see it from too close) is simplified by removing "a le malheur" (has the misfortune). Additionally, the descriptive detail "propre seulement à fournir de la pasture aux Animaux" (fit only to provide pasture for Animals) is entirely omitted, significantly reducing textual density and a specific element illustrating Earth's mundane close-up appearance.

The French "l'éclat des Conditions élevées au-dessus des nostres" (the brilliance of Conditions elevated above ours) is rendered more concretely as "the Quality and Fortune of those who are above us." More significantly, the nuanced phrase "qu'au fond elles se ressemblent toutes extremement" (at bottom they all resemble each other extremely) is simplified to the more direct and absolute statement "we are all alike," reducing the subtlety of the original comparison.

The French phrase "nous sommes toûjours dans un mauvais point de veüe" (we are always in a bad point of view) is simplified to the more concrete and less formal English "but still stand in the wrong place."

The hypothetical French construction "Qui serait entre la Lune & la Terre, ce seroit la vraye place pour les bien voir" (He who would be between the Moon & the Earth, that would be the true place to see them well) is simplified into a more direct indicative statement: "So that the true way to see things as they are, is to be between the Moon and the Earth," making the assertion less conditional and more straightforward.

The French transitional phrase "mais il n'importe, voicy ce que c'est" (but it doesn't matter, here is what it is / here's the thing), which signals an upcoming explanation, is omitted in the English translation after "but that is no great matter." This simplifies the text by removing explicit signposting.

The complex French sentence "elle ne nous presente jamais que ces yeux, cette bouche, & le reste de ce visage que nostre imagination luy compose sur le fondement des tâches qu'elle nous montre" (it never presents to us but these eyes, this mouth, & the rest of this face that our imagination composes for it on the foundation of the spots that it shows us) is significantly simplified. The English version restructures this into a more direct statement, and the clause "sur le fondement des tâches" (on the foundation/basis of the spots) is reduced to "of the Spots," simplifying the expressed causal link.

The concise French phrase "une partie de ce tremblement" is elaborated upon ("which causeth a little corner of her Face to be sometimes hid from us, and a little corner of the opposite half appears"). More significantly, the somewhat abrupt infinitive phrase "& de s'imaginer que nous avons..." (and to imagine that we have...) is expanded into a clearer, more explicit series of clauses: "she attributes that trembling to us, and fancies that we have...". This simplifies comprehension by making the agent (the Moon) and the action (attributing and fancying) more direct and less ambiguous than the dense French construction implies.

chunks.source_manual: <P026>Toutes ces Planetes, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, sont faites comme nous, qui rejettons toûjours sur les autres ce qui est en nous-mesmes. La Terre dit, Ce n'est pas moy qui tourne, c'est le Soleil. La Lune dit, Ce n'est pas moy qui tremble, c'est la Terre. Il y a bien de l'erreur par tout. Je ne vous conseille pas d'entreprendre d'y rien réformer, répondis-je; il vaut mieux que vous acheviez de vous convaincre de l'entiere ressemblance de la Terre & de la Lune. Representez-vous ces deux grandes Boules suspendües dans les Cieux. Vous sçavez que le Soleil éclaire toûjours une moitié des Corps qui sont ronds, & que l'autre moitié est dans l'ombre. Il y a donc toûjours une moitié, tant de la Terre que de la Lune, qui est éclairée du Soleil, c'est à dire, qui a le jour, & une autre moitié qui est dans la nuit. Remarquez d'ailleurs que comme une Balle a moins de force & de vistesse aprés qu'elle a esté donner contre une muraille qui l'a renvoyée d'un autre costé, de mesme la lumiere s'affoiblit lors qu'elle a esté réfléchie par quelque Corps. Cette lumiere blanchâtre qui nous vient de la Lune, est la lumiere mesme du Soleil, mais elle ne peut venir de la Lune à nous que par une réflexion. Elle a donc beaucoup perdu de la force & de la vivacité qu'elle avoit lors qu'elle estoit receüe directement sur la Lune, & cette lumiere éclatante que nous recevons directement du Soleil & que la Terre reflechit sur la Lune, ne doit plus estre qu'une lumiere blanchâtre quand elle y est arrivée. Ainsi ce qui nous paroit lumineux dans la Lune, & qui nous éclaire pendant nos nuits, ce sont des parties de la Lune qui ont le jour, & les parties de la Terre qui ont le jour, lors qu'elles sont tournées vers les parties de la Lune qui ont la nuit, les éclairent aussi. Tout dépend de la maniere dont la Lune & la Terre se regardent. Dans les premiers jours du mois que l'on ne voit pas la Lune, c'est qu'elle est entre le Soleil & nous, & qu'elle marche de jour avec le Soleil. Il faut necessairement que toute sa moitié qui a le jour, soit tournée vers le Soleil, & que toute sa moitié qui a la nuit, soit tournée vers nous. Nous n'avons garde de voir cette moitié qui n'a aucune lumiere pour se faire voir. Mais cette moitié de la Lune qui a la nuit, estant tournée vers la moitié de la Terre qui a le jour, nous voit sans estre veüe, & nous voit sous la même figure que nous voyons la Pleine Lune. C'est alors pour les Gens de la Lune Pleine Terre, s'il est permis de parler ainsi. Ensuite la Lune qui avance sur son Cercle d'un mois, se dégage de dessous le Soleil, & commence à tourner vers nous un petit coin de sa moitié éclairée, & voila le Croissant. Alors aussi les parties de la Lune qui ont la nuit, commencent à ne plus voir toute la moitié de la Terre qui a le jour, & nous sommes en Decours pour elles.</P026>
chunks.target_manual: <P015>I find, saith the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, the Planets are just like us; we cast that upon others which is in our selves; the Earth saith, 'Tis not I that turn, 'tis the Sun; the Moon saith, 'tis not I that shake, 'tis the Earth; there is a great deal of errour every where. But I would not advise you, said I, to undertake the reforming it; you had better convince your self of the entire resemblance of the Earth and the Moon: Imagine then these two great Bowls held up in the Heavens, you know that the Sun always enlightens the one half of a Body that is round, and the other half is in the Shadow; there is then one half of the Earth and one half of the Moon which is enlightned by the Sun; that is, which hath Day, and the other half which is Night. Observe also, that as a Ball hath less force after it hath been struck against a Wall which sends it to the other side, so Light is weakned when it is reflected. This pale Light which comes to us from the Moon, is the very Light of the Sun, but it cannot come to us from the Moon but by reflection; it hath lost much of the Force and Lustre it had when it came directly from the Sun upon the Moon; and that bright Light which shines directly upon us from the Sun, and which the Earth reflects upon the Moon, is as pale and weak when it arrives there; so that the Light which appears to us in the Moon, and which enlightens our Nights, is the parts of the Moon which have Day, and that part of the Earth which hath Day, when it is opposite to the part of the Moon which hath Night, gives Light to it: All depends upon how the Moon and the Earth behold one another. At the beginning of the Month we do not see the Moon, because she is between the Sun and us; that half of her which hath Day, is then turn'd towards the Sun, and that half which hath Night, turn'd towards us; we cannot see it then, because it hath no Light upon it; but that half of the Moon which hath Night, being turn'd to the half of the Earth which hath Day, sees us without being perceiv'd, and we then appear to them just as the full Moon doth to us; so that, as I may say, the People of the Moon have then a full Earth; but the Moon being advanc'd upon her Circle of a Month, comes from under the Sun, and begins to turn towards us a little corner of the half which is Light, there's the Crescent; then those parts of the Moon which have Night do not see all the half of the Earth which hath Day, and we are then in the Wayn to them.</P015>
