explanations: The French "je ne puis me resoudre à" (I cannot resolve myself to) is a more complex, reflexive psychological construction. The English "I can never suffer" (in the sense of "tolerate" or "allow") is more direct and uses simpler vocabulary to convey a similar meaning of unwillingness, simplifying the internal deliberation implied by "me resoudre".

The original French "de les tirer d'un endroit si facheux" (to pull them from such a vexing place) describes a direct action of rescue by the Moon for the souls. The English "to get into the Light again" simplifies this by focusing on the Moon's movement as the method of relief, rather than the more direct extrication of the souls from the "endroit facheux" (vexing place).

The translator has omitted the latter part of the Marquise's French sentence, which follows 'car apparemment on nous les envoye aussi' (translated as 'for certainly they are sent to us'). This omitted segment offers a somewhat cynical or complex philosophical reflection on how happiness for souls is conceived. This omission simplifies the Marquise's characterization and reduces the density of the philosophical commentary.

The French uses litotes ("un plaisir non mediocre," meaning a great pleasure), a more complex rhetorical device. The English "it would be very pleasant" translates the meaning directly, simplifying the stylistic complexity by removing the understatement.

The French "tout ce qui estoit de ma connoissance" (everything that was of my knowledge) is a slightly more formal and abstract phrasing. The English "all I can shew you" is more direct, active, and uses more common phrasing, simplifying the original's construction.

The French "je reprens le Saint Denis" (I take up again Saint Denis / Saint Denis comes to mind again) contains a specific cultural reference ("Saint Denis") likely obscure to the English audience of the time. The translator replaces it with "Greenwich," a familiar English landmark. This modification simplifies the text for the target reader by substituting an obscure reference with a familiar one, enhancing readability and accessibility at the cost of specific cultural nuance.

The French "ce Pourquoy a une vertu qui suffira pour peupler tout" (this Why has a power/virtue that will suffice to populate everything) is a witty and figurative philosophical statement. The English "for I see no reason to the contrary" is a far more prosaic, common, and rationalistic expression, simplifying the original's abstract and stylistically rich language.

The French presents a complex hypothetical construction with multiple subordinate clauses ("il faudroit concevoir que... que... et que..."). The English simplifies this by breaking it into a conditional clause followed by more direct statements and questions ("I think they were made but to little purpose; why should Nature be so partial..."). This simplifies the sentence structure and changes the rhetorical approach from reported thought to direct argument, enhancing readability.

The original French details the Marquise's direct observation of the philosopher's shifting conviction and her specific prediction of his anger ("vous vous mettriez en colere"). The English translation generalizes this into a proverbial statement ("a Philosopher will never make a good Martyr, you can so quickly shift your Opinion") and omits the direct accusation of anger. This simplification changes the specific, personal observation into a more abstract, less pointed commentary, reducing the directness and emotional specificity.

The French provides a nuanced self-reflection on the nature of belief and the philosopher's specific state of mind, including the candid admission "je crois que je vous aurois dit comment ils estoient tous faits" (I believe I would have told you how they were all made). The English drastically simplifies this by substituting a colloquial idiom ("as the Maggot bites") and a generalized, almost flippant statement about philosophers. The specific, imaginative claim of knowing "how they were all made" is replaced by a more generic fantastical example ("a Nation in a Mustard Ball"), simplifying the original's detailed psychological self-portrayal into a more stereotypical depiction using more common vocabulary and imagery.

The French "que je suis un peu plus de sens froid, je ne laisse pas de trouver qu'il seroit bien étrange que..." (now that I am a bit more cool-headed, I nevertheless find that it would be very strange that...) shows a reasoned return to a position. The English "but the tide is turn'd, and all the Planets are Peopled like an Anthill;" replaces this careful reasoning with a colloquial idiom ("the tide is turn'd") and a highly assertive, imagistic statement. This simplifies the argumentative process and the language used to express the shift in thought, opting for more common idiomatic expressions.

The French uses a concise and powerful metaphor: the mite ("Ciron") being "l'Elephant" to yet smaller creatures. The English translation simplifies this by explicating the metaphor: instead of the direct "dont il est l'Elephant," it provides an analogy ("as little in comparison with a Mite, as a Mite is of an Ox"). This explication makes the concept more immediately accessible but reduces the stylistic density and metaphorical richness of the original.

The French text describes a sequence of actions leading to an observation ("Mix... or expose... or let them spoil, thereupon immediately [appear] new species..."). The English translation simplifies this by omitting the descriptive process entirely and replacing it with a brief, allusive list of examples ("not to name the blue on Plums, and twenty Experiments of the like nature."). This significantly reduces the length and detail of the original scientific observation, thereby simplifying the text.

chunks.source_manual: <P050>Beaucoup de Corps qui paroissent solides <UP></UP>, ne sont que des amas de ces Animaux imperceptibles, qui y trouvent pour leurs mouvemens autant de liberté qu'il leur en faut. Une feüille d'Arbre est un petit Monde habité par des Vermisseaux invisibles, à qui elle paroist d'une étenduë immense, qui y connoissent des Montagnes & des Abismes, & qui d'un costé de la feüille à l'autre n'ont pas plus de communication avec les autres Vermisseaux qui y vivent, que nous avec nos Antipodes. A plus forte raison, ce me semble, une <RW>grosse</RW> Planete sera-t-elle un Monde habité. On a trouvé jusque dans des especes de pierres tres-dures de petits Vers sans nombre, qui y étoient logez de toutes parts dans des vuides insensibles, & qui ne se nourrissoient que de la substance de ces pierres qu'ils rongeoient. Figurez-vous combien il y avoit de ces petits Vers, & pendant combien d'années ils subsistoient de la grosseur d'un grain de sable; & sur cet exemple, quand la Lune ne seroit qu'un amas de rochers, je la ferois plûtost ronger par ses Habitans que de n'y en pas mettre. Enfin tout est vivant, tout est animé <UP></UP>: mettez toutes ces especes d'Animaux nouvellement découvertes, & mesme toutes celles que l'on conçoit aisément qui sont encore à découvrir, avec celles que l'on a toûjours veuës, vous trouverez assurément que la Terre est bien peuplée, & que la Nature y a si liberalement répandu les Animaux, qu'elle ne s'est pas mise en peine que l'on en vist seulement la moitié. Croirez-vous qu'aprés qu'elle a poussé icy sa fecondité jusqu'à l'excés, elle a esté pour toutes les autres Planetes d'une sterilité à n'y rien produire de vivant?</P050> <P051>Ma raison est assez bien convaincuë, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, mais mon imagination est accablée de la multitude infinie des Habitans de toutes ces Planetes, & embarrassée de la diversité qu'il faut établir entre eux; car je voy bien que la Nature, selon qu'elle est ennemie des repetitions, les aura tous faits différens, mais comment se representer cela? Ce n'est pas à l'imagination à prétendre le représenter, répondis-je, elle n'est pas propre à aller plus loin que les yeux. On peut seulement apercevoir d'une certaine veuë universelle, la diversité que la Nature doit avoir mise entre tous ces Mondes. Tous les visages sont en general sur un mesme modele; mais ceux de deux grandes Nations, comme des Européens, si vous voulez, & des Africains, paroissent estre faits sur deux modeles particuliers, & il faudroit encore trouver le modele des visages de chaque Famille. Quel secret doit avoir eu la Nature pour varier en tant de manieres une chose aussi simple qu'un visage? Nous ne sommes dans l'Univers que comme une petite Famille, dont tous les visages se ressemblent; dans une autre Planete, c'est une autre Famille dont les visages ont un autre air. <UP></UP>.</P051> <P052>Apparemment les differences augmentent à mesure que l'on s'éloigne, & qui verroit un Habitant de la Lune, & un Habitant de la Terre, remarqueroit bien qu'ils seroient de deux Mondes plus voisions qu'un Habitant de la Terre & un Habitant de Saturne. Icy, <NCP>par exemple</NCP>, on a l'usage de la voix, ailleurs on ne parle que par signes, plus loin on ne parle point du tout. Icy le raisonnemét se forme entierement par l'experience; ailleurs l'experience y ajoûte fort peu de chose, plus loin les Vieillards n'en sçavent pas plus que les Enfants. Icy on se tourmente de l'avenir plus que du passé; plus loin on ne se tourmente ny de l'un ny de l'autre, & ceux-là ne sont peut-estre pas les plus malheureux. On dit qu'il pourroit bien nous manquer un sixiéme Sens naturel, qui nous aprendroit beaucoup de choses que nous ignorons. Ce sixiéme Sens est apparemment dans quelque autre Monde, où il manque quelqu'un des cinq que nous possedons. Peut-estre mesme y a-t-il effectivement un grand nombre de Sens naturels; mais dans le partage que nous avons fait avec les Habitans des autres Planetes, il ne nous en est écheu que cinq, dont nous nous contentons faute d'en connoistre d'autres. Nos Sciences ont de certaines bornes que l'Esprit humain n'a jamais pû passer; il y a un point où elles nous manquent tout à coup, le reste est pour d'autres Mondes, où quelque chose de ce que nous sçavons est inconnu. <RW>Cette Planete-cy</RW> joüit des douceurs de l'Amour, mais elle est toûjours desolée en plusieurs de ses parties par les fureurs de la Guerre. Dans une autre Planete on joüit d'une Paix éternelle, mais au milieu de cette Paix on ne connoist point l'Amour, & on s'ennuye. Enfin ce que la Nature pratique en petit entre les hommes pour la distribution du bonheur où des talens, elle l'aura sans doute pratiqué en grand entre les Mondes, & elle se sera bien souvenuë de mettre en usage ce secret merveilleux qu'elle a de diversifier toutes choses, & de les égaler en mesme temps que les compensations.</P052>
chunks.target_manual: <P040>Nay, to shew you that they can see <UP>as far into a Milstone as Descartes himself</UP>, they have discover'd that several, even of the most solid Bodies, are nothing but an immense swarm of imperceptible Animals: Do but consider this little Leaf; why it is a great World, of a vast extent, what Mountains, what Abysses are there in it? the Insects of one side, know no more of their fellow Creatures on t' other side, then you and I can tell what they are now doing at the Antipodes; is it not reason then that a great Planet should be inhabited? In the hardest Stones, for Example, in Marble, there are an infinity of Worms, which fill up the vacuums, and feed upon the substance of the Stone; fancy then millions of living Creatures to subsist; many years on a grain of Sand; so that were the Moon but one continued Rock, she should be gnaw'd by these invisible Mites, (as <UP>if she were a green Cheese) rather than not be inhabited: In short, every thing is animated, and the Stones upon Salisbury Plain are as much alive, as a Hive of Bees</UP>; imagine then those Animals which are yet undiscovered, and add them and those which are but lately discover'd, to those we have always seen, you will find the Earth swarms with Inhabitants. Why then should Nature, which is fruitful to an excess here, be so very barren in the rest of the Planets? I must own, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, you have convinc'd my Reason, but you have confounded my Fancy, with such variety, that I cannot imagine how Nature, which hates Repetitions, should produce so many different kinds. There is no need of Fancy, I reply'd, do but trust your Eyes, and you will easily perceive how Nature diversifies in these several Worlds.</P040> <P041>All humane Faces, in general, are of the same Model, and yet the Europeans and the Africans have two particular Moulds; nay, commonly every Family have a different Form; what secret then has Nature to shew so much variety in the single Face? Our World, in respect of the Universe, is but a little Family; all whose Faces have some resemblance; in another Place, there is another Family, whose Faces have a different Air and Fashion; <UP>the difference too increaseth with the distance, for whosoever should see an Inhabitant of the Moon, and an Inhabitant of the Earth, would soon perceive they were nearer Neighbours than one of the Earth, and one of Saturn; here, for Example, we have the use of Voice, in another World, they speak by Signs, and at a greater distance they do not speak at all; here our Reason is form'd by Experience, in the next World, Experience contributes little towards it; and in the next to that, old Men know no more than Children; here we are troubled more with what is to come, than with what is past; further off, they are not concern'd with either, which by the way, I think, is much the better: Here, 'tisthought we want a sixth Sense, which would teach us many things, of which we are now ignorant; this sixth Sense, is apparently in another World, where they want one of the five which we enjoy; nay, perhaps there is a much greater number of Senses, but in the Partition we have made of 'em with the Inhabitants of the other Planets, there are but five fall'n to our share, with which we are well contented, for want of being acquainted with the rest: Our Sciences have bounds, which the wit of Man could never pass; there is a point where they fail us on a sudden, the rest is reserv'd for other Worlds, where somewhat which we know, is unknown to them. This Planet enjoys the pleasures of Love, but lies desolate in several places by the fury of War; in another Planet, they enjoy a perpetual Peace, yet in the midst of that Peace, know nothing of Love, and time lies on their hands; in a word, that which Nature practises here in little, in distributing her Gifts among Mankind; she does at large in other Worlds, where she makes use of that admirable secret she hath to diversifie all things, and at the same time makes 'em equal, by compensating for the inequality; this I confess is on the Borders of Nonsense, but a Man is ne'er the less a Philosopher for being a little obscure, if not unintelligible.</UP></P041>

mais ceux de deux grandes Nations, comme des Européens, si vous voulez, & des Africains, paroissent estre faits sur deux modeles particuliers,
& il faudroit encore trouver le modele des visages de chaque Famille.
Apparemment les differences augmentent à mesure que l'on s'éloigne,
ailleurs l'experience y ajoûte fort peu de chose,
& ceux-là ne sont peut-estre pas les plus malheureux.
un sixiéme Sens naturel,
un grand nombre de Sens naturels;
Nos Sciences ont de certaines bornes
on s'ennuye.
elle l'aura sans doute pratiqué en grand entre les Mondes,
& elle se sera bien souvenuë de mettre en usage ce secret merveilleux
target_segments: several, even of the most solid Bodies, are nothing but an immense swarm of imperceptible Animals:

Do but consider this little Leaf; why it is a great World, of a vast extent, what Mountains, what Abysses are there in it? the Insects of one side, know no more of their fellow Creatures on t' other side, then you and I can tell what they are now doing at the Antipodes;
is it not reason then that a great Planet should be inhabited?
In the hardest Stones, for Example, in Marble, there are an infinity of Worms, which fill up the vacuums, and feed upon the substance of the Stone;
she should be gnaw'd by these invisible Mites, (as if she were a green Cheese) rather than not be inhabited:
In short, every thing is animated,
those Animals which are yet undiscovered,
you will find the Earth swarms with Inhabitants.
Why then should Nature, which is fruitful to an excess here, be so very barren in the rest of the Planets?
you have confounded my Fancy, with such variety,
that I cannot imagine how Nature, which hates Repetitions, should produce so many different kinds.
There is no need of Fancy, I reply'd, do but trust your Eyes,
and you will easily perceive how Nature diversifies in these several Worlds.
and yet the Europeans and the Africans have two particular Moulds;
nay, commonly every Family have a different Form;
the difference too increaseth with the distance,
in the next World, Experience contributes little towards it;
which by the way, I think, is much the better:
a sixth Sense,
a much greater number of Senses;
Our Sciences have bounds
and time lies on their hands;
she does at large in other Worlds,
where she makes use of that admirable secret
explanations: The translation simplifies the original sentence by omitting its final relative clause 'qui y trouvent pour leurs mouvemens autant de liberté qu'il leur en faut' (who find there for their movements as much freedom as they need). This reduces descriptive detail and overall sentence complexity.

The original long, descriptive declarative sentence with multiple relative clauses is restructured into a more direct imperative ('Do but consider') followed by rhetorical questions and shorter statements. This simplifies the sentence structure, making it more conversational. Additionally, 'Vermisseaux invisibles' (invisible little worms/grubs) is rendered as the more general term 'Insects'.

The formal and somewhat complex French introductory phrase 'A plus forte raison, ce me semble' (For a stronger reason, it seems to me) is simplified to the more direct and conversational English question 'is it not reason then'.

The translation simplifies by omitting or condensing descriptive details from the original: 'des especes de pierres tres-dures' (types of very hard stones) becomes 'the hardest Stones'; 'logez de toutes parts dans des vuides insensibles' (lodged on all sides in imperceptible voids) is reduced to 'which fill up the vacuums'; and the active description 'qu'ils rongeoient' (which they gnawed) is omitted. This reduces vividness and specific detail.

The original's general term 'par ses Habitans' (by its Inhabitants), key to Fontenelle's theme of extraterrestrial life, is translated as 'by these invisible Mites.' While 'Mites' is a common word, its use (linked to an added simile of green cheese) makes the potential inhabitants more specific and mundane (vermin-like) compared to the open-ended 'Habitans,' simplifying the philosophical scope of potential life forms.

The French uses a repetition 'tout est vivant, tout est animé' (everything is living, everything is animated) for emphasis. The translation simplifies this by using only 'every thing is animated,' reducing the rhetorical device and its emphatic effect.

The phrase 'que l'on conçoit aisément' (that one easily conceives/imagines), which modifies 'celles... qui sont encore à découvrir', is omitted in the translation. This simplification removes the nuance regarding the ease with which one can imagine such undiscovered species.

The translation simplifies the original sentence by omitting the second conjoined clause: '& que la Nature y a si liberalement répandu les Animaux, qu'elle ne s'est pas mise en peine que l'on en vist seulement la moitié' (and that Nature has so liberally spread Animals there, that she did not bother that one saw only half of them). This omission significantly reduces the density and the richness of Fontenelle's argument about Nature's profligacy.

The original French poses a more elaborate rhetorical question beginning 'Croirez-vous que...' (Will you believe that...). The English translation uses a more direct and structurally simpler question 'Why then should Nature...'. Additionally, the nominal phrase 'd'une sterilité à n'y rien produire de vivant' (of a sterility as to produce nothing living there) is rendered with the simpler adjectival phrase 'be so very barren'.

The source describes the imagination as 'accablée de la multitude infinie des Habitans...' and 'embarrassée de la diversité...'. This complex state is simplified in the target to the imagination being 'confounded with such variety'. The specific causes of being overwhelmed (multitude of inhabitants, diversity to be established) are reduced to the general term 'such variety', simplifying the expression and losing detail.

The original structure consists of a statement ('car je voy bien...') followed by a separate question ('mais comment se representer cela?'). The translation simplifies this by integrating these two parts into a single, more streamlined subordinate clause beginning with 'that I cannot imagine how...', making the sentence structure less segmented and more direct.

The abstract French phrase 'Ce n'est pas à l'imagination à prétendre le représenter' (It is not for the imagination to claim to represent it) is simplified to the more direct 'There is no need of Fancy.' Similarly, the negative and somewhat philosophical statement 'elle n'est pas propre à aller plus loin que les yeux' (it [imagination] is not fit/suited to go further than the eyes) is transformed into the simpler, positive injunction 'do but trust your Eyes.' These changes simplify complex phrasing and abstract concepts.

The nuanced phrase 'd'une certaine veuë universelle' (with a certain universal view/perspective), indicating a specific philosophical or epistemological standpoint for perception, is omitted. The translation 'you will easily perceive' is more general and direct, simplifying the original by losing this subtle qualification about the nature of perception.

The translation simplifies the French phrase by omitting the polite, conversational aside 'si vous voulez' (if you like). Additionally, the more tentative phrasing 'paroissent estre faits sur deux modeles particuliers' (seem to be made on two particular models) is rendered as the more assertive and direct 'have two particular Moulds,' reducing nuance.

The French 'il faudroit encore trouver' (one would still need to find / it would still be necessary to find) implies an ongoing or hypothetical task. The English 'commonly every Family have a different Form' simplifies this by presenting it as a direct, empirical-sounding statement of common observation, thus losing the speculative or process-oriented nuance.

The word 'Apparemment' (Apparently/Seemingly), which conveys a sense of inference, likelihood, or observation based on appearances, is translated as 'too.' This simplification alters the epistemic modality, making the statement a more straightforward continuation ('too' implying 'also' or 'furthermore') rather than a nuanced supposition.

The French idiomatic expression 'fort peu de chose' (a very little thing / a very small amount), which emphasizes the insignificance of experience's contribution, is simplified to 'little.' This reduction lessens the emphatic and slightly colloquial force of the original.

Fontenelle's speculative and understated comment 'ceux-là ne sont peut-estre pas les plus malheureux' (and those ones are perhaps not the most unhappy) is replaced by the translator's direct, colloquial, and strongly opinionated aside 'which by the way, I think, is much the better.' This simplifies the original by removing its philosophical speculation, understatement ('peut-estre pas les plus malheureux'), and nuanced observation on happiness, substituting it with a blunt and personal value judgment.
The qualifier 'naturel' (natural) modifying 'Sens' (Sense) is omitted. This simplification removes a specifying adjective, making the concept of this sense slightly less defined than in the original.

The qualifier 'naturels' (natural) modifying 'Sens' (Senses) is omitted. This simplification removes a specifying adjective, making the concept of these senses slightly less defined than in the original.

The word 'certaines' (certain) qualifying 'bornes' (limits/bounds) is omitted. This removes a nuance implying that these limits are specific or particular (even if not fully defined), simplifying the statement to a more general one about sciences merely having bounds.

The French 'on s'ennuye' (one becomes bored/experiences ennui) is translated with the English idiom 'time lies on their hands.' While effectively conveying boredom, this common idiom simplifies the potentially richer and more philosophical concept of 'ennui,' which can carry deeper existential weight, especially in French intellectual contexts.

The French future perfect 'elle l'aura sans doute pratiqué' (she will undoubtedly have practiced it), expresses a strong supposition or reasoned deduction about Nature's past actions having present relevance or forming a general truth. This is simplified to the present simple 'she does,' which reduces the speculative tone and the more complex temporal and modal framing of Nature's actions.

The French 'elle se sera bien souvenuë de mettre en usage' (she will have well remembered to put into use) strongly personifies Nature, attributing to it memory and deliberate intention. The translation 'she makes use of' is far more neutral and less anthropomorphic. This simplification reduces the original's figurative richness and its philosophical implication regarding Nature's conscious-like agency.

chunks.source_manual: <P053>Etes-vous contente, Madame, ajoûtay-je en quittant le ton serieux? Vous ay-je dubité assez de chimeres? Vrayment, répondit-elle, il me semble que j'ay presentement moins de peine à attraper les differences de tous ces Mondes. Mon imagination travaille sur le plan que vous m'avez donné. Je me represente comme je puis des Caracteres & des Coûtumes extraordinaire pour les Habitans des Planetes, & je leur compose mesme des figures tout-à-fait bizarres. Je ne vous les pourrois pas décrire, mais je voy pourtant quelque chose. Pour ces figures-là, repliquay-je, je vous conseille d'en laisser le soin aux Songes que vous aurez cette nuit. Nous verrons demain s'ils vous auront bien servie, & s'ils vous auront appris comment sont faits les Habitants de quelque Planete.</P053>
chunks.target_manual: <P042>But is it not time, Madam, to be serious, how will you dispose of all these Notions? Trouble not your self, says she, Fancy is a great Traveller; I already comprehend these several Worlds, and represent to my self their different Characters and Customs; some of 'em, I assure you, are very extraordinary; I see at this moment, a thousand different Figures, tho' I cannot well describe 'em. Oh leave 'em, I reply'd, to your Dreams, they will represent 'em very faithfully.</P042>

Vrayment, répondit-elle, il me semble que j'ay presentement moins de peine à attraper les differences de tous ces Mondes.
Je me represente comme je puis des Caracteres & des Coûtumes extraordinaire pour les Habitans des Planetes, & je leur compose mesme des figures tout-à-fait bizarres.
mais je voy pourtant quelque chose.
Pour ces figures-là, repliquay-je, je vous conseille d'en laisser le soin aux Songes que vous aurez cette nuit.
Nous verrons demain s'ils vous auront bien servie, & s'ils vous auront appris comment sont faits les Habitants de quelque Planete.

Trouble not your self, says she, Fancy is a great Traveller; I already comprehend these several Worlds,
and represent to my self their different Characters and Customs; some of 'em, I assure you, are very extraordinary; I see at this moment, a thousand different Figures,
Oh leave 'em, I reply'd, to your Dreams,
explanations: The original two-part question, with its playful inquiry about "chimeres" (fantasies/speculations) and a remark about the speaker adopting a less serious tone ("en quittant le ton serieux"), is significantly altered. The first question ("Etes-vous contente") is omitted. The second, somewhat ornate question "Vous ay-je dubité assez de chimeres?" (Have I spun you enough fantasies?) is replaced by the more direct, though semantically different, "how will you dispose of all these Notions?". The literary term "chimeres" is substituted with the more common "Notions." This overall change simplifies the interaction by reducing the number of questions and using more straightforward vocabulary, thereby lessening the original's stylistic complexity and figurative language.

The French phrase "il me semble que j'ay presentement moins de peine à attraper les differences" (it seems to me that I now have less difficulty in grasping/catching the differences) conveys a nuanced and gradual understanding. This is simplified to the more absolute and direct statement "I already comprehend". The descriptive nuance of process and reduced difficulty ("moins de peine à attraper") is replaced by a simpler verb ("comprehend"), removing some of the subtlety of the Marquise's evolving understanding.

The French text includes nuances simplified in the translation. Firstly, "Je me represente comme je puis" (I represent to myself as best I can/as I am able) is reduced to "represent to my self," omitting "comme je puis," which qualifies the Marquise's imaginative effort. Secondly, "je leur compose mesme des figures tout-à-fait bizarres" (I even compose/imagine for them completely bizarre figures) is changed to "I see at this moment, a thousand different Figures." The active verb "compose" (create) becomes the more passive "see." The vivid descriptor "tout-à-fait bizarres" (completely bizarre) is replaced by "a thousand different Figures," shifting focus from the strange nature of the figures to their quantity and variety. The emphatic "mesme" (even) is also lost, simplifying the description's intensity and specific detail.

The French clause "mais je voy pourtant quelque chose" (but I nonetheless/however see something) provides a contrast, indicating that despite her inability to fully describe her visions, the Marquise still perceives something. This clause is omitted in the English translation (the corresponding English sentence ends prior to conveying this idea). This omission simplifies the Marquise's expression by removing this assertion of partial perception and the contrast it introduces.

The more formal and structurally elaborate French sentence is simplified. The introductory phrase "Pour ces figures-là" (As for those figures) is rendered as the more colloquial and direct "Oh." The polite advisory phrase "je vous conseille d'en laisser le soin" (I advise you to leave the care/responsibility of them) is simplified to the direct imperative "leave 'em." Additionally, the clause "que vous aurez cette nuit" (that you will have tonight), modifying "Songes" (Dreams), is omitted. These changes result in a more concise, less formal, and structurally simpler utterance.

The entire French sentence, in which the philosopher suggests revisiting the topic the next day to see if the Marquise's dreams provided insights about planetary inhabitants, is omitted from the translation. This is a significant simplification by reduction, as it shortens the dialogue and removes a forward-looking narrative element, thereby reducing the text's density and conversational scope.

chunks.target_manual: <P044>The Fourth Evening.</P044>

chunks.source_manual: <P055><SC>Les songes ne furent point heureux: ils representerent toûjours quelque chose qui ressembloit à ce que l'on voit icy. J'eus lieu de reprocher à la <IIM>Marquise</IIM> ce que nous reprochent à la veüe de nos Tableaux, de certains Peuples qui ne font jamaïs que des peintures bizarres & grotesques. Bon, nous disent-ils, cela est tout fait comme des hommes, il n'y a pas là d'imagination. Il falut donc se resoudre à ignorer les figures des Habitans de toutes ces Planetes, & se contenter d'en deviner ce que nous pourrions, en continuant le Voyage des Mondes que nous avions commencé.</SC> Nous en estions à Venus. On est bien seur, dis-je à la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que Venus tourne sur elle-mesme, <SC>mais on ne sçait pas bien en quel temps</SC>, ny par consequent combien ses jours durent. Pour ses années, elles ne sont que de huit mois, puis qu'elle tourne en ce temps-là autour du Soleil. Come elle est quarante fois plus petite que la Terre, la Terre de dedans Venus paroist une Planete quarante fois plus grande, que Venus ne nous paroist d'icy; & comme la Lune est aussi quarante fois plus petite que la Terre, elle paroist dedans Venus à peu prés de la mesme grandeur dont Venus nous paroist d'icy.</P055>
chunks.target_manual: <P045><UP>I Have been told of a Physician that makes his Patients dream as he pleases, by prescribing such a Specifick for their Supper, as works those impressions he would have on the Fancy; of what use he may be to the modern Poets, I leave to the curious; and return to the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, who either did not dream at all, or nothing to the purpose</UP>; so that continuing our Voyage to the other Worlds, we could only guess at their Inhabitants. We were come to Venus, and I told her, that Venus certainly turn'd on it self, tho' no body could tell in what time, and consequently were ignorant how long her Day lasted; but her Year was compos'd of eight Months, because 'tis in that time she turns round the Sun: And seeing Venus is forty times less than the Earth, the Earth appears (to them in Venus) to be a Planet, forty times bigger than Venus appears to us on the Earth; and as the Moon is forty times lesser than the Earth, so she seems to be just of the same magnitude, to the Inhabitants of Venus, as here Venus seems to us.</P045>

target_segments: so that continuing our Voyage to the other Worlds, we could only guess at their Inhabitants.
the Earth appears (to them in Venus) to be a Planet, forty times bigger than Venus appears to us on the Earth;
so she seems to be just of the same magnitude, to the Inhabitants of Venus, as here Venus seems to us.
explanations: The original complex French sentence, detailing the necessity to resolve to ignore appearances ('les figures des Habitans') and content oneself with limited guessing ('ce que nous pourrions'), is significantly condensed. The translation simplifies this to the more direct statement 'we could only guess at their Inhabitants,' reducing structural complexity, overall length, and omitting several descriptive details from the original.

The translation simplifies by making perspectives clearer for easier comprehension and using more common vocabulary. The French 'de dedans Venus' (from within Venus) is explicated as '(to them in Venus)', and 'd'icy' (from here) is rendered more concretely as 'on the Earth', both aiding readability. Additionally, the somewhat more formal 'plus grande' (larger) is replaced by the more common 'bigger'.

Simplification occurs by clarifying perspective and using simpler vocabulary. The French 'dedans Venus' (within Venus) is explicated as 'to the Inhabitants of Venus', making the viewpoint explicit and easier for the reader to grasp. The phrase 'à peu prés' (approximately, nearly) is rendered as 'just', a shorter and more common English word, which simplifies the expression by making the statement more direct.

chunks.source_manual: <P056>Vous m'affligez, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Je voy bien que la Terre n'est pas pour Vénus l'Etoile du Berger, & la Mere des Amours, comme Vénus l'est pour la Terre; car la Terre de dedans Vénus paroist trop grande, mais la Lune qui y paroist de la mesme grandeur dont Vénus nous paroist d'icy, est justement taillée comme il faut pour y estre Mere des Amours, & Etoile du Berger <NCE></NCE>. Ces noms ne peuvent convenir qu'à une petite Planete qui soit jolie, claire, brillante, & qui ait un air galant. <UP></UP> C'est asseurément une destinée agréable pour nostre Lune que de presider aux Amours des Habitans de Venus; ces Gens là doivent bien entendre la galanterie. Oh! sans doute, répondis-je, le menu Peuple de Venus n'est composé que de Celadons & de Silvandres, & leurs Conversations le plus communes valent les plus belles de Clesie. <UP></UP> Le climat est tres-favorable aux Amours. Venus est plus proche que nous du Soleil, & elle en reçoit une lumiere plus vive & plus de chaleur.</P056>
chunks.target_manual: <P046>I see then, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, that the Earth is not to Venus, what Venus is to the Earth; I mean, that the Earth is too bigg to be the Mother of Love, or the Shepherd's Star to Venus; but the Moon, which appears to Venus, of the same bigness that Venus appears to us, is assign'd to be the Mother of Love, and <NCE>Shepherds Star to Venus</NCE>; for such names are only proper for a little brisk airy Planet, bright, and shining as the Goddess her self. Oh, blessed Moon, how happy art thou, to preside over the Amours of those gallant People, where all they say, is soft and moving, <UP>and perfectly refin'd from the dross of our Wits, who are fitter for a Bear-Garden than a Circle? How gross is their Courtship? how mean their Raillery? without any distinction of time, place, or person; they make Love, (as they call it) but one way, and the form is the same, at a Farce, or Funeral. Be not so very severe, I reply'd, if some of our Beaux speak plain English, some of your Belles, like 'em ne're the worse for't: The art of Love is as much improv'd as the art of War, the Generals of this Age take a Town in two days, which in the last, held out as many years; and the Roses, Lillies, Pearls, and Rubies, (a whining Lovers train of Artillery)</UP> are grown as useless as Bows and Arrows: tho' after all, I must own they have another Standard in the Planet Venus; there <UP>Clelia</UP> and Parthenissa, is below the language of Grooms and Chamber Maids; and every Porter and Car-Man a perfect Sir Courtly; but then consider the difference of Climats; Venus is much nearer than the Earth is to the Sun, from whence she receives a more vigorous and active influence.</P046>

explanations: The original French "Vous m'affligez" (You grieve me/distress me) expresses a direct, somewhat dramatic emotion. The English "I see then" replaces this with a cognitive realization, simplifying the emotional tone to a more neutral observation and making the character's reaction more about intellectual understanding than personal feeling.

The French "est justement taillée comme il faut" (is precisely cut/shaped as it should be) suggests a natural, inherent suitability and perfect design, using vivid imagery of being 'cut' or 'shaped'. The English "is assign'd to be" simplifies this by implying an attributed or designated role rather than an intrinsic, perfectly formed quality, losing some of the original's vividness and nuance.

The French describes the planet's qualities as "petite" (small/little), "jolie" (pretty), "claire" (clear/light), "brillante" (brilliant), and having "un air galant" (a gallant air). The English translation renders "petite" as "little." However, it simplifies the set of qualities "jolie, claire, brillante" to primarily "bright, and shining," losing the distinct nuance of "jolie" (pretty). Furthermore, the culturally rich and specific French concept "un air galant" (implying refined charm, amorous sophistication, and elegance) is replaced by the more general adjectival phrase "brisk airy" and an illustrative comparison "as the Goddess her self." This makes the overall description more accessible but reduces its original specificity, descriptive richness, and cultural nuance.

The original French is a declarative statement: "C'est asseurément une destinée agréable pour nostre Lune..." (It is certainly an agreeable destiny for our Moon...). The English translation transforms this into an exclamatory apostrophe: "Oh, blessed Moon, how happy art thou..." This shift simplifies the somewhat philosophical concept of "destinée agréable" (agreeable destiny) into a more direct and perhaps more readily accessible emotional expression of the Moon's presumed "happiness," and changes the sentence's mood to enhance engagement.

The French text uses specific, dense literary allusions ("Celadons & de Silvandres," "Clesie" – characters and works from popular contemporary French romances) to concisely characterize the refined nature of Venusian society, implying even commoners speak like romantic heroes. The English translation entirely omits these specific French allusions, which would be obscure to many English readers, and substitutes this with a re-imagined scenario of Venusian refinement using different cultural touchstones. This removal of Fontenelle's dense, culturally specific literary references simplifies the original text for an English audience by eliminating the need for specialized French literary knowledge.

The French "une lumiere plus vive & plus de chaleur" (a more vivid light and more heat) provides concrete, direct physical factors influencing Venus. The English "a more vigorous and active influence" generalizes these specific physical elements into a more abstract and conceptual term, "influence." This simplifies the directness of the physical description into a broader, less tangible concept, potentially to make the link to 'Amours' seem less crudely deterministic or more philosophically phrased.

chunks.source_manual: <P057>Je vois presentement, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, comment sont faits les Habitans de Venus. Ils ressemblent aux Mores Grenadins; un petit Peuple noir, brûlé du Soleil, plein d'esprit & de feu, toûjours amoureux, faisant des Vers, aimant la Musique, inventant tous les jours des Festes, des Danses, & des Tournois. Permettez-moy de vous dire, Madame, repliquay-je, que vous ne connoissez guere bien les Habitans de Venus. Nos Mores Grenadins n'auroient esté auprés d'eux que des Lappons & des Groënlandois pour la froideur & pour la stupidité.</P057>
chunks.target_manual: <P047>I find, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, it is easie enough to guess at the Inhabitants of Venus; they resemble what I have read of the Moors of Granada, who were a little black People, scorch'd with the Sun, witty, full of Fire, very Amorous, much inclin'd to Musick and Poetry, and ever inventing Masques and Turnaments in honour of their Mistresses. Pardon me, Madam, said I, you are little acquainted with the Planet; Granada in all its Glory, was a perfect Greenland to it; and your gallant Moors, in comparison with that People, were as stupid as so many Laplanders.</P047>

While "I find" can convey discovery, it's a slightly more general and common term, potentially reducing the immediacy or directness of "voir" (to see/perceive).

The direct French phrase "comment sont faits les Habitans de Venus." (literally "how the inhabitants of Venus are made," meaning "what they are like" or "what their nature is") is transformed into the English "it is easie enough to guess at the Inhabitants of Venus;". This simplifies the original by shifting from a statement about their actual nature to a comment on the ease of conjecture, using a more periphrastic and common idiomatic structure ("easie enough to guess at").

The original French specifies a high frequency with "tous les jours" (every day) and lists three types of events: "Festes, des Danses, & des Tournois." (Feasts/Festivals, Dances, and Tournaments). The translation simplifies this by: 1. Generalizing the temporal specificity of "tous les jours" to the less precise "ever inventing." 2. Reducing the enumeration of distinct activities from three to two ("Masques and Turnaments"), thereby decreasing the textual density and the variety presented in the original.

The formal and somewhat elaborate French phrase "Permettez-moy de vous dire" (Permit me to tell you / Allow me to say) is simplified to the more concise, common, and direct English interjection "Pardon me." This reduces both the formality and the length of the original expression.

The French "que vous ne connoissez guere bien les Habitans de Venus." (that you hardly know well / that you don't know [them] very well) uses a common French negative construction ("ne...guere"). This is simplified in English to the more idiomatic and arguably more common phrase "you are little acquainted with the Planet;". Additionally, the specific noun phrase "les Habitans de Venus" (the Inhabitants of Venus) is simplified to the shorter reference "the Planet," reducing lexical repetition and density by relying on the immediate context.

The original French uses a single, syntactically complex conditional past clause ("n'auroient esté... que..." - would have been nothing but/only...) to draw a multifaceted comparison. The English translation significantly simplifies this dense structure by: 1. Breaking the single complex comparison into two shorter, more straightforward, and independent declarative clauses ("Granada... was a perfect Greenland to it;" and "your gallant Moors... were as stupid as so many Laplanders."). 2. Replacing the nuanced conditional ("n'auroient esté que") with direct, simpler assertions of comparison ("was a perfect...", "were as stupid as..."). 3. Making the grounds for comparison more distinct by linking "Greenland" primarily to coldness (implied) and "Laplanders" explicitly to stupidity. This restructuring enhances readability by reducing syntactic complexity.

chunks.source_manual: <P058>Mais que sera-ce des Habitants de Mercure? Ils sont encore plus proches du Soleil; il faut qu'ils soient fous à force de vivacité. <UP></UP> Je croy qu'ils n'ont point de memoire, non plus que la plupart des Négres; qu'ils ne font jamais de reflexion sur rien, qu'ils n'agissent qu'à l'aventure, & par des mouvemens subits, & <IIM>qu'enfin c'est dans Mercure que sont les Petites Maisons de l'Univers.</IIM> <NCE></NCE> Ils voyent le Soleil beaucoup plus grand que nous ne le voyons, parce qu'ils en sont beaucoup plus proches. Il leur envoye une lumiere si forte, que s'ils estoient icy, ils ne prendroient nos plus beaux jours que pour de <IIM>tres-foibles</IIM> Crepuscules, & peut-estre n'y pourroient-ils pas distinguer les objets, & la chaleur à laquelle ils sont accoûtumez est si excessive, que celle qu'il fait icy au fond de l'Afrique, suffiroit pour les glacier. Leur année n'est que de trois mois. La durée de leur jour ne nous est point encore connuë, parce que Mercure est si petit & si proche du Soleil, dans les rayons duquel il est presque toûjours perdu, qu'il échappe à toute l'adresse des Astronomes, & qu'on n'a pû encore avoir assez de prise sur luy, pour observer le mouvement qu'il doit avoir sur son centre; mais sa petitesse fait croire qu'il acheve ce tour en peu de temps; que par consequent le jour de Mercure est fort court, & que les Habitans voyent le Soleil comme un <RW>grand poêle ardent</RW>, peu éloigné de leurs testes, & qui va d'une rapidité prodigieuse. Cela en est mieux pour eux, car apparemment ils soûpirent aprés la nuit. Ils sont éclairez pendant ce temps-là de Venus,& de la Terre, qui leur doivent paroistre assez grandes. Pour les autres Planetes, comme elles sont au-delà de la <IIM>Terre vers le Firmament</IIM>, ils les voyent plus petites que nous ne les voyons, & n'en reçoivent que bien peu de lumiere, peut-estre n'en reçoivent-ils point du tout. Les Etoles Fixes sont aussi plus petites pour eux, & même il doit y en avoir beaucoup qui disparoissent entierement; c'est, selon moy, une perte. Je suis bien fàché de voir cette <RW>grande voûte ornée de mois d'Etoiles, & de ne voir celles qui me resteroient</RW>, que plus petites, & d'une couleur plus effacée. <SC></SC>.</P058>
chunks.target_manual: <P048>But what do you think then of the Inhabitants of Mercury? They are yet nearer to the Sun, and are so full of Fire, <UP>that they are absolutely mad; I fancy, they have no memory at all, like most of the Negroes, that they make no reflections, and what they do is by sudden starts, and perfect hap-hazard; <NCE>in short, Mercury is the Bedlam of the Universe</NCE>; the Sun appears to them much greater than it does to us, because they are much nearer to it than we; it sends them so vast and strong a light, that the most glorious day here, would be no more with them than a declining Page 97 twilight: I know not if they can distinguish Objects, but the heat to which they are accustom'd, is so excessive, that they would be starved with cold in the Torrid Zone; their year is but three Months, but we know not the exact length of their Day, because Mercury is so little, and so near the Sun; it is, (as it were) lost in his Rays, and is very hardly discover'd by the Astronomers; so that they cannot observe how it moves on its Centre, but because it is so little, fancy it compleats its motion in a little time; so that by consequence, the day there is very short, and the Sun appears to them like <RW>a vast fiery Furnace at a little distance</RW>, whose motion is prodigiously swift and rapid; and during their Night, Venus and the Earth (which must appear considerably big) give light to them; as for the other Planets which are beyond the Earth, <RW>towards the Firmament</RW>, they appear less to them in Mercury, than they do to us here, and they receive but little light from them, perhaps none at all; the fix'd Stars likewise seem less to them, and some of 'em totally disappear, which were I there, I should esteem a very great</UP> loss. <SC></SC></P048>
source_segments: il faut qu'ils soient fous à force de vivacité.
qu'enfin c'est dans Mercure que sont les Petites Maisons de l'Univers.
parce que Mercure est si petit & si proche du Soleil, dans les rayons duquel il est presque toûjours perdu,
& qu'on n'a pû encore avoir assez de prise sur luy, pour observer le mouvement qu'il doit avoir sur son centre;
& peut-estre n'y pourroient-ils pas distinguer les objets,
target_segments: they are so full of Fire, that they are absolutely mad;
in short, Mercury is the Bedlam of the Universe;
because Mercury is so little, and so near the Sun; it is, (as it were) lost in his Rays,
so that they cannot observe how it moves on its Centre,
I know not if they can distinguish Objects,
explanations: The translator simplifies the French "à force de vivacité" (by dint of liveliness/vivacity) to the more concrete and common English phrase "so full of Fire." Additionally, the French modal construction "il faut qu'ils soient fous" (it is necessary that they are mad / they must be mad) is rendered as a more direct assertion "they are absolutely mad," simplifying the original's more philosophical implication of necessity.

The French text uses a cleft sentence structure "c'est dans Mercure que sont..." (it is in Mercury that are...), which emphasizes "dans Mercure" but is grammatically more complex. The translation simplifies this to a more direct, common English declarative sentence structure "Mercury is...", enhancing readability.

The original French uses a single complex sentence structure featuring a relative clause introduced by "duquel" ("dans les rayons duquel il est presque toûjours perdu" - in whose rays it is almost always lost). The translation simplifies this by breaking the idea into two shorter, coordinated clauses: "because Mercury is so little, and so near the Sun; it is, (as it were) lost in his Rays." This reduces syntactic complexity and makes the sentence easier to follow.

The French phrase "qu'on n'a pû encore avoir assez de prise sur luy" (that one has not yet been able to get enough of a hold on it/grasp of it) conveys the difficulty of observation in a somewhat figurative and detailed manner. The translation simplifies this by stating the direct consequence – "so that they cannot observe..." – thereby omitting the specific nuance of 'not getting a hold' and reducing the density and idiomatic complexity of the original phrasing.

The French "peut-estre n'y pourroient-ils pas distinguer les objets" (perhaps they could not distinguish objects there) uses a complex negative modal construction to express a supposition. The translation simplifies this grammatically and conceptually by shifting to the speaker's perspective of uncertainty with "I know not if they can distinguish Objects," which employs a more straightforward clause ("if they can distinguish").

chunks.source_manual: <P059>Je ne suis pas si touchée, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, de cette perte-là que sont les <IIM>Habitans de Mercure</IIM>, que de l'incommodité qu'ils reçoivent de l'excés de la chaleur. Je voudrois bien que nous les soulageassions un peu. Donnons à Mercure de longues & d'abondantes pluyes qui le rafraischissent, comme on dit qu'il en tombe icy dans les Pays chauds pendant des quatre mois entiers, justement dans les saisons les plus chaudes.</P059> <P060>Cela se peut, repris-je, & mesme nous pouvons rafraîchir encore Mercure d'une autre façon. Il y a des Pays dans la Chine qui doivent estre tres-chauds par leur situation, & où il fait pourtant de grands froids pendant les mois de Juillet & d'Aoust, jusque-là que les Rivieres se gelent. C'est que ces contrées là ont beaucoup de Salpêtre; les exhalaisons en sont fort froides, & la force de la chaleur les fait sortir de la Terre en grande abondance. Mercure sera, si vous voulez, une petite Planete toute de <IIM>Salpêtre</IIM>, & le Soleil tirera d'elle-mesme le remede au mal qu'il luy pourroit faire. Ce qu'il y a de seur, c'est que la Nature ne sçauroit faire vivre les Gens qu'où ils peuvent vivre, & que l'habitude jointe à l'ignorance de quelque chose de meilleur, survient, & les y fait vivre agréablement. Ainsi on pourroit même se passer dans Mercure du <IIM>Salpêtre</IIM> & des pluyes.</P060>
chunks.target_manual: <P049>What signifies the loss of a few fix'd Stars, says the <IIM>Countess?</IIM> I pity 'em for the excessive heat <SC>they </SC> endure; let us give 'em some relief, and send Mercury a few of the refreshing Showers they have sometimes four Months together in the hottest Countries during their greatest extremity. Your Fancy is good, Madam, I reply'd, but we will relieve 'em another way; In China there are Countries which are extreamly hot by their Situation: yet in July and August are so cold, that the Rivers are Frozen; the reason is, they are full of Salt-Petre, which being exhal'd in great abundance by the excessive heat of the Sun, makes a perfect Winter at Midsummer. We will fill the little Planet with Salt-petre, and let the Sun shine as hot as he pleases. And yet after all, who knows but the Inhabitants of Mercury may have no occasion either for Rain, or Salt- Petre. If it is a certain truth, that Nature never gives life to any Creature, but where that Creature may live; then thro' Custom, and ignorance of a better Life, those People may live happily.</P049>

explanations: The original complex French sentence, 'Je ne suis pas si touchée... de cette perte-là... que de l'incommodité...', compares the degree to which the Marquise is affected by two issues. The translation simplifies this by breaking the single complex comparison into two simpler, distinct clauses: a rhetorical question ('What signifies the loss...?') addressing the first issue, and a direct statement ('I pity 'em for the excessive heat they endure;') for the second. This restructuring simplifies the sentence. Furthermore, the concept of being 'touchée de l'incommodité' (affected by the discomfort) is simplified to 'pity 'em for the excessive heat', using a more common emotional term.

The polite and slightly formal French subjunctive 'Je voudrois bien que nous les soulageassions un peu' (I would very much like that we relieve them a little) is simplified to a direct imperative suggestion 'let us give 'em some relief,' making the tone more colloquial and the sentence structure more straightforward.

The phrase 'comme on dit' (as they say / as it is said), which indicates reported information or common knowledge, is omitted in the translation. This removal of the qualifying clause simplifies the sentence by presenting the information more directly and with less nuance about its evidentiary basis.

The French 'nous pouvons rafraîchir encore Mercure' (we can even cool Mercury further) uses the specific verb 'rafraîchir' (to cool). The English 'we will relieve 'em' simplifies this by using the more general verb 'relieve' and the common colloquial pronoun ''em.' The nuance of 'mesme ... encore' (even ... further/again) is also condensed.

The French 'doivent estre tres-chauds' (must be / ought to be very hot), indicating inference, is simplified to 'are extreamly hot,' a direct statement of fact. The idiomatic 'il fait ... de grands froids' (lit. it makes great colds, meaning it is very cold) is simplified to the standard English structure 'are so cold.' The conjunction 'jusque-là que' (to the point that) is simplified to 'that.' These changes make the sentence structure more direct and employ more standard phrasing.

The French phrase 'la force de la chaleur' (the force of the heat), which is somewhat abstract, is translated to 'the excessive heat of the Sun,' a more concrete and vivid expression. This simplifies the concept by making the agent of heat more specific and imaginable.

The polite, conditional framing 'Mercure sera, si vous voulez...' (Mercury will be, if you like...) is simplified to the more assertive 'We will fill...'. More significantly, the complex and philosophical idea 'le Soleil tirera d'elle-mesme le remede au mal qu'il luy pourroit faire' (the Sun will draw from the planet itself the remedy to the harm it could do to it) is entirely replaced by the much simpler, colloquial phrase 'and let the Sun shine as hot as he pleases.' This substitution simplifies the original's sophisticated concept of a natural counterbalance.

The French declarative structure 'Ce qu'il y a de seur, c'est que X & que Y' (What is certain is that X and that Y) is simplified into a conditional 'If X, then Y,' changing the logical relationship from two asserted truths to a hypothesis and consequence. The verb 'survient' (supervenes, arises), which indicates an active intervening process for habit and ignorance, is omitted, simplifying the causal description. Furthermore, the causative 'les y fait vivre agréablement' (makes them live there agreeably) is softened to the potential 'those People may live happily,' reducing the original's definitiveness.

The French 'Ainsi on pourroit même se passer...' (Thus one could even do without...) functions as a logical conclusion. The translator has rephrased this idea as a speculative rhetorical question, 'who knows but [they] may have no occasion...', and moved it to an earlier position in the text relative to its preceding philosophical justification. This simplifies the original's formal conclusiveness ('Ainsi...') into a more conversational and less assertive framing.

chunks.source_manual: <P061>Aprés Mercure vous sçavez qu'on trouve le Soleil. Il n'y a pas moyen d'y mettre d'Habitans. Le Pourquoy non nous manque-là. Nous jugeons par la Terre qui est habitée, que les autres Corps de la mesme espece qu'elle, doivent l'estre aussi; mais le Soleil n'est point un Corps de la mesme espece que la Terre, ny que les autres Planetes. Il est la source de toute cette lumiere que les Planetes ne font que se renvoyer les unes aux autres, aprés l'avoir reçeüe de luy. Elles ne peuvent faire, pour ainsi dire, des échanges entre elles, mais elles ne la peuvent produire. Luy seul tire de soy-mesme cette pretieuse substance; il la pousse avec force de tous costez; de là elle revient à la rencontre de tout ce qui est solide, & d'une Planete à l'autre il s'épand de longues & vastes traisnées de lumieres qui se croisent & se traversent, & s'entrelassent en mille façons diferentes, & forment d'admirables tissus de la plus riche matiere qui soit au monde. Aussi le Soleil est-il placé dans le centre, qui est le lieu le plus commode d'où il la puisse distribuer également, & animer tout par sa chaleur <NCP></NCP>. Le Soleil est donc un Corps <UP>particulier</UP>, mais quelle sorte de Corps? On est bien embarrassé à le dire. On avoit toûjours crû que c'estoit un feu tres-pur, mais on s'en desabusa au commencement de ce <IIM>Siecle</IIM>, qu'on apperceut des taches sur sa surface. Comme on avoit découvert peu de temps auparavant de nouvelles Planetes dont je vous parleray; que tout le <IIM>Monde Philosophe</IIM> n'avoit l'esprit remply d'autre chose, & qu'enfin les nouvelles Planetes s'estoient mises à la mode, on jugea aussi-tost que ces taches en estoient; <UP>qu'elles avoyent un mouvement autour du Soleil</UP>, & qu'elles nous en cachoient necessairement quelque partie, en tournant leur moitié obscure vers nous. Déja les Sçavans faisoient leur Cour de ces pretendües Planetes à tous les Princes de l'Europe. Les uns leur donnoient le nom d'un Prince, les autres d'un autre, & peut-estre il y auroit eu querelle entre-eux à qui seroit demeuré le maistre des taches pour les nommer comme il eust voulu...</P061>
chunks.target_manual: <P050>After Mercury comes the Sun, but there is no possibility of peopling it, nor no room left for a wherefore. By the Earth which is inhabited, we judge that other Bodies of the same Nature may be likewise inhabited; but the Sun is a Body not like the Earth or any of the Planets, the Sun is the source or Fountain of Light, which tho' it is sent from one Planet to another, and receives several alterations by the way, yet all originally proceeds from the Sun, he draws from himself that precious substance which he emits from all sides, and which reflects when it meets with a solid Body, and spreads from one Planet to another those long and vast trains of Light which cross, strike thro', and intermingle in a thousand different fashions, and make <NCP>(if I may so say,)</NCP> the Richest Tissu's in the World. The Sun likewise is placed in the Centre, from whence with most convenience, he may equally distribute and animate by his heat; it is then a particular Body, <UP>but what sort of Body has often puzled better heads than mine</UP>. It was thought formerly a Body of pure Fire, and that Opinion passed currant till the beginning of this Age; when they perceived several spots on its surface. A little after they had discover'd new Planets, (of which, hereafter) which some said were those Spots; for those Planets moving round the Sun, when they turned their dark half to us, must necessarily hide part of it; and had not the Learned with these pretended Planets made their Court before to most of the Princes in Europe, giving the name of this Prince to one, and of that Prince to another Planet; I believe they would have quarrel'd who should be Master of these spots, that they might have nam'd them as they pleas'd.</P050>
source_segments: Le Pourquoy non nous manque-là.
Elles ne peuvent faire, pour ainsi dire, des échanges entre elles
de là elle revient à la rencontre de tout ce qui est solide
mais on s'en desabusa au commencement de ce Siecle, qu'on apperceut des taches sur sa surface.

Comme on avoit découvert peu de temps auparavant de nouvelles Planetes dont je vous parleray; que tout le Monde Philosophe n'avoit l'esprit remply d'autre chose, & qu'enfin les nouvelles Planetes s'estoient mises à la mode, on jugea aussi-tost que ces taches en estoient; qu'elles avoyent un mouvement autour du Soleil, & qu'elles nous en cachoient necessairement quelque partie, en tournant leur moitié obscure vers nous.
target_segments: nor no room left for a wherefore.
which tho' it is sent from one Planet to another
and which reflects when it meets with a solid Body
and that Opinion passed currant till the beginning of this Age; when they perceived several spots on its surface.

A little after they had discover'd new Planets, (of which, hereafter) which some said were those Spots; for those Planets moving round the Sun, when they turned their dark half to us, must necessarily hide part of it;
explanations: The original French is a concise, abstract, and slightly philosophical statement ("The 'why not' is lacking for us there / we lack it there"). The English translation "nor no room left for a wherefore" rephrases this using a more conventional idiomatic structure ("room left for"), simplifying the original's abstractness and unique phrasing, even while retaining an archaic tone with "wherefore".

The French phrase "Elles ne peuvent faire, pour ainsi dire, des échanges entre elles" (They cannot, so to speak, make exchanges among themselves) highlights the planets' limited agency regarding light, with the important qualifier "pour ainsi dire" signalling a metaphorical use of "exchanges." The English "which tho' it is sent from one Planet to another" simplifies this by focusing on the passive transmission of light, omitting the explicit idea of planets' inability to "make exchanges" and, crucially, dropping the "pour ainsi dire." This removal of the authorial qualifier and the nuanced concept reduces stylistic complexity and precision.

The French "de là elle revient à la rencontre de tout ce qui est solide" uses narrative language to describe the light's journey ("from there it returns to meet anything solid"). The English "and which reflects when it meets with a solid Body" simplifies this by directly stating the physical phenomenon (reflection) and its condition. This shifts from a more descriptive, imagistic phrasing of a process to a more concise, factual statement of an event, reducing the original's descriptive richness.

The French "on s'en desabusa" (one was disabused of it) uses a reflexive verb to actively describe a collective cognitive shift or the correction of a misconception. The English translation "that Opinion passed currant till..." simplifies this by shifting focus to the opinion's lifespan and eventual obsolescence, rather than the dynamic process of people realizing their error. This makes the description of the change in understanding more passive and less direct.

The original French sentence presents a complex sentence structure outlining three distinct contextual reasons (recent discovery of planets, the philosophical world's preoccupation, and their fashionability) for the swift, possibly premature, judgment that sunspots were new planets. The English translation significantly simplifies this by omitting two of these culturally rich explanatory clauses: "que tout le Monde Philosophe n'avoit l'esprit remply d'autre chose" and "qu'enfin les nouvelles Planetes s'estoient mises à la mode." This omission reduces the text's density, simplifies the complex sentence structure, and lessens the cultural and intellectual context provided by Fontenelle for the hasty conclusion.

chunks.source_manual: <P062>Je ne trouve point cela bon, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Vous me disiez l'autre jour qu'on avoit donné aux differentes parties de la Lune des noms de Sçavans & d'Astronomes, & j'en estois fort contente. Puis que les Princes prennent pour eux la Terre, il est juste que les Sçavans se reservent le Ciel, & y dominent, mais ils n'en devroient point permettre l'entrée à d'autres. Souffrez, répondis-je, <UP></UP> qu'ils puissent, du moins en cas de besoin, engager aux Princes quelque Astre, ou quelque partie de la Lune. Quant aux taches du Soleil, ils n'en purent faire aucun usage. Il se trouva que ce n'estoient point des Planetes, mais des nuages, des fumées, des écumes, qui s'élèvent sur le Soleil. Elles sont tantost en grande quantité, tantost en petit nombre; tantost elles disparoissent toutes, quelquefois elles se mettent plusieurs ensemble, quelquefois elles se separent, quelquefois elles sont plus claires, quelquefois plus noires. Il y a des temps où l'on en voit beaucoup, il y en a d'autres, & mesme assez longs, où il n'en paroist aucune. Il semble que le Soleil soit une matiere liquide, quelques-uns disent de l'Or fondu, qui boüillonne incessamment <NCP></NCP>, & produit des impuretez, qui par la force de son mouvement sont rejettées sur sa surface. Elles s'y consument, & puis il s'en produit d'autres. Imaginez-vous quels Corps étrangers ce sont là. Il y en a tel qui est peut-estre aussi grand que la Terre. Jugez par là quelle est la quantité de cet Or fondu, ou l'étenduë de cette grande Mer de lumiere & de feu qu'on appelle le Soleil. D'autres disent que le Soleil paroît avec des Lunettes tout plein de Montagnes qui vomissent des flâmes, & que c'est comme un million de Monts Etna mis ensemble, mais on dit aussi que ces Montagnes sont une pure vision, causée par quelque chose qui arrive dans les Lunettes. Aquoy se fiera-t-on, s'il faut se défier des Lunettes mesme, ausquelles nous devons la connoissance de tant de nouveaux objects. Enfin, quoy que ce puisse estre que le Soleil, il ne paroist nullement propre à estre habité. C'est pourtant dommage, l'habitation seroit belle. On seroit au centre de tout, on verroit toutes les Planetes tourner regulierement autour de soy, au lieu que nous voyons dans leur cours une infinité de bizareries, qui n'y paroissent que parce que nous ne sommes pas en le lieu propre pour en bien juger, c'est à dire, au centre de leur mouvement. Cela n'est-il pas pitoyable? Il n'y a qu'un lieu dans le Monde, d'où l'étude des Astres puisse estre extremément facile, & justement dans ce lieu-là, il n'y a personne. Vous n'y songez pas, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Qui seroit dans le Soleil, verroit rien, ny Planetes, ny Etoiles Fixes. Le Soleil n'efface-t-il pas tout? Ce seroient ses Habitans qui seroient bien fondez à se croire seuls dans toute la Nature.</P062>
chunks.target_manual: <P051>'Twas but t'other day, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, you were describing the Moon, and call'd several places by the names of the most famous Astronomers. I was pleased with the fancy; for since the Princes have seiz'd on the Earth; 'tis fit the Philosophers should reserve the Heavens for themselves without any Competitors. Oh! trouble not your self, said I, <UP>the Philosophers make the best advantage of their Territories; and if they part with the least Star, 'tis on very good terms; let me tell you, an Acre of Land in England, is worth ten thousand in the Moon, but the spots on the Sun are fallen to nothing; the actions of Pensilvania are not half so low</UP>, 'tis now discover'd that they are not Planets, but Clouds, Steams, or Dross, which rise upon the Sun, sometimes in great quantity, sometimes in less; sometimes they are dark, sometimes clear, sometimes they continue a great while, and sometimes they disappear as long. It seems the Sun is a Liquid Matter, some think of melted Gold, which boils over <NCP>(as it were)</NCP> continually, and by the force of its motion casts the Scum or dross on its surface, where it is consumed, and others arise. Imagine then what strange Bodies these are, when some of 'em are as big as the Earth; What a vast quantity must there be of this melted Gold, and what must be the extent of this great Sea of Light and Fire which they call the Sun? Others say, the Sun appears through their Tellescopes, full of Mountains which vomit Fire continually, and are joyn'd together like millions of Etna's. Yet there are those who say these burning Mountains are pure Vision, caus'd by a fault in the Spectacles; but what shall we trust, if we must distrust our Tellescopes to which we owe the knowledge of so many new Objects? But let the Sun be what it will, it cannot be at all proper for habitation; and what pity 'tis not, for how pleasant would it be? You might then be at the Centre of the Universe, where you would see all the Planets turn regularly about you; but now we know nothing but extravagant Page 103 fancies, because we do not stand in the proper place; there is but one place in the World where the study or knowledge of the Stars is easily obtain'd, and what pity 'tis there is no body there. You forget your self sure, says she, were you in the Sun you would see nothing, neither Planets nor fix'd Stars, doth not the Sun efface all? so that could there be any Inhabitants there, they might justly think themselves the only people in Nature.</P051>
source_segments: Je ne trouve point cela bon, interrompit la Marquise. Vous me disiez l'autre jour qu'on avoit donné aux differentes parties de la Lune des noms de Sçavans & d'Astronomes, & j'en estois fort contente.
Puis que les Princes prennent pour eux la Terre, il est juste que les Sçavans se reservent le Ciel, & y dominent, mais ils n'en devroient point permettre l'entrée à d'autres.
Souffrez, répondis-je, qu'ils puissent, du moins en cas de besoin, engager aux Princes quelque Astre, ou quelque partie de la Lune.
Quant aux taches du Soleil, ils n'en purent faire aucun usage.

Elles sont tantost en grande quantité, tantost en petit nombre; tantost elles disparoissent toutes, quelquefois elles se mettent plusieurs ensemble, quelquefois elles se separent, quelquefois elles sont plus claires, quelquefois plus noires.

Jugez par là quelle est la quantité de cet Or fondu, ou l'étenduë de cette grande Mer de lumiere & de feu qu'on appelle le Soleil.

Aquoy se fiera-t-on, s'il faut se défier des Lunettes mesme, ausquelles nous devons la connoissance de tant de nouveaux objects.

au lieu que nous voyons dans leur cours une infinité de bizareries, qui n'y paroissent que parce que nous ne sommes pas en le lieu propre pour en bien juger, c'est à dire, au centre de leur mouvement.
Il n'y a qu'un lieu dans le Monde, d'où l'étude des Astres puisse estre extremément facile, & justement dans ce lieu-là, il n'y a personne.
Vous n'y songez pas, dit la Marquise.
