explanations: The initial critical remark "Je ne trouve point cela bon," is omitted in the target, which begins the Marquise's speech directly with her recollection. This simplifies the character's opening statement and streamlines the dialogue flow.

The source's "& y dominent, mais ils n'en devroient point permettre l'entrée à d'autres" (and dominate there, but they should not allow entry to others) is condensed to "without any Competitors," simplifying by merging two distinct ideas into a single, less forceful phrase.

The formal French "Souffrez... qu'ils puissent... engager" (Allow... that they might... pledge) is simplified to the more colloquial "if they part with... 'tis on very good terms," replacing a nuanced request with a general statement using more common phrasing.
The literal "ils n'en purent faire aucun usage" (they couldn't make any use of them) is simplified to the more concise and idiomatic English phrase "are fallen to nothing."

The detailed French list of sunspot behaviors is simplified by omitting the specific actions "quelquefois elles se mettent plusieurs ensemble, quelquefois elles se separent" (sometimes several gather together, sometimes they separate), reducing the description's density.
The French passive construction "sont rejettées" (are thrown/rejected) is simplified to the active voice "casts," a common simplification of sentence structure.
The formal French construction "Il y en a tel qui" (There is such a one which) is simplified to the more colloquial and direct "some of 'em."

The French imperative "Jugez par là" (Judge by that) followed by an indirect question is simplified by rephrasing into more direct exclamatory questions in English, making the expression more immediate.

The vague French phrase "quelque chose qui arrive dans les Lunettes" (something that happens in the lenses) is simplified to the more specific and direct "a fault in the Spectacles," enhancing clarity.
The impersonal French construction "Aquoy se fiera-t-on" (In what can one trust) is simplified to the personal and direct "what shall we trust," reducing formal distance.

The phrase "il ne paroist nullement propre à estre habité" (it appears in no way suitable) is simplified to "it cannot be at all proper for habitation," removing epistemic modality ("appears") for a more direct assertion.

The explanatory clause "c'est à dire, au centre de leur mouvement" (that is to say, at the center of their movement) is omitted from the target, simplifying the sentence by reducing explanatory detail and overall length.

The French "extrêmement facile" (extremely easy) is softened to "easily obtain'd," and the emphatic adverb "justement" (precisely) is omitted. The original's two distinct clauses are also merged with an expression of pity, simplifying the structure and nuance.

The somewhat formal French expression "Vous n'y songez pas" (You are not thinking about that/You haven't considered that) is simplified to the more idiomatic and colloquial English phrase "You forget your self sure."

The French emphatic sentence structure "Ce seroient ses Habitans qui..." (It would be its inhabitants who...) is simplified into a standard English conditional clause, making the syntax more straightforward.

chunks.source_manual: <P063>J'avoüe que je m'estois trompé, répondis-je, je ne songeois qu'à la situation où est le Soleil,& non à l'effet de sa lumiere; mais vous qui me redressez si à propos, vous voulez bien que je vous dise que vous vous estes trompée aussi; les Habitans du Soleil ne le verroient seulement pas. Ou ils ne pourroient soûtenir la force de sa lumiere, ou ils ne la pourroient recevoir, faute d'en estre à quelque distance, & tout bien considéré, le Soleil ne seroit qu'un séjour d'Aveugles; encore un coup, il n'est pas fait pour estre habité; mais voulez-vous que nous poursuivions nostre Voyage des Mondes? Nous sommes arrivéz au centre qui est toûjours le lieu le plus bas dans tout ce qui est rond, il faudroit presentement retourner sur nos pas, & remonter. Nous retrouverons Mercure, Venus, la Terre, la Lune, toutes Planetes que nous avons visitées. Ensuite c'est Mars qui se presente. Mars n'a rien de curieux que je sçache, ses jours ne sont pas d'une heure entiere plus longs que les nostres; ses années valent deux de nos années. Il est plus petit que la Terre, il voit le Soleil un peu moins grand & moins vif que nous ne le voyons; enfin Mars ne vaut pas trop la peine qu'on s'y arreste. Mais la jolie chose que Jupiter avec ses quatre Lunes ou <RW>Satellites</RW>! Ce sont quatre petites Planetes qui tournent autour de luy, comme nostre Lune tourne autour de nous. Mais, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, pourquoy y a-t-il des Planetes qui tournent autour d'autres Planetes qui ne valent pas mieux qu'elles? Serieusement il me paroîtroit plus regulier & plus uniforme que toutes les Planetes, grandes & petites, n'eussent que le mesme mouvement autour du Soleil!</P063>
chunks.target_manual: <P052>I own said I, my mistake; I was thinking of the Situation of the Sun, and not of the effect of its Light: I thank you for your correction, but must take the boldness to tell you, that you are in an errour, as well as my self; for were there Inhabitants in the Sun, they would not see at all, either they could not bear the strength of its light, or for want of a due distance, they could not receive it; so that things well consider'd, all the People there must be stark blind, which is another reason why the Sun cannot be inhabited; but let us pursue our Voyage. We are now arriv'd at the Centre, which is always the bottom, or lowest place of what is round; if we go on, we must ascend; we shall find Mercury, Venus, the Earth, the Moon, all the Planets we have already visited; the next is Mars: Mars hath nothing curious that I know of, his Day is not quite an hour longer than ours, but his Year is twice as much as our Year; he is a little less than the Earth; and the Sun seems not altogether so large and so bright to him, as it appears to us? but let us leave Mars, he is not worth our stay: But what a pretty thing is Jupiter, with his four Moons, <UP>or Yeomen of the Guard</UP>; they are four little Planets that turn round him, as our Moon turns round us. But why, says she, interrupting me, must there be Planets to turn round other Planets, that are no better than themselves? I should think it would be more regular and uniform, that all the Planets, little and great, without any distinction, should have one and the same motion round the Sun.</P052>

explanations: The French descriptive clause "vous qui me redressez si à propos" (you who correct me so aptly/timely) is simplified to the more direct and common phrase "I thank you for your correction." This reduces the formality and descriptive richness of the original but enhances directness.

The French "le Soleil ne seroit qu'un séjour d'Aveugles" (the Sun would only be an abode of blind people), which is somewhat metaphorical, is translated into the more direct and less figurative "all the People there must be stark blind." This simplification makes the meaning more concrete and less abstract.

The French phrase "encore un coup" (literally "another blow/hit", idiomatically "once again" or "another point is") followed by a statement is rephrased into a clause "which is another reason why...". This simplifies by making the logical connection to the preceding argument more explicit and the transition smoother.

The original French is a polite question inviting agreement ("Do you want us to pursue..."). The translation simplifies this to a direct hortative statement "let us pursue our Voyage." This changes the sentence mode from interrogative to a more direct suggestion, streamlining the conversational flow.

The French "il faudroit presentement retourner sur nos pas, & remonter" (it would be necessary now to retrace our steps, and go back up) details two actions. The translation simplifies this by omitting the specific action "retourner sur nos pas" (retrace our steps) and condensing the meaning to "we must ascend," reducing the density of information.

The French "Ensuite c'est Mars qui se presente" (Next it is Mars which presents itself) uses a cleft sentence structure and a slightly active verb "se presente". This is simplified to the more concise and common declarative phrasing "the next is Mars:", removing the slight personification and structural emphasis.

The impersonal French construction "enfin Mars ne vaut pas trop la peine qu'on s'y arreste" (finally Mars is not really worth the trouble that one stops there) is simplified. The translation uses a direct call to action, "let us leave Mars," and a more common English idiom, "he is not worth our stay," making the tone more decisive and the phrasing more familiar.

The scientific term "Satellites" (used by Fontenelle in "Lunes ou Satellites") is rendered as "Yeomen of the Guard" in the phrase "Moons, or Yeomen of the Guard". This simplifies the terminology by replacing a more technical astronomical term with a culturally specific and familiar analogy, enhancing accessibility.

The English translation adds the phrase "without any distinction" to the Marquise's statement. The French original implies this lack of distinction. The addition simplifies the text by making this implication explicit, reducing the inferential load on the reader and enhancing clarity.

chunks.source_manual: <P064>Ah! Madame, répliquay-je! Si vous sçaviez ce que c'est que les <RW><NCP>Tourbillons</NCP></RW> de Descartes, ces Tourbillons dont le nom est si terrible, & l'idée si agreable, vous ne parleriez pas comme vous faites. La teste me dust-elle tourner, dit-elle en riant, il est beau de sçavoir ce que c'est que les Tourbillons. Achevez de me rendre folle, je ne me ménage plus, je ne connois plus de retenuë sur la Philosophie; laissons parler le monde, & donnons-nous aux Tourbillons. Je ne vous connoissois pas de pareils emportemens, répris-je; c'est dommage qu'ils n'ayent que les Tourbillons pour objet. Ce qu'on appelle un Tourbillon, c'est un amas de matiere dont les parties sont détachées les unes des autres, & se meuvent toutes en un mesme sens; permis à elles d'avoir pendant ce temps-là quelques petites mouvemens particuliers, pourveu qu'elles suivent toûjours le mouvement general. Ainsi un Tourbillon de vent <UP></UP>, c'est une infinité de petites parties d'air, qui tournent en rond toutes ensemble, & enveloppent ce qu'elles rencontrent. Vous sçavez que les Planetes sont portées dans la matiere celeste, qui est d'une subtilité, & d'une agitation prodigieuse. Tout ce grand amas de matiere celeste, qui est depuis le Soleil <UP></UP>jusqu'aux Etoiles fixes, tourne en rond, & emportant avec soy les Planetes <UP></UP>, les fait tourner toutes en un mesme sens autour du Soleil, qui occupe le centre; mais en des temps plus ou moins longs, selon qu'elles en sont plus ou moins éloignées. Il n'y a pas jusqu'au Soleil qui ne tourne; mais il ne tourne que sur luy-mesme, parce qu'il est justement au milieu de toute cette <IIM>matiere celeste</IIM>; & vous remarquerez en passant, que quand la Terre seroit dans la place où il est, elle ne pourroit encore faire moins que de tourner sur elle-mesme.</P064> <P065>Voila quel est le grand Tourbillon dont le Soleil est comme le Maistre; mais en mesme temps les Planetes se composent de petits Tourbillons particuliers à l'imitation de celuy du Soleil. Chacune d'elles en tournant autour du Soleil, ne laisse pas de tourner autour d'elle-mesme, & fait tourner aussi autour d'elle en mesme sens une certaine quantité de cette matiere celeste, qui est toûjours preste à suivre tous les mouvemens qu'on luy veut donner, s'ils ne la détournent pas de son mouvement general. c'est-là le Tourbillon particulier de la Planete & elle le pousse aussi loin que la force de son mouvement se peut étendre. S'il faut qu'il tombe dans ce petit Tourbillon quelque Planete moindre que celle qui y domine, la voilà emportée par la grande, & forcée indispensablement à tourner autour d'elle, & le tout ensemble, la grande Planete, la petite, & le Tourbillon qui les renferme, n'en tourne pas moins autour du Soleil. C'est ainsi qu'au commencement du Monde nous nous fismes suivre par la Lune, parce qu'elle se trouva dans l'étenduë de nostre Tourbillon, & tout à fait à nostre bienséance. Jupiter dont je commençois à vous parler, fut plus heureux ou plus puissant que nous. Il y avoit dans son voisinage quatre petites Planetes, ils se les assujettit toutes quatre, & <UP></UP> nous qui sommes une Planete principale, croyez-vous que nous l'eussions esté, si nous nous fussions trouvés proches de luy? Il est quatre-vingt-dix fois plus gros que nous, il nous auroit engloutis sans peine dans son Tourbillon, & nous ne serions qu'une Lune de sa dépendance, au lieu que nous en avons une qui est dans la nostre, tant il est vray que le seul hazard de la situation décide souvent de toute la fortune qu'on doit avoir.</P065>
chunks.target_manual: <P053>Ah, Madam, said I, if you knew what were Descartes's <RW>Whirlpools or Vortex's</RW>, <NCP>(whose Name is terrible, but their Idea pleasant)</NCP> you would not talk as you do. Must my Head, says she, smiling, turn round to comprehend 'em, or must I become a perfect Fool to understand the misteries of Philosophy? Well, let the World say what it will, go on with your Whirlpools. I will, said I, and you shall see the Whirlpools are worthy of these transports: That then which we call a Whirlpool, or Vortex, is a Mass of Matter, whose parts are separated or detach'd one from another, yet have all one uniform motion, and at the same time, every one is allow'd, or has a particular Motion of its own, provided if follows the general Motion: Thus a Vortex of Wind, or Whirlwind, is an infinity of little particles of Air, which turn round all together, and involve what ever they meet with. You know the Planets are born up by the Celestial Matter, which is prodigiously subtile and active; so that this great Mass, or <IIM>Ocean of</IIM> Celestial Matter, which flows as far as from the Sun to the fix'd Stars, turns round, and bears the Planets along with it, making them all turn after the same manner round the Sun, who possesses the Centre, but in a longer or shorter time, according as they are farther or nearer in distance to it; there is nothing to the very Sun, which does not turn, but he turns on himself because he is just in the middle of this Celestial Matter; and you must know by the way, that were the Earth in his place, it must turn on it self, as the Sun does. This is the great Vortex, of which the Sun is Lord; yet at the same time, the Planets make little particular Vortex's, in imitation of that of the Sun, each of 'em in turning round the Sun, doth at the same time turn round it self, and makes a certain quantity of Celestial Matter turn round it likewise, which is always prepar'd to follow the Motion the Planet gives it, provided it is not diverted from its general Motion; this then is the particular Vortex of the Planet, which pushes it as far as the strength of its Motion reaches; and if by chance, a lesser Planet falls into the Vortex of a greater Planet, it is immediately born away by the greater, and is indispensably forc'd to turn round it, tho' at the same time, the great Planet, the little Planet, and the Vortex which encloses 'em, all turn round the Sun: 'Twas thus at the beginning of the World, when we made the Moon follow us, because she was within the reach of our Vortex, and therefore wholly at our dispose: Jupiter was stronger, or more fortunate than we, he had four little Planets in his neighbourhood, and he brought 'em all four under his subjection; and <UP>no doubt</UP>, we, tho' a principal Planet, had had the same Fate, had we been within the Sphere of his Activity; he is ninety times bigger than the Earth, and would certainly have swallow'd us into his Vortex; we had then been no more than a Moon in his Family, when now we have one to wait on us; so that you see the advantage of Situation, decides often all our good Fortune.</P053>

explanations: The translation significantly condenses the Marquise's enthusiastic speech by omitting several clauses that detail her abandon ('Finish making me mad,' 'I no longer spare myself,' 'I no longer know any restraint regarding Philosophy'), thereby reducing textual density and emotional nuance.

The translation omits the philosopher's commentary on the Marquise's surprising passion and his witty remark ('it's a pity that they only have the Whirlpools as their object'), simplifying the text by removing a layer of nuanced character interaction and playful wit.

The French 'permis à elles d'avoir...' is an elegant, condensed participial construction. The English 'every one is allow'd, or has...' simplifies this by using a more direct structure with an explicit subject ('every one') and active verbs, making the syntax more straightforward.

The French noun-based phrasing 'd'une subtilité, & d'une agitation prodigieuse' (of a prodigious subtlety and agitation) is simplified to a more direct adverb-adjective construction ('prodigiously subtile and active'). 'Active' is also a more common adjective than the abstract noun 'agitation' here, simplifying vocabulary.

The formal and somewhat indirect French expression of necessity 'ne pourroit encore faire moins que de tourner' (lit. could still do no less than turn) is simplified to the more direct and common 'it must turn.'

The French reflexive verb 'se composent de' (compose for themselves) in 'les Planetes se composent de petits Tourbillons particuliers' is simplified to the more common and direct active verb 'make' in 'the Planets make little particular Vortex's', streamlining the grammatical structure.

The French idiomatic phrase 'ne laisse pas de tourner' (does not fail to turn/nevertheless turns) is simplified to the more direct verb phrase 'doth... turn,' removing the need to process a less common idiomatic construction.
The French pronominal verb phrase 'se peut étendre' (can extend itself/can be extended) is simplified to the shorter, more direct active verb 'reaches.'

The French impersonal modal construction 'S'il faut qu'il tombe...' (If it must be that... falls...), which uses the subjunctive, is simplified to a standard conditional clause 'if... a lesser Planet falls...', making the structure less complex.

The nuanced French idiomatic litotes 'n'en tourne pas moins' (nevertheless turns/still turns just as much) is simplified to the direct assertion 'all turn round the Sun,' losing the specific rhetorical subtlety.
The French reflexive causative construction 'nous nous fismes suivre par' (we made ourselves be followed by) is simplified to the more direct English causative structure 'we made [object] [verb]'.
The formal and somewhat abstract French noun 'bienséance' (suitability/convenience) is replaced by the more concrete and direct phrase 'at our dispose' (disposal), simplifying the vocabulary.

The translation simplifies the sentence by omitting the parenthetical clause 'dont je commençois à vous parler' (of whom I was beginning to speak to you), making the main statement more direct and reducing textual density.

The original French rhetorical question addressed to the Marquise ('croyez-vous que...' - do you believe that...) is simplified by being transformed into a declarative statement ('no doubt...'), which alters the pragmatic function and reduces interactive complexity.

The French phrase 'une qui est dans la nostre [dépendance]' (one which is in ours [our dependence]), which refers to an abstract concept, is simplified by using the more concrete and vivid imagery 'one to wait on us.'

The impersonal French emphatic construction 'tant il est vray que...' (it is so true that...) is simplified to the more direct and conversational 'so that you see...', making the tone less formal and more engaging.

chunks.source_manual: <P066>Et qui nous assure, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que nous demeurerons toûjours où nous sommes? Je commence à craindre que nous ne fassions la folie de nous approcher d'une Planete aussi entreprenante que Jupiter, ou qu'il <IIM>ne vienne</IIM> vers nous pour nous absorber; car il me paroist que dans ce grand mouvement, où vous dites qu'est la matiere Celeste, elle devroit agiter les Planetes irregulierement, tantost les approcher, tantost les éloigner les unes des autres. <UP>Nous pourrions aussi-tost y gagner qu'y perdre, répondis-je</UP>, peut-estre irions-nous soumettre à nostre domination Mercure & Venus, qui sont de petites Planetes, & qui ne nous pourroient résister. Mais nous n'avons rien à esperer ny à craindre; les Planetes se tiennent où elles sont, & les nouvelles conquestes leur sont défenduës, comme elles l'étoient autrefois aux Rois de la Chine. Vous sçavez bien que quand on met de l'huile avec de l'eau, l'huile surnage. Qu'on mette sur ces deux liqueurs un Corps extremement leger <UP></UP>, l'huile le soûtiendra, & il n'ira pas jusqu'à l'eau. Qu'on y mette un autre Corps plus pesant, & qui soit justement d'une certaine pesanteur, il passera au travers de l'huile, qui sera trop foible pour l'arrester, & tombera jusqu'à ce qu'il rencontre l'eau, qui aura la force de le soûtenir. Ainsi dans cette liqueur composée de deux liqueurs qui ne se mêlent point, deux Corps inégalement pesants se mettent naturellement à deux places differentes, & jamais l'un ne montera, ny l'autre ne descendra. Qu'on mette encore d'autres liqueurs qui se tiennent separées, & qu'on y plonge d'autres corps, il arrivera la mesme chose. Representez-vous que la Matiere Celeste qui remplit ce grand Tourbillon, à differentes couches qui s'envelopent les unes les autres, & dont les pesanteurs sont differentes, comme celles de l'huile & de l'eau, & des autres liqueurs. Les Planetes ont aussi differentes pesanteurs; chacune d'elles par consequent s'arreste dans la couche qui a précisément la force necessaire pour la soûtenir, & qui luy fait équilibre, & vous voyez bien qu'il n'est pas possible qu'elle en sorte jamais.</P066>
chunks.target_manual: <P054>But pray, says she, who can assure us we shall still continue as we do now? if we should be such Fools as to go near Jupiter, or he so <IIM>ambitious</IIM> as to approach us, what will become of us? for if (as you say) the Celestial Matter is continually under this great Motion, it must needs agitate the Planets irregularly; sometimes drive 'em together, and sometimes separate 'em. <UP>Luck is all, said I; we may win as well as lose</UP>, and who knows, but we should bring Mercury and Venus under our Government; they are little Planets, and cannot resist us; but in this particular, Madam, we need not hope or fear; the Planets keep within their own bounds, and are oblig'd (as formerly the Kings of China were) not to undertake new Conquests. Have you not seen when you put Water and Oyl together, the Oyl swims a top; and if to these two Liquors, you add a very light Liquor, the Oyl bears it up, and it will not sink to the Water: But put an heavier Liquor, of a just weight, and it will pass through the Oyl, which is too weak to sustain it, and sink till it comes to the Water, which is strong enough to bear it up; so that in this Liquor, compos'd of two Liquors, which do not mingle, two Bodies of an unequal weight, will naturally assume two different Places; the one will never ascend, the other will never descend: Fancy then that the Celestial Matter which fills this great Vortex, hath several resting places, one by another, whose weight are different, like that of Oyl, Water, and other Liquors; the Planets too are of a different weight, and consequently, every Planet settles in that place which has a just strength to sustain and keep it equilibrate, so you see 'tis impossible it should ever go beyond.</P054>
source_segments: Je commence à craindre que nous ne fassions la folie de nous approcher d'une Planete aussi entreprenante que Jupiter, ou qu'il ne vienne vers nous pour nous absorber;
Nous pourrions aussi-tost y gagner qu'y perdre, répondis-je, peut-estre irions-nous soumettre à nostre domination Mercure & Venus
Qu'on y mette un autre Corps plus pesant, & qui soit justement d'une certaine pesanteur
Representez-vous que la Matiere Celeste qui remplit ce grand Tourbillon, à differentes couches qui s'envelopent les unes les autres

explanations: The French expresses fear through a complex subordinate clause ('Je commence à craindre que...'). The English translation simplifies this structure into a more direct conditional ('if we should be such Fools...') followed by an explicit question ('what will become of us?'). The formal phrase 'la folie de nous approcher' (the folly of approaching) is rendered as the more colloquial and direct 'be such Fools as to go near,' enhancing readability.

The translator simplifies the somewhat formal French 'Nous pourrions aussi-tost y gagner qu'y perdre' (We could as soon gain by it as lose by it) by introducing the common, pithy idiom 'Luck is all.' Furthermore, 'peut-estre irions-nous soumettre à nostre domination' (perhaps we would go and submit to our domination) is rephrased using the conversational idiom 'who knows, but' and the simpler phrasal verb 'bring...under our Government,' replacing the more formal 'soumettre à nostre domination.'

The French impersonal construction 'Qu'on y mette' (Let one put there), which uses an indefinite pronoun and subjunctive mood, is simplified to a direct imperative 'But put.' Additionally, the relative clause '& qui soit justement d'une certaine pesanteur' (and which is precisely of a certain weight/density) is simplified to the more concise prepositional phrase 'of a just weight,' reducing the sentence's structural complexity.

The original French 'à differentes couches qui s'envelopent les unes les autres' (has different layers that envelop one another) describes a somewhat abstract and intricate spatial arrangement. The English translation simplifies this by replacing 'couches' (layers) with the more concrete and functionally descriptive 'resting places.' It also simplifies the reciprocal action 's'envelopent les unes les autres' (envelop one another) to the plainer phrase 'one by another,' making the concept easier for a non-scientific audience to visualize.

chunks.source_manual: <P067>Je conçois, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que ces pesanteurs-là reglent fort bien les rangs. Plust à Dieu qu'il y eust quelque chose de pareil qui les reglast parmi nous, & qui fixast les Gens dans les places qui leur sont naturellement convenables. Me voila fort en repos du costé de Jupiter. Je suis bien-aise qu'il nous laisse dans nostre petit Tourbillon <SC>avec nostre Lune unique</SC>. Je suis d'humeur à me borner aisément, & je ne luy envie point les quatre qu'il a.</P067> <P068>Vous auriez tort de les luy envier, repris-je, il n'en a point plus qu'il ne luy en faut. Dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil, les Lunes ne reçoivent & ne luy renvoyent, qu'une lumiere assez faible. Il est vray que comme il tourne sur luy-mesme en dix heures, & que ses nuits, qui par consequent <IIM>n'en durent que cinq</IIM>, sont fort courtes, quatre Lunes ne paroîtroient pas si necessaires, mais il y a autre chose à considerer. Icy sous les Pôles, on a six mois de jour, & six mois de nuit. C'est que les Pôles sont les deux extremitez de la Terre les plus éloignées des lieux où le Soleil donne à plomb, & sur lesquels il paroit faire sa course. La Lune ne tient, ou paroist tenir la même route à peu prés que le Soleil, & si les Habitans des Pôles voyent le Soleil pendant toute une moitié de sa course d'un an, & pendant toute l'autre moitié ne le voyent point, ils voyent aussi la Lune pendant toute une moitié de sa course d'un mois, c'est à dire, pendant quinze jours, & ils ne la voyent point pendant toute l'autre moitié. <IIM>Les années de Jupiter</IIM> en valent douze des nostre, & il doit y avoir dans cette Planete deux extremitez opposées, où l'on ait des jours & des nuits de six ans entiers. <IIM>Des nuits</IIM> de six ans sont bien longues, aussi est ce principalement pour elles que je crois que les quatre Lunes sont faites. Celle qui à l'egard de Jupiter est la plus élevée, fait son cercle autour de luy en dix-sept jours, la seconde en sept, la troisiéme en trois jours & demy, la quatrième en quarante-deux heures. Leurs courses estant coupées justement par la moitié pour ces malheureux <UP></UP> Pays qui ont six ans de nuit, il ne se peut passer vingt & une heures, qu'on ne voye paroistre au moins la derniere Lune. C'est quelque consolation pendant des tenebres d'une durée si ennuyeuse; mais quelque lieu que l'on habite dans Jupiter, ces quatre Lunes vous y donnent les plus jolis Spectacles <UP></UP> du monde. Tantost elles se lèvent toutes quatre ensemble, & puis se separent selon l'inégalité de leur cours; tantost elles sont toutes à leur Midy rangées l'une au dessus de l'autre, tantost <RW>on les</RW> voit toutes quatre sur l'Horizon à des distances égales; tantost quand deux se levent, deux autres se couchent; sur tout j'aimerois à voir ce jeu perpetuel d'Eclipses qu'elles font, car il ne se passe point de jour qu'elles ne s'éclipsent les unes les autres, ou qu'elles n'éclipsent le Soleil, & asseurément les Eclipses s'estant renduës si familieres en ce Monde-là, elles y sont un sujet de divertissement, & non pas de frayeur, comme en celuy-ci.</P068> <P069><SC>Gens de nostre Lune</SC>, me fait douter que Jupiter en ait beaucoup sur le Habitans de siennes, & je croy qu'un des avantages ausquels ils puissent le plus raisonnablemént pretendre, c'est de leur faire peur. <UP>Par exemple, dans celle qui est la plus proche de luy, ils le voyent trois cents soixante fois plus gros que nostre Lune ne nous paroist, car il la surpasse autant en grosseur. Il est, je croy, beaucoup plus proche d'eux, qu'elle n'est de nous, sa grosseur en augmente encore. Ils fent comme des Colonies de Jupiter; qu'elles eussent receu de luy, s'il estoit possible, leurs Loix & leurs Coûtumes; que par consequent elles luy redissent quelque sorte d'hommage, & ne regardassent la grande Planete qu'avec respect. Ne faudroit-il point aussi, luy dis-je, que les quatre Lunes envoyassent de temps en temps des Députez dans Jupiter, pour luy prester ferment de fidelité? Pour moy, je vous avoüe que le peu de superiorité que nous avons sur les Gens.</UP></P069>
chunks.target_manual: <P055>Would to God, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, our World were as well regulated, and every one among us knew their proper Place. I am now in no fear of being over-run by Jupiter; and since he lets us alone in our Vortex, with our Moon, I do not envy him the four which he hath. Did you envy him, I reply'd, you would do him wrong, for he has no more than what he has occasion for; at the distance he is from the Sun, his Moons receive, and send him but a very weak light; it is true, that as he turns upon himself in ten hours, his nights, by consequence, are but five hours long; so one would think there is no great occasion for four Moons; but there are other things to be considered. Here under the Poles, they have six Months Day, and six Months Night, because the Poles are the two extremities of the Earth, the farthest removed from those places where the Sun is over 'em in a perpendicular line. The Moon seems to keep almost the same course as the Sun, and if the Inhabitants of the Poles see the Sun during one half of his course of a Year, and during the other half, do not see him at all; they see the Moon likewise during one half of her course of a Month; that is, she appears to 'em fifteen days, but they do not see her during the other half. Jupiter's Year is as much as twelve of ours, so that there must be two opposite extremities in that Planet, where their Night and their Day are six Years each. A Night six Years long, is a little disconsolate, and 'tis for that reason, I suppose, they have four Moons; that which (in regard to Jupiter) is uppermost, finisheth its course about him in seventeen days, the second in seven, the third in three days and an half, and the fourth in two and forty hours; and tho' they are so unfortunate as to have six years Night, yet their course being exactly divided into halves, they never pass above one and twenty hours, wherein they do not see at least the last Moon, which is a great comfort in so tedious a darkness; so that be where you will, these four Moons are sometimes the prettiest sight imaginable; sometimes they rise all four together, and then separate according to the inequality of their course; sometimes they are all in their Meridian, rang'd one above another, sometimes you see 'em at equal distances on the Horizon, sometimes when two rise, the other two go down. Oh, how I should love to see this pleasant sport of Eclipses; for there is not a Day passes but they Eclipse the Sun, or one another; and they are so accustom'd to this diversion in Jupiter, <UP>that the late Duke of B-m in his Rehersal, brought the dance of Eclipses from that Planet, as now most of our modish Dances come out of France</UP>.</P055>

explanations: The opening clause "Je conçois, dit la Marquise, que ces pesanteurs-là reglent fort bien les rangs" (I understand, said the Marquise, that these gravities/weights regulate ranks very well) is entirely omitted in the translation, which begins directly with the translation of "Plust à Dieu...". This simplifies the dialogue by removing the Marquise's explicit acknowledgment of the preceding scientific point, reducing the textual density and a conversational link.

The French "quelque chose de pareil qui les reglast parmi nous" (something similar that would regulate them among us) is rendered more generally as "our World were as well regulated." The subsequent complex clause "qui fixast les Gens dans les places qui leur sont naturellement convenables" (that would fix People in the places that are naturally suitable for them) is simplified in vocabulary ("fixast les Gens" to "every one...knew") and condensed in structure to "and every one among us knew their proper Place," making the wish less specific and using more common phrasing.

The introductory phrase "Je suis d'humeur à me borner aisément" (I am of a temperament to easily content myself / I am easily satisfied with little), which is part of the Marquise's sentence, is omitted. This simplification removes a nuance of the Marquise's self-characterization—her professed easy contentment—making her statement about not envying Jupiter's moons more direct but less psychologically detailed.

The final descriptive clause of the French sentence, "& sur lesquels il paroit faire sa course" (and over which it [the Sun] appears to make its course/journey), is omitted in the translation. This simplification removes a specific astronomical detail about the Sun's apparent path relative to the Earth's poles, slightly reducing the scientific density of the explanation.

The French "ne tient, ou paroist tenir" (keeps, or appears to keep; or possibly with a nuanced negation, "does not [truly] keep, or appears to keep") suggests a more complex or alternative perspective on the Moon's course. The English translation "seems to keep" simplifies this by opting for a single, less complex expression of appearance, thereby losing the potential ambiguity or explicit alternative presented in the original French phrasing.

The French "qu'on ne voye paroistre" (that one does not see appear) is translated as "wherein they do not see". The verb "paroistre" (to appear), which emphasizes the moon's arrival into view, is omitted. This simplifies the description by focusing only on the act of seeing rather than the phenomenon of appearance, reducing a minor descriptive element and density.

The French "jeu perpetuel" (perpetual game) is rendered as "pleasant sport." The adjective "perpetuel" (perpetual), indicating constant recurrence and a key characteristic of the "game" of eclipses, is omitted. This simplifies the description by removing this specific attribute, reducing the richness of the imagery. The word "pleasant" is an addition by the translator.

Fontenelle's general philosophical observation—that familiarity with eclipses (on Jupiter) would lead to amusement rather than fear (as on Earth)—is entirely replaced. The translator substitutes this abstract reflection with a specific, contemporary English cultural reference to the Duke of Buckingham's play "The Rehearsal" and a comment on French dances. This drastically simplifies the original's philosophical content by removing it and inserting a localized, concrete anecdote, thereby reducing the intellectual density and universalizing scope of Fontenelle's text to make it more superficially 'relatable' to a late 17th-century English audience.

chunks.source_manual: <P070>Et vous ne manquerez pas, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, à faire habiter ces quatre Lunes, quoy que ce ne foient que de petites Planetes subalternes, destinées seulement à en éclairer une autre pendant ces nuits? N'en doutez nullement, répondis-je. Ces Planetes n'en sont pas moins dignes d'estre habitées pour avoir le malheur d'estre asservies à tourner autour d'une autre plus importante.</P070> <P071>Je voudrais donc, reprit-elle, que les Habitans des quatre Lunes de Jupiter <UP></UP>, fussont donc toûjours cette monstrueuse Planete suspédüe sur leurs testes à une distance assez petite. En verité, si les Gaulois craignaient anciennement que le Ciel ne tombast sur eux, les Habitans de cette Lune auroient bien plus de sujet de craindre une chute de Jupiter <UP></UP>. C'est peut-estre là aussi la frayeur qu'ils ont, dit- elle, au lieu de celle des Eclipses, dont vous m'avez asseuré qu'ils sont exempts, & qu'il faut bien remplacer par quelque autre sottise? Il le faut de necessité absolüe, répondis-je. L'Inventeur du troisième Systême dont je vous parlois l'autre jour, le celebre Ticho-Brahé <UP></UP>, un des plus grands Astronomes qui furent jamais, n'avoit garde de craindre les Eclipses, comme le Vulgaire les craint, il passoit sa vie avec elles. Mais croiriez-vous bien ce qu'il craignoit en leur place? Si en sortant de son logis, la premiere personne qu'il rencontroit estoit une Vieille, si un Lievre traversoit son chemin, Ticho-Brahé croyoit que la journée devoit estre malheureuse, & retournoit promptement se renfermer chez luy, sans oser commencer la moindre chose.</P071>
chunks.target_manual: <P056>Well, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, I hope you will People these four Moons, tho' you say they are but little secondary Planets, appointed to give light to another Planet during its Night. Do not doubt it, I reply'd; these Planets are not a jot the worse to be inhabited, for being forc'd to turn round another Planet of greater consequence. I would have then, says she, the People of these four Moons, to be so many Colonies under Jupiter's <UP>Government</UP>; they should receive their Laws and Customs from him. Would it not be convenient too, said I, that they should send Deputies with Addresses to him; for he hath cetainly a more absolute command over his Moon, than we have over ours; tho' his Power <UP>after all, is but imaginary</UP>, and consists chiefly in making 'em afraid; for that Moon which is nearest to him, sees that he is <UP>three hundred and sixty times bigger than our Moon appears to us</UP>; for in truth, he is so much bigger than she; he is also much nearer to them, than our Moon is to us, the which makes him appear the greater, so that this <UP>formidable</UP> Planet hangs continually over their Heads, at a very little distance and if the Gauls were afraid heretofore that the Heavens would fall on 'em, I think the Inhabitants of that Moon may well be apprehensive that Jupiter will at some time or other overwhelm 'em. They are, says she, I fancy, possess'd with that fear, because they are not concern'd at Eclipses: Every one has their due folly; we are afraid of an Eclipse, and they, that Jupiter will fall on their Heads. It is very true, said I, the Inventer of the third Systeme, I told you t'other night, the famous Ticho Brahe, <NCP>(one of the greatest Astronomers that ever was,)</NCP> <UP>did not apprehend the least danger from an Eclipse, when every body else was under the greatest consternation; yet this great Man had as an unaccountable a fear, did a hare cross him, or were the first Person he met in a morning an old Woman, home presently went Ticho Brahe, he shut himself up for that day, and would not meddle with the least Business</UP>.</P056>

explanations: The French "vous ne manquerez pas à faire habiter" implies a strong expectation or polite injunction ("you will be sure to make inhabited"). The English "I hope you will People" softens this to an expression of hope. The addition of "Well" also makes it more conversational and less formal, which simplifies by reducing assertiveness and formality.

The phrase "n'en sont pas moins dignes d'estre habitées" (are not less worthy of being inhabited) is rendered as "are not a jot the worse to be inhabited," using a more colloquial and less formal idiom. Further, "pour avoir le malheur d'estre asservies" (for having the misfortune of being enslaved/subjected) is simplified to "for being forc'd," which is a more direct and common verb, reducing the literary nuance of "avoir le malheur de."

The clause "dont vous m'avez asseuré qu'ils sont exempts" (from which you assured me they are exempt), which adds context by referring to the philosopher's prior statements about the inhabitants' freedom from fear of eclipses, is omitted in the corresponding English sentence. This omission simplifies the sentence by reducing its grammatical complexity and informational density.

The Marquise's sharp, rhetorical question "& qu'il faut bien remplacer par quelque autre sottise?" (and which must indeed be replaced by some other foolishness?) is transformed. The translator replaces this with a more generalized proverbial statement ("Every one has their due folly") followed by a concrete, illustrative comparison. This simplifies the original by making the abstract, cynical point more explicit and accessible through familiar phrasing and an example, lessening the sharpness of the original wit.

The French phrase "Il le faut de necessité absolüe" (It is absolutely necessary / It must be so, by absolute necessity), a somewhat formal and emphatic assertion of inevitability, is translated as "It is very true." This simplifies the original by replacing a philosophically-tinged expression with a common phrase of agreement, reducing lexical formality and conceptual specificity.

The phrase "il passoit sa vie avec elles" (he spent his life with them [eclipses]), which underscores Tycho Brahe's profound familiarity with eclipses, is omitted. The English text moves directly to describing his own peculiar fear. This omission streamlines the sentence by removing a clause that provides supporting detail, thus simplifying the text by reducing its informational content slightly.

The direct rhetorical question "Mais croiriez-vous bien ce qu'il craignoit en leur place?" (But would you believe what he feared instead?) is changed into a declarative statement: "yet this great Man had as an unaccountable a fear,". This simplifies the text by removing the direct address to the reader ("vous") and the interrogative structure, making the introduction of Tycho's superstition more of a straightforward narration.

The clause "Ticho-Brahé croyoit que la journée devoit estre malheureuse" (Tycho Brahe believed that the day was bound to be unlucky) is omitted. The English translation moves directly to his actions ("home presently went Ticho Brahe, he shut himself up for that day"), simplifying the narrative by relying on implication rather than an explicit statement of his belief, thus reducing the explanatory text.

chunks.source_manual: <P072>Il ne seroit pas juste, <IIM>reprit-elle</IIM>, aprés que cet homme-là n'a pû se delivrer impunément de la crainte des Eclipses, que les Habitans de cette <UP></UP> Lune de Jupiter, dont nous parlions, en fussent quittes à meilleur marché. Nous ne leur ferons pas de quartier, ils subiront la Loy commune <UP></UP>, & donneront dans quelque autre erreur, mais comme je ne me pique pas de la pouvoir deviner, éclaircissez-moy, je vous prie, une autre difficulté qui m'occupe depuis quelques momens. Si la Terre est si petite à l'égard de Jupiter, Jupiter nous voit-il? Je crains que nous ne luy soyons inconnus.</P072> <P073>De bonne foy, je croy que cela est, répondis-je. Il faudroit qu'il vist la Terre quatre-vingt-dix fois plus petite que nous ne le voyons. C'est trop peu, il ne la voit point. Voicy seulement ce que nous pouvons croire de meilleur pour nous. Il y aura dans Jupiter des Astronomes, qui aprés avoir bien pris de la peine à composer des Lunettes excellentes, aprés avoir choisy les plus belles Nuits pour observer, auront enfin découvert dans les Cieux une petite Planete qu'ils n'avoyent jamais veüe. D'abord le <NCE>Journal des Sçavans</NCE> de ce Pays-là en parle; le Peuple de Jupiter, ou n'en entend point parler, ou n'en fait que rire. Les Philosophes dont cela détruit les opinions, forment le dessein de n'en rien croire, il n'y a que les Gens tres-raisonnables qui en veulent bien douter. On observe encore, on revoit la petite Planete, on s'asseure bien que ce n'est point une vision, on commence même à soupçonner qu'elle a un mouvement autour du Soleil; on trouve au bout de mille observations, que ce <RW>mouvement</RW> est d'une année; & enfin, grace à toutes les peines que se donnent les Sçavans, <NCP></NCP> on sçait dans Jupiter que nostre Terre est un Monde. Les Curieux vont la voir au bout d'une Lunette, & la veüe à peine peut-elle encore l'attraper.</P073>
chunks.target_manual: <P057>Let us go on with ours tho', says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, and leave Ticho Brahe to defend his Superstition. Pray tell me, if the Earth be so little in comparison of Jupiter, whether his Inhabitants do discover us? Indeed, said I, I believe not; for if we appear to him ninety times less than he appears to us; judge you if there be any possibility: Yet this we may reasonably conjecture, that there are Astronomers in Jupiter, that after they have made the most curious Telescopes, and taken the clearest Night for their observations, they may have discover'd a little Planet in the Heavens, which they never saw before; if they publish their discovery, most People know not what they mean, or laugh at 'em for Fools; nay, the Philosophers themselves will not believe 'em, for fear of destroying their own opinions; yet some few may be a little curious; they continue their observations, discover the little Planet again, and are now assur'd it is no Vision; then they conclude it hath a motion round the Sun, which it compleats in a year, and at last, <NCP>(thanks to the Learned,)</NCP> they know in Jupiter our Earth is a World, every body runs to see it at the end of the Telescope, tho' 'tis so little, 'tis hardly discover'd.</P057>

explanations: The formal and somewhat elaborate French request "éclaircissez-moy, je vous prie, une autre difficulté qui m'occupe depuis quelques momens" (clarify for me, I pray you, another difficulty that has been occupying me for some moments) is condensed into the simpler, more direct, and common English phrase "Pray tell me". This reduces circumlocution and lexical density, making the dialogue flow more quickly.

The French phrase "De bonne foy" (in good faith, sincerely, truly) is rendered as the more common English adverb "Indeed". While "Indeed" conveys affirmation, it simplifies the original by using a more standard term and slightly reducing the nuance of earnestness or sincere conviction conveyed by "De bonne foy".

The French "Voicy seulement ce que nous pouvons croire de meilleur pour nous" (Here is only what we can believe that is best for us / most favorable to our case) presents a slightly more complex and specific framing. The English "Yet this we may reasonably conjecture," simplifies this by being more direct and omitting the "de meilleur pour nous" (best for us) aspect, thus reducing the original's slight subjectivity and focus on a favorable belief.

The French phrase "aprés avoir bien pris de la peine à composer" (after having taken great pains to create/develop) emphasizes significant effort and meticulousness in the creation process. The English "after they have made" simplifies this considerably by using a more general and less expressive verb ("made"), thereby reducing the explicit emphasis on the laborious nature of the task, even if "curious" for "excellentes" could be a period-appropriate synonym for finely made.

The French "D'abord le Journal des Sçavans de ce Pays-là en parle" (At first, the Journal of Scholars of that land speaks of it) contains a specific cultural and historical reference to "Le Journal des Sçavans," a prominent French scientific periodical. The English translation "if they publish their discovery" simplifies this by generalizing the act of dissemination and removing the specific, culturally-bound reference. This makes it more accessible to a non-French audience of the time but loses the original's precision and cultural richness. The change from a declarative statement to a conditional one also simplifies the narrative progression.

The French "forment le dessein de n'en rien croire" (form the plan/intention to believe nothing of it) uses a more formal and somewhat elaborate construction to describe the philosophers' deliberate decision. The English "will not believe 'em" (within the larger clause that rephrases the reason) simplifies this to a more direct and common expression of their refusal. The core simplification is in the rendering of the act of deciding not to believe.

The French "il n'y a que les Gens tres-raisonnables qui en veulent bien douter" (there are only the very reasonable people who are willing to doubt it) characterizes a select group by their high degree of reason and their intellectual act of doubting. The English "yet some few may be a little curious" simplifies this by reducing "very reasonable people" to the less specific "some few" and by changing the more profound "willing to doubt" (implying critical thinking) to the more superficial "a little curious." This lessens the emphasis on rationality and intellectual engagement.

The French "on commence même à soupçonner" (one even begins to suspect) describes the initial, tentative phase of forming a hypothesis. The English "then they conclude" simplifies this process by presenting a more definitive and seemingly quicker step ("conclude" instead of "begin to suspect"). This removes the nuance of gradual discovery and the cautious nature of early scientific inference.

The French "on trouve au bout de mille observations, que ce mouvement est d'une année" (one finds after a thousand observations, that this movement is of one year) explicitly highlights the extensive empirical work involved ("a thousand observations"). The English translation, by rendering this as part of a relative clause "which it compleats in a year," omits the detail of "mille observations." This simplification reduces the text's density and lessens the emphasis on the laborious and time-consuming nature of the scientific discovery process.

The French "grace à toutes les peines que se donnent les Sçavans" (thanks to all the pains/efforts that the Scholars/Scientists take upon themselves) conveys the significant and self-driven effort of the scientists. The English "(thanks to the Learned,)" simplifies this by using the more general term "the Learned" (instead of the more active "Sçavans" implying those who know and do) and by omitting the emphatic "toutes les peines que se donnent" (all the pains they take upon themselves). This reduces the vividness of the description of their labor.

The French "Les Curieux vont la voir" (The curious ones/people interested in novelties go to see it) specifies a particular group motivated by curiosity. The English "every body runs to see it" simplifies this by generalizing "Les Curieux" to the much broader and more colloquial "every body." This makes the reaction seem more universal and less characteristic of a specific intellectual type, potentially for a more popular appeal.

chunks.source_manual: <P074>Si ce n'estoit, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, qu'il n'est point trop agreable de sçavoir qu'on ne nous peut découvrir de dedans Jupiter qu'avec des Lunettes d'approche, je me representerois avec plaisir ces Lunettes de Jupiter dressées vers nous, comme les nostres le sont vers luy, & cette curiosité mutuelle avec laquelle les Planetes s'entre-considerent & demandent l'une de l'autre, Quel monde est-ce-là? Quelles Gens l'habitent?</P074> <P075><IIM>Cela ne va pas si viste que vous pensez</IIM>, repliquay-je. Quand on verroit nostre Terre de dedans Jupiter, quand on l'y connoistroit, nostre Terre ce n'est pas nous; on n'a pas le moindre soupçon qu'elle puisse estre habitée. Si quelqu'un vient à se l'imaginer, Dieu sçait comme tout Jupiter se moque de luy. Peut-estre mesme sommes-nous cause qu'on y <UP>a fait le procés</UP> à des Philosophes qui ont voulu soûtenir que nous estions. Cependant je croirois plus volontiers que les Habitans de Jupiter sont assez occupez à faire des découvertes sur leur Planete, pour ne songer point du tout à nous. Elle est si grande, que s'ils navigent, asseurément <UP>leurs Cristophles Colombs ne sçauroient manquer d'employ</UP>. Il faut que les Peuples de ce Monde-là ne connoissent pas seulement de réputation la centiéme partie des autres Peuples, au lieu que dans Mercure, <NCP>qui est fort petit</NCP>, ils sont tous voisins les uns des autres, ils vivent familierement ensemble, & ne comptent que pour une promenade de faire le tour de leur Monde. Si on ne nous voit point dans Jupiter, vous jugez bien qu'on y voit encore moins Venus & Mercure, qui sont des Mondes, & plus petits, & plus éloignez de luy. En récompense ses Habitans voyent Mars, & leurs quatre Lunes, & Saturne <RW>avec les siennes</RW>. Voila assez de Planetes pour embarasser ceux d'entre eux qui sont Astronomes; la Nature a eu la bonté de leur cacher ce qui en reste dans l'Univers.</P075> <P076>Quoy, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, vous comptez cela pour une grace? Sans doute, répondis-je. Il y a dans tout ce grand <RW>Tourbillon</RW> seize Planetes. La Nature qui veut nous épargner la peine d'étudier tous leurs mouvemens, ne nous en montre que sept, n'est-ce pas là une assez grande faveur? Mais nous, qui n'en sentons pas le prix, nous faisons si bien que nous attrapons les neuf autres, qui avoient esté cachees; aussi en sommes-nous punis par les grands travaux que l'Astronomie demande presentement.</P076>
chunks.target_manual: <P058>It must be pleasant, says she, to see the Astronomers of both Planets, levelling their Tubes at one another, like two files of Musqueteers, and mutually asking, What World is that? What People inhabit it? Not so fast neither, I reply'd, for tho' they may from Jupiter discover our Earth, yet they may not know us; that is, they may not have the least suspicion it is inhabited; and should any one there chance to have such a fancy, he might be sufficiently ridicul'd, if not prosecuted for it; for my part, I believe they have work enough to make discoveries on their own Planet, not to trouble their Heads with ours; <UP>and had Sir Francis Drake and Columbus been in Jupiter, they might have had good employments</UP>; why, I warrant you, they have not yet discover'd the hundredth part of their Planet; when Mercury is so little, they are all <NCP>(as it were)</NCP> near Neighbours, and 'tis but taking a walk, to go round that Planet. But if we do not appear to 'em in Jupiter, they cannot certainly discover Venus and Mercury, which are much less than the Earth, and at a greater distance; but in lieu of it, they see Mars, their own four Moons, and Saturn, with his; this I think is work enough for their Astronomers; and Nature hath been so kind to conceal from 'em the rest of the Universe. Do you think it a favour then, says she? Yes, certainly, said I, for there are sixteen Planets in this great Vortex: Nature saves us the trouble of studying the Motions of 'em all, and shows us but seven, which I think is very obliging, tho' we know not how to value the kindness, for we have recover'd the other nine which were hid from us, and so render'd the Science of Astronomy much more difficult than Nature design'd it.</P058>

explanations: The translator simplifies the Marquise's statement by omitting the initial complex negative conditional clause ("If it were not that it is not too pleasant to know that one cannot discover us from within Jupiter except with telescopes..."). This removes a layer of nuanced thought and directly presents the idea of the "pleasant" image, reducing sentence complexity and density. The simile "like two files of Musqueteers" is an addition by the translator, not a simplification of the original text content.

The French phrase describes "this mutual curiosity with which the Planets consider each other and ask one another." The English translation simplifies this to "and mutually asking," omitting the explicit mention of "curiosity" and the action of "considering each other" (`s'entre-considerent`), thus reducing the descriptive detail and density for a more direct statement.

The French "Dieu sçait comme tout Jupiter se moque de luy" (God knows how all of Jupiter mocks him) conveys a strong, somewhat colloquial emphasis on the intensity and certainty of the mockery. The English "he might be sufficiently ridicul'd," tones down this expressiveness, using more formal and less vivid vocabulary, and removes the emphatic "Dieu sçait comme," simplifying the emotional register of the statement.

The original French offers a specific and somewhat ironic speculation: "Perhaps we are even the cause that philosophers there have been put on trial who wanted to maintain that we existed." The English translation drastically simplifies this to "if not prosecuted for it;", which is attached to the preceding idea of someone having the "fancy" that Earth is inhabited. This simplification omits the specific detail about philosophers being prosecuted and the narrator's ironic suggestion of Earth's inhabitants being the indirect cause, reducing the conceptual richness and length of the original thought.

The French text states, "It must be that the Peoples of that World do not know even by reputation the hundredth part of the other Peoples (on their own planet)." This implies a lack of social or informational connection between different populations. The English translation, prefaced by the colloquial "why, I warrant you," (an addition for idiomatic tone not present in the original French), simplifies the core idea to "they have not yet discover'd the hundredth part of their Planet." This shifts the focus from a lack of mutual awareness among populations to a simpler concept of geographical discovery, reducing the socio-cultural nuance of the original.

The French "ils sont tous voisins les uns des autres, ils vivent familierement ensemble" (they are all neighbors to each other, they live familiarly together) is reduced in the English translation to "they are all (as it were) near Neighbours,". The specific detail about living "familierement ensemble" (familiarly together), which implies a quality of social interaction, is omitted, simplifying the depiction of Mercurial society by removing a layer of social detail.

The French "embarasser" (to embarrass, trouble, puzzle, or overwhelm) suggests a significant level of difficulty or confusion for the Jovian astronomers. The English "work enough" is a more general and milder expression. This change in vocabulary simplifies the intensity of the challenge faced by the astronomers, making it sound less daunting.

The French text uses a rhetorical question, "n'est-ce pas là une assez grande faveur?" (is that not a great enough favor?), which directly engages the listener and emphasizes the point. The English translation changes this to a declarative statement, "which I think is very obliging,". This alteration simplifies the rhetorical structure by removing the direct question, making the tone less emphatic and more of a personal reflection by the narrator ("I think").

The French "nous faisons si bien que nous attrapons les neuf autres" (we do so well that we catch/find the nine others) carries a subtle ironic tone, implying a kind of meddlesome cleverness. The English "for we have recover'd the other nine" is more neutral and factual, presenting it as a straightforward achievement. This simplification reduces the ironic nuance present in the original phrasing.

The French text explicitly states "aussi en sommes-nous punis par les grands travaux que l'Astronomie demande presentement" (also we are punished for it by the great labors that Astronomy demands nowadays). This frames the increased difficulty as a direct "punishment" manifested through the "great labors" required by astronomy. The English translation simplifies this by stating "and so render'd the Science of Astronomy much more difficult," removing the direct and somewhat theological concept of "punishment" and the specific agent of this punishment ("les grands travaux"). It rephrases the consequence in more neutral terms of increased difficulty, reducing the original's expressive force and specific imagery. The phrase "than Nature design'd it" is an interpretative addition by the translator rather than a direct translation of this specific clause.

chunks.source_manual: <P077>Je voy, reprit-elle, par ce nombre de seize Planetes qu'il faut que Saturne ait cinq Lunes. Il les a aussi, repliquay-je, & de ces cinq Lunes, il y en a deux bien fraischement découvertes; mais il ya a quelque chose qui est encore bien plus remarquable. Comme son année est de trente des nostres, & que par consequent il a <IIM>des Pays</IIM>, où une seule nuit dure des quinze ans entiers, devinez ce que la Nature a inventé pour éclaires des nuits si affreuses. Elle ne s'est pas contentée de donner cinq Lunes à Saturne, elle a mis autour de luy un grand Cercle, ou un grand Anneau qui l'environne entierement, & qui estant assez élevé pour estre hors de l'ombre du Corps de cette Planete, refléchit perpetuellement la lumiere du Soleil <RW>dans les lieux qui ne le voyent point</RW>.</P077>
chunks.target_manual: <P059>If there are sixteen Planets, says she, Saturn must have five Moons. 'Tis very true, said I, and two of these five, are but lately discover'd; but there is somewhat that is more remarkable, since his Year is thirty of ours, there are consequently in him some Countreys, where their Night is fifteen years long; and what can you imagine Nature hath invented to give light, during so dreadful a Night? Why, she hath not only given Saturn five Moons, but she hath encompass'd him round with a great Circle or Ring, the which being plac'd beyond the reach of the shadow which the Body of that Planet casts, reflects the light of the Sun continually on those places where they cannot see the Sun at all.</P059>

explanations: The French original ("Je voy... par ce nombre... que" - I see by this number that...) describes the Marquise's reasoning as an observation leading to a deduction. The translation simplifies this by restructuring it into a more direct conditional sentence ("If there are sixteen Planets..."), making the logical flow more immediately accessible and less narratively embedded.

The French "il y en a deux bien fraischement découvertes" (there are two of them very freshly/recently discovered) uses the intensifier "bien" (very). The English "two of these five, are but lately discover'd" translates "fraischement" (freshly/recently) as "lately" and uses "but" (in the sense of only/just), effectively omitting a direct equivalent of the intensifier "bien." This simplifies by reducing the original's explicit emphasis on the recency of the discovery.

The French phrase "quinze ans entiers" (fifteen entire years) includes the adjective "entiers" (entire/whole), which emphasizes the completeness and unbroken nature of the period. The English "fifteen years long" omits this specific emphasis, simplifying the description by using a more common and less intensely descriptive phrase.

The original French uses the direct imperative "Devinez" (Guess), actively inviting the Marquise to participate and reason. The English translation changes this to the more polite and less demanding question "what can you imagine Nature hath invented," softening the philosopher's directive. This shift simplifies the interaction by reducing its assertive and pedagogically direct force.

The French clause "dans les lieux qui ne le voyent point" (in the places that do not see it [the Sun]) is concise and implies the observer. The English translation "on those places where they cannot see the Sun at all" makes the implied subject ("they," referring to inhabitants) explicit, specifies "the Sun" (which was 'le' - it - in French), and adds the intensifier "at all." This explicitation, while clarifying, simplifies the original by reducing the reader's inferential work.

The French "Elle ne s'est pas contentée de donner..." (She was not content with giving...) introduces a subsequent, more significant action in a standard narrative way. The English translation prefaces the equivalent idea with the colloquial interjection "Why," and shifts to a "not only... but..." rhetorical structure (with the "but" part following). This move towards a more conversational tone and a common English framing simplifies the original's somewhat more formal narrative style.

chunks.source_manual: <P078>En verité, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, <IIM>de l'air d'une personne qui rentroit en elle-mesme avec étonnement</IIM>, tout cela est d'un grand ordre; il paroist bien que la Nature a eu en veüe les besoins de quelques Estres vivans, & que la distribution des Lunes n'a pas esté faite au hazard. Il n'en est tombé en partage qu'aux Planetes éloignées du Soleil, à la Terre, à Jupiter, à Saturne, car ce n'estoit pas la peine d'en donner à Venus & à Mercure, qui ne reçoivent que trop de lumiere, dont les nuits sont fort courtes, & qui les comptent apparemment pour de plus grands bienfaits de la Nature que leurs jours mesmes. Mais attendez, il me semble que Mars, qui est encore plus éloigné du Soleil que la Terre, n'a <IIM>point de Lune</IIM>. On ne peut pas vous le dissimuler, répondis-je, il n'en a point, & il faut qu'il ait pour ses nuits des ressources que nous ne sçavons pas. Vous avez veu des <SC>Phosphores</SC>, de ces matieres liquides ou seches, qui en recevant la lumiere du Soleil, s'en imbibent, & s'en penetrent, & ensuite jettent un assez grand éclat dans l'obscurité. <SC>Peut-estre Mars a-t-il</SC> de grands Rochers fort élevéz, qui sont des <SC>Phosphores</SC> naturels, & qui prennent pendant le jour une provision de lumiere qu'ils rendent pendant la nuit. Vous ne sçauriez nier que ce ne fust un Spectacle assez agreable, de voir tous ces Rochers s'alumer de toutes parts dés que le Soleil seroit couché, & faire sans aucun art des illuminations magnifiques. Vous sçavez encore qu'il y a en Amerique des Oyseaux qui sont si lumineux dans les tenebres, qu'on s'en peut servir pour lire. Que sçavons-nous si Mars n'a point un grand nombre de ces Oyseaux, qui dés que la nuit est venuë, se dispersent de tous costéz, & vont répandre un nouveau jour?</P078>
chunks.target_manual: <P060>I protest, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, this is very surprizing, and yet all is contriv'd in such great order, that it is impossible not to think but Nature took time to consider the necessities of all animate Beings, and that the disposing of these Moons was not a work of Chance, for they are only divided among those Planets which are farthest distant from the Sun, the Earth, Jupiter, Saturn; indeed it was not worth while to give any to Mercury or Venus, they have too much light already; and they account their nights (as short as they are) a greater blessing than their day. But pray, why has not Mars a Moon too? It seems he has none, tho' he is much further than the Earth from the Sun. It is very true, said I; no doubt but he hath other helps, tho' we do not know 'em: You have seen the Phosphorus, both liquid and dry, how it receives and imbibes the rays of the Sun, and what a great light it will cast in a dark Place: Perhaps Mars hath many great high Rocks, which are so many natural Phosphorus's, which in the day take in a certain provision of light, and return it again at night. What think you, Madam, is it not very pleasant when the Sun is down to see those lighted Rocks, like so many Illuminations at a Birth day night? Besides, there is a kind of Bird in America, that yields such a light, you may read by it in the darkest night; and who knows but Mars may have great flocks of these Birds, that as soon as it is night, disperse themselves into all parts, and spread from their wings another day.</P060>

explanations: The French phrase, describing the Marquise's introspective and astonished demeanor ('withdrawing into herself with astonishment'), is simplified. The translation conveys the 'astonishment' aspect directly through the Marquise's exclamation 'this is very surprizing,' while the reflective detail 'rentroit en elle-mesme' (withdrawing into herself) is omitted, reducing the original's psychological nuance and simplifying the character's expression.

The somewhat formal and idiomatic French 'Il n'en est tombé en partage qu'aux' (literally 'It has only fallen in share to them') is replaced by the more direct and common phrasal verb 'are only divided among,' simplifying vocabulary and sentence structure.

The translation simplifies the original by: a) using the more direct 'have too much light already' for 'ne reçoivent que trop de lumiere'; b) restructuring 'dont les nuits sont fort courtes' (whose nights are very short) into a simpler parenthetical '(as short as they are)', streamlining the sentence; c) omitting the qualifying adverb 'apparemment' (apparently); and d) reducing 'de plus grands bienfaits de la Nature que leurs jours mesmes' to 'a greater blessing than their day,' omitting 'de la Nature' (of Nature) and the emphatic 'mesmes' (themselves), thereby reducing descriptive density and nuance.

The Marquise's original statement of realization, 'il me semble que Mars... n'a point de Lune' (it seems to me that Mars... has no Moon), is restructured. The translator simplifies her expression by first posing a direct question ('why has not Mars a Moon too?') and then stating the observation ('It seems he has none'), making the dialogue more direct and less reflective of her thought process.

The formal and slightly indirect French 'On ne peut pas vous le dissimuler' (One cannot hide it from you / It cannot be concealed from you) is simplified to the very direct, common, and shorter English phrase 'It is very true.'

The French 'des ressources' (resources), implying specific means or provisions, is translated as 'other helps.' 'Helps' is a more general and arguably simpler term in this context, simplifying the vocabulary by reducing the specificity of the original.

The French 'fort élevéz' (very high/highly elevated) modifying 'grands Rochers' (great Rocks) is simplified in 'many great high Rocks' by omitting the intensifier 'fort' (very), slightly reducing the descriptive intensity.

This passage is simplified in several ways: a) The complex French rhetorical construction 'Vous ne sçauriez nier que ce ne fust' (You could not deny that it would be) is replaced by the simpler direct question and assertion 'What think you, Madam, is it not very pleasant'. b) The descriptive detail 's'alumer de toutes parts' (to light up on all sides) is reduced to 'lighted Rocks,' omitting 'de toutes parts'. c) 'dés que le Soleil seroit couché' (as soon as the Sun had set) is simplified to the more common 'when the Sun is down.' d) The qualifying phrase 'sans aucun art' (without any artifice/naturally), describing the illuminations, is entirely omitted, removing a nuance and simplifying the description.

Simplification occurs by: a) Changing 'Vous sçavez encore que' (You also know that), which suggests shared knowledge, to 'Besides,' which frames it as new information, simplifying the conversational dynamic. b) Replacing the somewhat literary 'dans les tenebres' (in the darkness/gloom) with the more common and vivid 'in the darkest night.' c) Transforming the impersonal 'qu'on s'en peut servir pour lire' (that one can use them to read) into the more direct second-person 'you may read by it,' a common simplification in popular writing to enhance accessibility.

chunks.source_manual: <P079>Je ne me contente, reprit-elle, ny de vos Rochers, ni de vos Oyseaux. Cela ne laisseroit pas d'estre joly, mais puis que la Nature a donné tant de Lunes à Saturne & à Jupiter, c'est une marque qu'il faut des Lunes. J'eusse esté bien-aise que tous les Mondes éloignez du Soleil en eussent eu, si Mars ne nous fust point venu faire une exception desagreable. Ah! vrayment, repliquay-je, si <LS><IIM>vous vous mêliez de Philosophie plus que vous ne faites</IIM></LS>, il faudroit bien que vous vous accoûtumassiez à voir des exceptions dans les meilleurs Sistêmes. Il y a toûjours quelque chose qui y convient le plus juste du monde, & puis quelque chose aussi qu'on y fait convenir comme on peut, ou qu'on laisse-là, si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout. Usons-en de mesme pour Mars, puis qu'il ne nous est point favorable, & ne parlons point de luy. Nous serions bien étonnez, si nous estions dans Saturne, de voir sur nos testes pendant la nuit ce grand Anneau qui iroit en forme de demy Cercle d'un bout à l'autre de l'Horison, & qui nous renvoyant la lumiere du Soleil feroit l'effet d'une Lune continuë. Et ne mettrons-nous point d'Habitans dans ce grand Anneau, interrompit-elle en riant? Quoy que je sois d'humeur, répondis-je, à en envoyer par tout assez hardiment, je vous avoüe que je n'oserois en mettre là, cet Anneau me paroist une habitation trop irreguliere. Pour les cinq petites Lunes, on ne peut pas se dispenser de les peupler. Si cependant l'Anneau n'estoit, comme quelques-uns le soupçonnent, qu'un Cercle de Lunes qui se suivissent de fort prés, & eussent un mouvement égal, & que les cinq petites Lunes fussent trois échapées de ce grand Cercle, que de Mondes dans le Tourbillon de Saturne! Quoy qu'il en soit, avec le secours même de l'Anneau, les Gens de Saturne sont assez miserables. Il leur donne de la lumiere, mais quelle lumiere, dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil! Le Soleil même n'est pour eux qu'une petite Etoile blanche & pâle, qui n'a qu'un éclat & une chaleur bien foible, & si vous les mettiez dans nos Pays les plus froids, dans la Groënlande, ou dans la Laponie, vous les verriez suër à grosses gouttes & expirer de chaud.</P079>
chunks.target_manual: <P061>I am not at all contented, says she, with your Rocks, or your Birds; 'tis a pretty fancy indeed, but 'tis a sign that there should be Moons in Mars, since Nature hath given so many to Saturn, and Jupiter; and if all the other Worlds that are distant from the Sun, have Moons, why should Mars only be excepted? Ah, Madam, said I, when you are a little more dip'd in Philosophy, you will find exceptions in the very best Systemes; there are always some things that agree extream well, but then there are others that do not accord at all; those you must leave as you found 'em, if ever you intend to make an end: We will do so by Mars, if you please, and say no more of him; but return to Saturn. What do you think of his great Ring, in the form of a semy Circle, that reaches from one end of the Horizon to the other, which reflecting the light of the Sun, performs the office of a continual Moon. And must we not inhabit this Ring too, says she? I confess, said I, in the humour I am in, I could almost send Colonies every where; and yet I can't well plant any there, it seems so irregular an habitation; but for the five little Moons, they cannot chuse but be inhabited; tho' some think this Ring is a Circle of Moons, which follow close to one another, and have one equal Motion; and that the five little Moons fell out of this Circle; how many Worlds are there then in the <UP>Vortex of Saturn</UP>? But let it be how it will, the People in Saturn live very miserably: 'Tis true, this Ring gives light to 'em, but it must be a very poor one, when the Sun seems to 'em but a little pale Star, whose light and heat cannot but be very weak at so great a distance; they say Greenland is a perfect Bagnio in comparison of that Planet, and that they would expire with heat in our coldest Countreys.</P061>
