explanations: The formal French litotes "ne laisseroit pas d'estre joly" (would not fail to be pretty) is simplified to the more direct and colloquial English "'tis a pretty fancy indeed," reducing structural complexity and formality.

The complex French sentence, expressing a past unreal conditional wish with multiple pluperfect subjunctive verbs, is drastically simplified by recasting it into a direct question with a simpler conditional structure, losing the original nuance of past regret.

The French uses a complex conditional structure with imperfect subjunctive verbs ("mêliez", "accoûtumassiez") and the modal phrase "il faudroit bien que". The English translation simplifies this to a more straightforward temporal clause with a simple future ("when you are... you will find..."), also using more common vocabulary ("dip'd") and reducing the semantic force from "it would be necessary that you accustom yourself" to "you will find".

The translator omits the French clause "puis qu'il ne nous est point favorable" (since he is not favorable to us), simplifying the sentence by removing a piece of justification. Additionally, the hortative "Usons-en" (Let us do) is changed to the more declarative "We will do so".

The original French sentence, a hypothetical conditional expressing astonishment ("Nous serions bien étonnez, si nous estions... de voir..."), is simplified by transforming its complex structure into a direct question ("What do you think of..."). This makes the text more conversational but sacrifices the original hypothetical and emotive framing.

The descriptive participial phrase "en riant" (laughing), which modifies "interrompit-elle" (she interrupted) and adds character detail, is omitted in the translation, which renders the phrase simply as "says she". This omission simplifies by removing a specific descriptive element.

The translator omits the phrase "avec le secours même de l'Anneau" (even with the help of the Ring). This omission simplifies the sentence by removing a qualifying detail that added a layer of meaning about the Ring's (in)effectiveness in alleviating the Saturnians' misery.

The vivid French idiom "suër à grosses gouttes" (to sweat profusely/big drops) is omitted from the description of the inhabitants' reaction to heat. Furthermore, the direct second-person hypothetical structure ("si vous les mettiez... vous les verriez...") is simplified to a reported statement ("they say... that they would expire..."), reducing directness and simplifying the narrative stance. The specific mention of "la Laponie" is also omitted.

chunks.source_manual: <P080>Vous me donnez une idée de Saturne qui me gele, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, au lieu que tantost vous m'échauffiez en me parlant de Mercure. Il faut bien, repliquay-je, que les deux Mondes qui sont aux extremitez de ce grand Tourbillon, soient opposées en toutes choses.</P080> <P081>Ainsi, reprit-elle, on est bien sage dans Saturne, car vous m'avez dit que tout le monde estoit fou dans Mercure. Si on n'est pas bien sage dans Saturne, repris- je, du moins, selon toutes les apparences, on y est bien flegmatique. Ce sont Gens qui ne sçavent ce que c'est que de rire, qui prennent toûjours un jour pour répondre à la moindre question qu'on leur fait, & qui eussent trouvé Caton d'Utique <IIM>trop badin & trop folâtre</IIM>. <NCE></NCE>.</P081>
chunks.target_manual: <P062>You give me, says she, such an Idea of Saturn, that makes me shake with cold, and that of Mercury, puts me into a feaver. It cannot be otherwise, I reply'd, for the two Worlds, which are the extremities of this great Vortex, must be opposite in all things. They must then, says she, be very wise in Saturn, for you told me they were all Fools in Mercury. If they are not wise, said I, yet they have all the appearances of being very Flegmatick: They are People that know not what 'tis to laugh, they take a days time to answer the least question you can ask 'em; and are so very grave, that were Cato living among 'em, they would think him <NCE>a merry Andrew</NCE>.</P062>

explanations: The French subordinate clause "au lieu que tantost vous m'échauffiez en me parlant de Mercure" (whereas just now you warmed me by speaking of Mercury) is condensed. The English translation simplifies this by omitting the temporal adverb "tantost" (just now) and replacing the participial clause "en me parlant de Mercure" (by speaking of Mercury) with the more concise noun phrase "that of Mercury." This reduces syntactic complexity and the amount of descriptive detail. The vocabulary shift from "m'échauffiez" (warmed me) to the common idiom "puts me into a feaver" also contributes to a different, more intense, but still accessible expression.

The French "qui ne sçavent ce que c'est que de rire" (who do not know what it is to laugh) uses a somewhat periphrastic construction "ce que c'est que de + infinitive." The English "that know not what 'tis to laugh" simplifies this by using the common contraction "'tis" and presenting a more direct phrasal equivalent, making the expression slightly less formal and more concise.

The impersonal French relative clause "qu'on leur fait" (literally "that one makes/does to them," used in "faire une question" meaning "to ask a question") is simplified to the more direct and colloquial relative clause "you can ask 'em." This uses a more common active phrasing with a personal pronoun ("you" for generalization) and the common verb "ask," along with the colloquialism "'em," enhancing readability and directness.

The translator has significantly restructured this phrase and substituted vocabulary. The French conditional past "qui eussent trouvé Caton d'Utique trop badin & trop folâtre" (who would have found Cato of Utica too playful and too frolicsome) is transformed. The English version first adds an explicit characteristic ("are so very grave"), then creates a hypothetical result clause ("that were Cato living among 'em, they would think him a merry Andrew"). The specific adjectives "badin & trop folâtre" are replaced by the colloquial English term "a merry Andrew," a stock character for a clown/buffoon. This simplifies by using a culturally specific and readily understandable stereotype (for the contemporary English reader) instead of nuanced descriptors. The name "Caton d'Utique" is also shortened to "Cato." These changes enhance readability and impact for the target audience.

chunks.source_manual: <P082>Il me vient une pensée, dit-elle. Tous les Habitans de Mercure sont vifs, tous ceux de Saturne sont lens. Parmy nous les uns sont vifs, les autres lents; cela ne viendroit-il point de ce que nostre Terre étant justement au milieu des autres Mondes, nous participons des extremitez? Il n'y a point pour les hommes de Caractere fixe & déterminé; les uns sont faits comme les Habitans de Mercure, les autres comme ceux de Saturne, & nous sommes un mélange de toutes les especes qui se trouvent dans les autres Planetes. J'aime assez cette idée, repris- je, nous formons un assemblage si bizarre, qu'on pourroit croire que nous serions ramassez de plusieurs Mondes différens. A ce compte, il est assez commode d'estre icy, on y voit tous les autres Mondes en abregé.</P082>
chunks.target_manual: <P063>It is odd to consider, says she, that the Inhabitants of Mercury are all life, and the Inhabitants of Saturn quite contrary; but among us, some are brisk, and some are dull; it is, I suppose, because our Earth is plac'd in the middle of the other Worlds, and so we participate of both extreams, there is no fix'd or determin'd Character; some are made like the Inhabitants of Mercury, some like those of Saturn; we are a mixture of the several kinds that are found in the rest of the Planets. Why, said I, do you not approve of the Idea? Methinks it is pleasant to be compos'd of such a fantastical Assembly, that one would think we were collected out of different Worlds; we need not travel, when we see the other Worlds in Epitome at home.</P063>

explanations: The translation uses 'all life' for 'vifs' (lively/quick), a more colloquial and emphatic expression that can enhance accessibility. More significantly, it simplifies the description of Saturn's inhabitants by replacing the specific adjective 'lens' (slow) with the more general term 'quite contrary.' This relies on the established contrast rather than stating a distinct quality, reducing the specific descriptive load.

The French uses a complex negative interrogative structure, 'cela ne viendroit-il point de ce que...' (Wouldn't this come from the fact that...), to gently propose an idea. The English translation simplifies this to a more direct declarative statement, 'it is, I suppose, because...', making the sentence structure less formal and more straightforward, thus improving readability.

The translation simplifies the original French phrase by omitting 'pour les hommes' (for men/mankind). While the meaning is implied by the context, its removal makes the English sentence shorter and more direct, reducing the textual density.

The translation simplifies the scope of the statement by changing 'toutes les especes' (all the kinds/species) to 'the several kinds.' Using 'several' instead of 'all' lessens the absoluteness of the original assertion, making the concept it presents slightly more moderate and potentially easier for the reader to process or accept.

The translation simplifies by replacing the introductory logical connector 'A ce compte' (On that account / By that reckoning) and the general statement of convenience 'il est assez commode d'estre icy' (it is quite convenient to be here) with a more concrete and explicit consequence, 'we need not travel.' Additionally, the impersonal French construction 'on y voit' (one sees there) becomes effectively personalized ('we see,' implied by 'we need not travel'), making the idea more direct and accessible.

chunks.source_manual: <P083>Du moins, reprit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, une commodité fort réelle qu'a nostre Monde par sa situation, c'est qu'il n'est ny si chaud que celuy de Mercure ou de Venus, ny si froid que celuy de Jupiter ou de Saturne. De plus, nous sommes justement dans un endroit de la Terre où nous ne sentons l'excés ny du chaud ni du froid. En verité si un certain Philosophe rendoit grace à la Nature d'estre Homme, & non pas Beste, Grec, & non pas Barbare, moy je veux luy rendre grace d'estre sur la Planete la plus tempérée de l'Univers, & dans un des lieux les plus temperez de cette Planete. Si vous m'en croyez, Madame, répondis-je, vous luy rendrez grace d'estre jeune & non pas vieille; jeune & belle, & non pas jeune & laide; jeune & belle Françoise, & non pas jeune & <UP></UP> belle Italienne. Voila bien d'autres sujets de reconnoissance que ceux que vous tirez de la situation de vostre Tourbillon, ou de la temperature de vostre Pays.</P083>
chunks.target_manual: <P064>I am sure, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, we have one great convenience in the situation of our World; it is not so hot as Mercury or Venus, nor so cold as Jupiter or Saturn; and our Country is so justly plac'd, that we have no excess either of Heat or Cold. I have heard of a Philosopher, who gave thanks to Nature that he was born a Man, and not a Beast, a Greek, and not a Barbarian; and for my part, I render thanks that I am seated in the most temperate Planet of the Universe, and in one of the most temperate Regions of that Planet. You have more reason, said I, to give thanks that you are Young, and not Old; that you are Young and Handsome, and not Young and Ugly; that you are Young, Handsome, and an English Woman, and not Young, Handsome, <UP>and a Spaniard</UP>, or an Italian; these are other guess Subjects for your thanks, than the Situation of your Vortex, or the Temperature of your Countrey.</P064>

Voila bien d'autres sujets de reconnoissance que ceux que vous tirez de la situation de vostre Tourbillon, ou de la temperature de vostre Pays.

explanations: The French "une commodité fort réelle qu'a nostre Monde par sa situation, c'est que..." uses a more formal and slightly complex structure with a relative clause ("qu'a nostre Monde") and the introductory phrase "c'est que". The English translation "we have one great convenience in the situation of our World; it is..." simplifies this into a more direct statement ("we have...") followed by a semicolon and the elaboration, enhancing readability by streamlining the sentence structure. The shift from "fort réelle" (very real) to the more common adjective "great" also contributes to simplification.

The French connective "De plus" (Moreover/Furthermore) is simplified to the more common conjunction "and". The original phrase "nous sommes justement dans un endroit de la Terre où nous ne sentons l'excés..." (we are precisely in a place on Earth where we do not feel the excess...) is restructured. The English "our Country is so justly plac'd, that we have no excess..." uses a more direct subject ("our Country" instead of the general "un endroit de la Terre") and a consecutive clause ("so...that..."). This makes the expression more concrete and employs a common English structure that is arguably simpler to process than the original's existential statement with a relative clause.

The original's introductory "En verité si un certain Philosophe rendoit grace..." (In truth if a certain Philosopher gave thanks...) presents a somewhat abstract or hypothetical framing. The translation simplifies this by omitting "En verité" (In truth) and recasting the philosopher's example as reported information: "I have heard of a Philosopher, who gave thanks...". This makes the reference more concrete and uses a common narrative device. Additionally, the French "d'estre Homme" (of being Man), an infinitive construction, is rendered as "that he was born a Man," making the state of being more explicit and arguably easier to understand.

The French polite and somewhat indirect introductory phrase "Si vous m'en croyez, Madame" (If you believe me / take my word for it, Madam) is simplified to the more direct and assertive statement "You have more reason". This change reduces rhetorical nuance and simplifies the interpersonal dynamic. Furthermore, the main verb phrase shifts from the future tense "vous luy rendrez grace" (you will give her thanks) to an infinitive phrase "to give thanks" governed by "You have more reason", which streamlines the sentence structure.

The French "Voila bien d'autres sujets de reconnoissance que ceux que vous tirez de..." (There are indeed other subjects of gratitude than those which you draw from...) is simplified. The phrase "bien d'autres" (many other/truly other) is rendered as the idiomatic (for the period) "other guess" (of another kind). More significantly, the relative clause construction "que ceux que vous tirez de..." (than those which you draw/derive from...) is simplified to a direct comparison "than the Situation...", omitting the pronoun and verb ("ceux que vous tirez de") and thus reducing syntactic complexity. The somewhat formal "reconnoissance" (gratitude) is also simplified to the more common word "thanks."

chunks.source_manual: <P084>Mon Dieu! repliqua-t-elle, laissez-moy avoir de la reconnaissance sur tout, jusque sur le Tourbillon où je suis placée. La mesure de bonheur qui nous a esté donnée, est assez petite; il n'en faut rien perdre, & il est bon d'avoir pour les choses les plus communes, & les moins considerables, un goust qui les mette à profit. Si on ne vouloit que des plaisirs vifs, on en auroit peu, on les attendroit long-temps, & on les payeroit bien. Vous me promettez donc, repliquay-je, que si on vous proposoit de ces plaisirs vifs, vous vous souviendriez des Tourbillons & de moy, & que vous vous borneriez à nous? Ouy, répondit-elle, mais faites que la Philosophie me fournisse toûjours des plaisirs nouveaux. Du moins pour demain, répondis-je, j'espere qu'ils ne vous manqueront pas. J'ai des Etoiles Fixes qui passent tout ce que vous avez veu jusqu'icy.</P084>
chunks.target_manual: <P065>Pray Sir, says she, let me give thanks for all things, to the very Vortex in which I am planted: Our proportion of Happiness is so very small, that we should lose none, but improve continually what we have, and be grateful for every thing, tho' never so common or inconsiderable. If nothing but exquisite pleasure will serve us, we must wait a long time, and be sure to pay too dear for it at last. I wish, said I, that Philosophy was the pleasure you propose, that when you think of Vortex's, you would not forget an humble Servant of your Ladyships. I esteem it a pleasure, says she, while it diverts innocently, but no longer. I will engage for it till to morrow, I reply'd, for the fix'd Stars are beyond what you have yet seen.</P065>

explanations: The French phrase "avoir de la reconnaissance" (to have gratitude/recognition) is simplified to the more common and direct English phrasal verb "give thanks," using more familiar vocabulary.

The somewhat abstract French "il est bon d'avoir... un goust qui les mette à profit" (it is good to have a taste that turns things to profit/good use) is simplified by translating it into more direct active recommendations: "improve continually what we have, and be grateful for every thing." This makes the structure less formal and the meaning more explicit.

The French sentence lists three consequences of seeking only intense pleasures, including "on en auroit peu" (one would have few of them). The English translation omits this first consequence, simplifying the sentence by reducing its informational density.

The philosopher's complex, multi-clausal conditional question in French, seeking a specific promise, is entirely replaced by a structurally simpler declarative sentence expressing a wish. This substitution simplifies the dialogic exchange by avoiding the intricate request for assurance present in the original.

The Marquise's direct affirmative followed by a demand using the "faites que..." (ensure that...) subjunctive construction is replaced. The English translation substitutes this with a more qualified and structurally simpler declarative statement about her conditions for pleasure, simplifying the force and complexity of her original utterance.

The French expression of hope, "j'espere qu'ils ne vous manqueront pas" (I hope they [new pleasures] will not be lacking for you), is simplified to the more concise and direct assertion "I will engage for it." This reduces periphrasis and nuance for a more straightforward statement of commitment.

The French clause "qui passent tout ce que vous avez veu jusqu'icy" (which surpass all that you have seen until now) uses a verb phrase ("passent tout ce que") to express superiority. This is simplified to the more concise and common prepositional phrase "beyond what you have yet seen," streamlining the sentence structure.

chunks.source_manual: <P085>CINQUIEME SOIR.</P085>
chunks.target_manual: <P066>The Fifth Evening.</P066>

chunks.source_manual: <P086><UP></UP>. La <IIM>Marquise</IIM> sentit une vraye impatience de sçavoir ce que les Etoiles Fixes deviendroient. Seront-elles habitées comme les Planetes, me dit-elle? Ne le seront-elles pas? Enfin qu'en ferons-nous? Vous le devineriez peut-estre, si vous en aviez bien envie, répondis-je. Les Etoiles Fixes ne sçauroient estre moins éloignées de la Terre que de quelques cinquante millions de lieuës, & si vous fâchiez un Astronome, il les mettroit encore plus loin. La distance du Soleil à la Planete la plus éloignée, n'est rien par rapport à la distance du Soleil ou de la Terre aux Etoiles Fixes, & on ne prend pas la peine de la compter. Leur lumiere, comme vous voyez, est assez vive & assez éclatante. Si elles la recevoient du Soleil, il faudroit qu'elles la receussent déja bien foible aprés un trajet de <IIM>cinquante millions de lieuës</IIM> <UP></UP>; il faudroit que par une reflexion qui l'affoibliroit encore beaucoup, elles nous la renvoyassent à cette mesme distance. Il seroit impossible qu'une lumiere qui auroit essuyé une reflexion, & fait deux fois <IIM>cinquante millions de lieuës</IIM>, eust cette force et cette vivacité qu'a celle des Etoiles Fixes. Les voila donc lumineuses par elles-mêmes, & toutes, en un mot, autant de Soleils.</P086>
chunks.target_manual: <P067>THE <IIM>Countess</IIM> was very impatient to know what would become of the fix'd Stars; are they inhabited, says she, as the Planets are, or are they not inhabited? What shall we do with 'em? You may soon guess, said I; the fix'd Stars cannot be less distant from the Earth than fifty millions of leagues; nay, if you anger an Astronomer, he will set 'em further. The distance from the Sun to the farthest Planet, is nothing in comparison of the distance from the Sun, or from the Earth, to the fix'd Stars, it is almost beyond Arithmetick. You see their light is bright and shining, and did they receive it from the Sun, it must needs be very weak after a passage of <NCE>fifty millions of leagues</NCE>; then judge how much it is wasted by reflection; for it comes back again as far to us; so that forwards and backwards, here are <NCE>an hundred millions of leagues</NCE> for it to pass; and it is impossible it should be so clear and strong as the light of a fix'd Star, which cannot but proceed from it self; so that in a word, all the fix'd Stars are so many Suns.</P067>

the fix'd Stars cannot be less distant from the Earth than fifty millions of leagues
it is almost beyond Arithmetick.

explanations: The French "Enfin qu'en ferons-nous?" (Finally, what shall we make of them/do with them?) includes the introductory "Enfin" (Finally/In the end) which lends a slightly more formal, concluding, or pondering tone. The English translation simplifies this by omitting "Enfin" and using the colloquial contraction "'em" for "them," making the question more direct and less formal, thus enhancing readability.

The French "Vous le devineriez peut-estre, si vous en aviez bien envie" (You would perhaps guess it, if you really wanted to/had a strong desire for it) contains a conditional clause ("si vous en aviez bien envie") that adds nuance, suggesting effort or strong inclination is needed. The English "You may soon guess" simplifies this by omitting the entire conditional clause and the idea of "bien envie" (strong desire/effort). This makes the statement more direct and the act of guessing seem easier and more immediate, simplifying the original's subtle implication.

The French "quelques cinquante millions de lieuës" (some/approximately fifty million leagues) uses the word "quelques" to qualify the number, indicating it's an approximation or estimate. The English translation "fifty millions of leagues" omits this qualifier "quelques." This simplification makes the statement more direct and the number appear more exact, reducing the slight nuance of imprecision present in the original and thus the density of the text.

The French "& on ne prend pas la peine de la compter" (and one does not take the trouble/bother to count it) describes an active choice or a common practice of not bothering with the calculation, implying the effort isn't worthwhile. The English "it is almost beyond Arithmetick" rephrases this by making a direct statement about the sheer magnitude of the distance, implying it's nearly incalculable. This simplifies the original by replacing the nuanced description of human action/choice with a more straightforward declaration about the nature of the distance itself, making it more impactful and easier to grasp.

The original French sentence "il faudroit que par une reflexion qui l'affoibliroit encore beaucoup, elles nous la renvoyassent à cette mesme distance" (it would be necessary that by a reflection which would weaken it much more, they send it back to us at this same distance) is a complex hypothetical construction with subjunctive moods ("faudroit que... renvoyassent") and embedded clauses. The English translation simplifies this significantly by transforming the hypothetical statement into a direct imperative to the reader ("then judge...") followed by a simpler explanatory clause ("for it comes back..."). This restructuring breaks down the complex conditional logic into more easily digestible parts, enhancing readability.

The French sentence features a complex syntactical structure: "Il seroit impossible que [a long subordinate clause acting as the subject, detailing the light's journey and weakening by reflection and distance] eust [properties]." The English translation simplifies this by: 1. Extracting and stating the distance traveled more plainly as a separate introductory clause ("so that forwards and backwards, here are an hundred millions of leagues for it to pass;"). 2. Then making a more direct statement of impossibility ("and it is impossible it should be..."). This restructuring breaks the single, dense French clause into more manageable segments. Additionally, the French subjunctive "eust" (had) is rendered as the simpler "should be," and "vivacité" (vivacity, liveliness, brightness) is translated to the more common and arguably less nuanced "clear."

The French "Les voila donc lumineuses par elles-mêmes" (So there they are, luminous by themselves / Thus they are luminous by themselves) is a direct, emphatic, and independent declarative statement concluding that the stars are self-luminous. The English translation renders this conclusion as a relative clause, "which cannot but proceed from it self;", grammatically dependent on the preceding phrase "the light of a fix'd Star". This change from a main declarative statement to a subordinate clause simplifies the rhetorical structure, making the conclusion flow more smoothly as an attribute of the light rather than a standalone pronouncement, thereby softening its declarative force for easier readability.

chunks.source_manual: <P087>Ne me trompay-je point, s'écria la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, ou si je vois où vous me voulez mener? M'allez-vous dire: Les Etoiles Fixes sont autant de Soleils, nostre Soleil est le centre d'un Tourbillon qui tourne autour de luy, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe ne sera-t-elle pas aussi le centre d'un Tourbillon qui aura un mouvement autour d'elle? Nostre Soleil a des Planetes qu'il éclaire, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe n'en aura-t-elle pas aussi qu'elle éclairera? Je n'ay à vous répondre, luy dis-je, que ce que répondit Phedre à Enone, C'est toy qui l'as nommé. <UP></UP>.</P087>
chunks.target_manual: <P068>I perceive, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, where you would carry me; you are going to tell me, that if the fix'd Stars are so many Suns, and our Sun the centre of a Vortex that turns round him, why may not every fix'd Star be the centre of a Vortex that turns round the fix'd Star? Our Sun enlightens the Planets; why may not every fix'd Star have Planets to which they give light? You have said it, <UP>I reply'd, and I will not contradict you</UP>.</P068>
source_segments: Ne me trompay-je point, s'écria la Marquise, ou si je vois où vous me voulez mener?
qui aura un mouvement autour d'elle
pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe n'en aura-t-elle pas aussi qu'elle éclairera?
Je n'ay à vous répondre, luy dis-je, que ce que répondit Phedre à Enone, C'est toy qui l'as nommé..
target_segments: I perceive, says the Countess, where you would carry me;
that turns round the fix'd Star
why may not every fix'd Star have Planets to which they give light?
You have said it, I reply'd, and I will not contradict you.
explanations: The French original uses a more elaborate and somewhat archaic interrogative construction ('Ne me trompay-je point... ou si je vois...') to express the Marquise's dawning realization. The English translation simplifies this to the direct statement 'I perceive...'. Additionally, the expressive verb 's'écria' (exclaimed) is simplified to the more neutral 'says'. This reduces stylistic complexity and makes the utterance more straightforward and accessible.

The French phrase 'qui aura un mouvement autour d'elle' (that will have a movement around it), describing the vortex's motion, is simplified to 'that turns round the fix'd Star.' The English uses a more common and active verb ('turns round') instead of the more abstract periphrastic construction ('aura un mouvement' - will have a movement), making the description more direct and using more common vocabulary.

The French question 'pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe n'en aura-t-elle pas aussi qu'elle éclairera?' (why will each Fixed Star not also have some [planets] that it will illuminate?) is simplified. The translation uses the more common phrase 'give light' instead of a direct cognate of 'éclairera' (will illuminate), changes the future tense to present within the relative clause, makes the object 'Planets' explicit (French 'en' is implicit), and uses a modal 'may not' instead of the future interrogative 'ne ... pas aussi', simplifying vocabulary and grammatical structure.

The French original uses a complex sentence structure featuring a specific literary allusion to Racine's 'Phèdre' ('que ce que répondit Phedre à Enone, C'est toy qui l'as nommé..') to convey agreement. The English translation entirely omits this culturally nuanced and stylistically elevated allusion, replacing it with the direct and simple statement 'You have said it... and I will not contradict you.' This significantly simplifies the text by removing the allusion and its introductory framework, thereby reducing stylistic complexity and cultural richness for greater directness and accessibility.

chunks.source_manual: <P088>Mais, reprit-elle, voila l'Univers si grand que je m'y perds, je ne sçais plus où je suis, <RW>je ne suis plus rien</RW>. Quoy, tout sera divisé en Tourbillons jettez confusément les uns parmi les autres? Chaque Etoile sera le centre d'un Tourbillon peut-estre aussi grand que celuy où nous sommes? Tout cet espace immense qui comprend nostre Soleil & nos Planetes, ne sera qu'une petite parcelle de l'Univers? Autant d'espaces pareils que d'Etoiles Fixes? <UP></UP>. Cela me confond, me trouble, m'épouvante. Et moy, répondis-je, cela me met à mon aise. Quand le Ciel n'estoit que cette voûte bleuë, où les Etoiles estoient cloüées, l'Univers me paroissoit petit & étroit, je m'y sentois comme oppressé; presentement qu'on a donné infiniment plus d'étenduë & de profondeur à cette voûte <UP></UP>, en la partageant en mille & mille <RW>Tourbillons</RW>, il me semble que je respire avec plus de liberté, & que je suis dans un plus grand air, & asseurement l'Univers a toute une autre magnificence. La Nature n'a rien épargné en le produisant, elle a fait une profusion des richesses qui est tout-à-fait digne d'elle. Rien n'est si beau à se representer que ce nombre prodigieux de Tourbillons, dont le milieu est occupé par un Soleil qui fait tourner des Planetes autour de luy. Les Habitans d'une Planete d'un de ces Tourbillons infinis voyent de tous costez les centres lumineux des Tourbuillons dont ils sont environnez, mais ils n'ont garde d'en voir les Planetes qui n'ayant qu'une lumiere foible, empruntée de leur Soleil, ne la poussent point au delà de leur Monde.<UP></UP>.</P088>
chunks.target_manual: <P069>You have made the Universe so large, says she, that I know not where I am, or what will become of me; what is it all to be divided into heaps confusedly, one among another? Is every Star the centre of a Vortex, as big as ours? Is that vast space which comprehends our Sun and Planets, but an inconsiderable part of the Universe? and are there as many such spaces, as there are fix'd Stars? <UP>I protest it is dreadful. Dreadful, Madam, said I</UP>; I think it very pleasant, when the Heavens were a little blue Arch, stuck with Stars; methought the Universe was too strait and close, I was almost stifled for want of Air; but now it is enlarg'd in heigth and breadth, and a thousand and a thousand Vortex's taken in; I begin to breath with more freedom, and think the Universe to be incomparably <UP>more magnificent than it was before</UP>. Nature hath spar'd no cost, even to profuseness, and nothing can be so glorious, as to see such a prodigious number of Vortex's, whose several centres are possess'd by a particular Sun, which makes the Planets turn round it. The Inhabitants of a Planet of one of these innumerable Vortex's, see on all sides these luminous centres of the Vortex, with which they are encompass'd; but perhaps they do not see the Planets, who receiving but a faint light from their Sun, cannot send it beyond their own World.</P069>

explanations: The original French 'je ne suis plus rien' (I am nothing anymore) expresses a profound existential annihilation. The translation 'or what will become of me' shifts this to a concern about future personal outcome, simplifying the philosophical depth and the immediate sense of insignificance into a more common anxiety.

The specific scientific term 'Tourbillons' (Vortices), central to the cosmological theory, is translated as 'heaps.' 'Heaps' is a far more common and vague term, simplifying the vocabulary and reducing the scientific precision of the original concept for easier understanding.

The French includes 'peut-estre' (perhaps), indicating a degree of speculation. The English translation omits this qualifier, rendering the question as a more direct ('Is every Star... as big as ours?'). This simplification removes a nuance of uncertainty from the Marquise's statement, making it more straightforward.

The French original is a highly condensed, elliptical exclamatory question. The English translation expands this into a more complete and conventional sentence structure ('and are there as many such spaces, as there are fix'd Stars?'), simplifying the syntax for greater clarity and easier parsing.

The French text lists three distinct psychological impacts: 'me confond' (confuses me), 'me trouble' (troubles/disturbs me), and 'm'épouvante' (frightens/terrifies me). The English translation simplifies this nuanced emotional cascade into a single, more general exclamation, 'I protest it is dreadful,' reducing the descriptive richness of the Marquise's reaction.

The French 'infiniment plus d'étenduë & de profondeur' (infinitely more extent and depth) is simplified to 'enlarg'd in heigth and breadth,' omitting the crucial intensifier 'infiniment plus.' Additionally, the clear French active construction 'en la partageant' (by dividing it) describing how the vault is modified is rendered more vaguely as 'Vortex's taken in,' simplifying the description of the process by obscuring the specific action and agency.

The descriptive French clause 'elle a fait une profusion des richesses qui est tout-à-fait digne d'elle' (she has made a profusion of riches which is entirely worthy of her) is significantly condensed to the simpler adverbial phrase 'even to profuseness.' This simplification omits the distinct idea that Nature's profusion is 'worthy of her,' losing a layer of philosophical commentary.

The French 'Rien n'est si beau à se representer que...' (Nothing is so beautiful to imagine/picture as...) involves an internal, imaginative act ('à se representer'). The English translation changes this to 'nothing can be so glorious, as to see...', simplifying the experience to a more direct, sensory act of 'seeing' rather than the more complex cognitive act of imagining.

The French 'des Tourbillons' (of the Vortices, plural) indicates that inhabitants are surrounded by, and see the centers of, multiple vortices. The English translation uses 'of the Vortex' (singular generic). This change simplifies the visual complexity by referring to a singular, representative entity rather than explicitly invoking the multiplicity of surrounding vortices.

The French phrase 'ils n'ont garde d'en voir' expresses a strong degree of certainty that they do not see the planets (idiomatically meaning they are far from seeing/it's a certainty they don't). The English translation 'perhaps they do not see' introduces an element of doubt with 'perhaps,' simplifying the original's more assertive, reasoned conclusion into a more tentative statement.

chunks.source_manual: <P089>Vous m'offrez, dit-elle, une espece de Perspective si longue, que la veuë n'en peut attraper le bout. Je voy clairement les Habitans de la Terre, ensuite vous me faites voir ceux de la Lune & des autres Planetes de nostre Tourbillon assez clairement à la verité, mais moins que ceux de la Terre; apres eux viennent les Habitans des Planetes des autres Tourbillons. Je vous avoüe qu'ils sont tout-à-fait dans l'enfoncement, & que quelque effort que je fasse pour les voir, je ne les apperçois presque point. Et en effet ne sont-ils pas presque aneantis par l'expression dont vous estes obligé de vous servir en parlant d'eux? Il faut que vous les appeliez, les Habitans d'une des Planetes, de l'un de ces Tourbillons infinis? <IIM>Nous mesmes, à qui la mesme expression convient, avoüez que vous ne sçauriez presque plus nous déméler au milieu de tant de Mondes</IIM>. Pour moy, je commence à voir la Terre si effroyablement petite, que je ne croy pas avoir desormais d'empressement pour aucune chose. <IIM>Asseurément, si on a tant d'ardeur de s'agrandir, si on fait desseins sur desseins, si on se donne tant de peine, c'est que l'on ne connoist pas les Tourbillons</IIM>. <UP></UP>. Je pretends bien que ma paresse profite de mes nouvelles lumieres, & quand on me reprochera mon indolence, je répondray: Ah! si vous sçaviez ce que c'est que les Etoiles Fixes! Il faut qu'Alexandre ne l'ait pas sceu, repliquay-je, car un certain Auteur qui tient que la Lune est habitée, dit fort serieusement qu'il n'estoit pas possible qu'Aristote ne fust dans une opinion si raisonnable (comment une verité eust-elle échappé à Aristote?) <UP></UP> mais qu'il n'en voulut jamais rien dire, de peur de déplaire, à Alexandre, qui eust esté au despoir de voir un Monde qu'il n'eust pas pû conquerir. A plus forte raison luy eust-on fait mystere des Tourbillons, des Etoiles Fixes, quand on les eust connus en ce temps-là; c'eust esté faire trop mal sa Cour que de luy en parler. Pour moy qui les connois, je suis bien fâché de ne pouvoir tirer d'utilité de la connoissance que j'en ay. Ils ne guerissent tout au plus, selon vostre raisonnement, que de l'ambition & de l'inquietude, & je n'ay point ces maladies-là. Un peu de foiblesse pour ce qui est beau, voila mon mal, & je ne croy pas que les Tourbillons y puissent rien. Les autres Mondes vous rendent celuy-cy petit, mais ils ne vous gâtent point de beaux yeux, ou une belle bouche, cela vaut toûjours son prix en dépit de tous les Mondes possibles.</P089>
chunks.target_manual: <P070>You present me with a kind of Perspective of so vast a length, that no Eye can reach to the end of it: I plainly see the Inhabitants of the Earth, and you have made me discover those that dwell in the Moon, and in other Planets of our Vortex; but these indeed I do not see so clearly as those of the Earth; after these, we come to the Inhabitants of the Planets which are in other Vortex's, but they are sunk into so great a depth, that tho' I do all I can to see them, yet <UP>I must confess</UP> I can hardly perceive 'em; by the expression you use in speaking of 'em, they seem to be almost annihilated; you ought then to call 'em the Inhabitants of one of those innumerable Vortex's: We our selves, for whom the same expression serves, must confess, that we scarce know where we are, in the midst of so many Worlds; for my own part, I begin to see the Earth so fearfully little, that I believe from henceforth, I shall never be concern'd at all for any thing: That we so eagerly desire to make our selves great, that we are always designing, always troubling and harassing our selves, is certainly because we are ignorant what these Vortex's are; but now I hope my new lights will in part justifie my laziness, and when any one reproaches me with my carelessness, I will answer, Ah did you but know what the fix'd Stars are! It was not fit, said I, that Alexander should know what they were; for a certain Author who maintains that the Moon is inhabited, very gravely tells us, that Aristotle, (from whom no truth could be long conceal'd) must necessarily be of an opinion, back'd with so much reason; but yet he would never acquaint Alexander with the secret, fearing he might run mad with despair, when he knew there was another World, which he could not conquer; with much more reason then was this mystery of Vortex's, and fix'd Stars kept secret in Alexander's time; for tho' they had been known in those days, yet a Man would have been a great Fool, to have said any thing of 'em to Alexander; it had been but an ill way of making his court to that ambitious Prince; for my part, I that know 'em, am not a little troubled to find my self not one jot the wiser for all the knowledge I have of 'em; the most they can do, according to your way of reasoning, is but to cure People of their ambition, and their unquiet restless humour, which are diseases I am not at all troubled with; I confess, I am guilty of so much weakness, as to be in love with what is beautiful; that's my distemper, and I am confident, the Vortex's can never cure it: what if the other Worlds render ours so very little? they cannot spoil fine Eyes, or a pretty Mouth; their value is still the same, in spite of all the Worlds that can possibly exist.</P070>

explanations: The French rhetorical question is transformed into a declarative statement in English, simplifying the sentence structure. Additionally, the phrase "dont vous estes obligé de vous servir" (which you are obliged/forced to use) is rendered as the simpler "you use," reducing the formal weight.

The French text uses a rhetorical question, ending with a question mark, to express a realization. The English translation changes this into a direct statement concluding with a colon, simplifying the sentence structure by removing its interrogative and rhetorical nature.

The French "ne sçauriez presque plus nous déméler" (would hardly be able to distinguish us anymore) uses a specific verb implying difficulty in differentiation. The English "we scarce know where we are" simplifies this by substituting the specific action with a more general and common expression of disorientation.

The original French employs the reduplicative phrase "desseins sur desseins" (designs upon designs) for emphasis on continuous scheming. The English translation "that we are always designing" captures the continuity but simplifies the original by removing the stylistic repetition, thereby reducing its rhetorical density.

The French "Je pretends bien que ma paresse profite de" (I fully intend for my laziness to profit from) expresses a strong, somewhat unconventional assertion. The English "I hope my new lights will in part justifie my laziness" simplifies this by softening the assertion to a "hope" and replacing "profit from" with the more conventional idea of "justify," making the Marquise's statement less bold.

The French text includes a direct rhetorical question within parentheses. The English translation simplifies this by converting the interrogative structure into a declarative statement, making the point more straightforwardly.

The French "Il faut qu'Alexandre ne l'ait pas sceu" suggests a logical deduction ("Alexander must not have known"). The English "It was not fit... that Alexander should know" simplifies this by shifting the meaning from logical necessity to a judgment of propriety, which is a less complex notion in this context.

The concise French idiom "c'eust esté faire trop mal sa Cour" (it would have been very poor courtliness/courting him very badly) is simplified by being expanded into two clauses that explicitly state the implied negative consequence ("a Man would have been a great Fool") and the nature of the misstep, making the meaning more direct and less reliant on cultural nuance.

The single French noun "l'inquietude" (anxiety, restlessness) is translated into the more descriptive and arguably more common English phrase "their unquiet restless humour." This expansion breaks down a somewhat abstract concept into more familiar descriptive terms, simplifying by elaboration.

The French "Un peu de foiblesse" (A little weakness) is an understatement. The English translation "I confess, I am guilty of so much weakness, as to be in love with what is beautiful" simplifies by removing this subtlety, making the emotion (being in love) explicit and more direct, rather than relying on the reader's inference from the more reserved original.

chunks.source_manual: <P090>C'est une étrange chose que l'Amour, répondit-elle en riant; il se sauve de tout, & il n'y a point de Systême qui luy puisse faire de mal. Mais aussi parlez-moy franchement, vostre Systême est-il bien vray? Ne me déguisez rien, je vous garderay le secret. Il me semble qu'il n'est appuyé que sur une petite convenance bien legere. Une Etoile Fixe & lumineuse d'elle-mesme comme le Soleil, par consequent il faut qu'elle soit comme le Soleil, le centre & l'ame d'un Monde, & qu'elle ait ses Planetes qui tournent autour d'elle. Cela est-il d'une necessité bien absoluë? Ecoutez, Madame, répondis-je, puis que nous sommes en humeur de mêler toûjours des folies de galanterie à nos Discours les plus serieux, les raisonnemens de Mathematique sont faits comme l'Amour. Vous ne sçauriez accorder si peu de chose à un Amant, que bien-tost aprés il ne faille luy en accorder davantage, & puis encore davantage, & à la fin cela va loin. De mesme accordez à un Mathematicien le moindre principe, il va vous en tirer une consequence, qu'il faudra que vous luy accordiez aussi, & de cette consequence encore une autre, & malgré vous-mesme il vous mene si loin, qu'à peine le pouvez-vous croire. Ces deux sortes de Gens-là prennent toûjours plus qu'on ne leur donne. Vous convenez que quand deux choses sont semblables en tout ce qui me paroist, je les puis croire aussi semblables en ce qui ne me paroist point, s'il n'y a rien d'ailleurs qui m'en empesche. De là j'ay tiré que la Lune estoit habitée, parce qu'elle ressemble à la Terre, les autres Planetes, parce qu'elles ressemblent à la Lune. Je trouve que les Etoiles Fixes ressemblent à nostre Soleil, je leur attribuë tout ce qu'il a. Vous estes engagée trop avant pour pouvoir reculer, il faut franchir le pas de bonne grace. Mais, dit-elle, sur le pied de cette ressemblance que vous mettez entre les Etoiles Fixes & nostre Soleil, il faut que les Gens d'un autre grand Tourbillon ne le voyent que comme une petite Etoile Fixe, qui se montre à eux seulement pendant leurs nuits.</P090> <P091>Cela est hors de doute, répondis-je. Nostre Soleil est si proche de nous en comparaison des Soleils des autres Tourbillons, que sa lumiere doit avoir infiniment plus de force sur nos yeux que la leur. Nous ne voyons donc que luy quand nous le voyons, & il efface tout; mais dans un autre grand Tourbillon c'est un autre Soleil qui y domine, & il efface à son tour le nostre, qui n'y paroist que pendant les nuits avec le reste des autres Soleils étrangers, c'est à dire, des Etoiles Fixes. On l'attache avec elles à cette grande voûte du Ciel, & il y fait partie de quelque Ourse, ou de quelque Taureau. Pour les Planetes qui tournent autour de luy, <NCP>nostre Terre, par exemple</NCP>, comme on ne les voit point de si loin, on n'y songe seulement pas. Ainsi tous les Soleils, sont Soleils de jour pour le Tourbillon où ils sont placez, & Soleils de nuit pour tous les autres Tourbillons. Dans leur Monde, ils sont les uniques de leur espece, par tout ailleurs ils ne servent qu'à faire nombre. Ne faut-il pas pourtant, reprit-elle, que les Mondes, malgré cette égalité different en mille choses, car un fond de ressemblance ne laisse de porter des differences infinies?</P091>
chunks.target_manual: <P071>This Love, reply'd the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, smiling, is a strange thing; let the World go how 'twill, 'tis never in danger; there is no System can do it any harm. But tell me freely, is your System true? Pray conceal nothing from me; I will keep your secret very faithfully; it seems to have for its foundation, but a slight probability; which is, that if a fix'd Star be in it self a luminous Body, like the Sun, then by consequence, it must as the Sun is, be the Centre and Soul of a World; and have its Planets turning round about it: But is there an absolute necessity it must be so? Madam, said I, since we are in the humour of mingling amorous Follies with our most serious Discourses, I must tell you, that in Love and the Mathematicks People reason alike: Allow never so little to a Lover, yet presently after you must grant him more; nay more and more, which will at last go a great way: In like manner, grant but a Mathematician one little Principle, he immediately draws a consequence from it, to which you must necessarily assent; and from this consequence another, till he leads you so far (whether you will or no) that you have much ado to believe him. These two sorts of People, Lovers and Mathematicians, will always take more than you give 'em. You grant that when two things are like one another in all those things that appear to you, it is possible they may be like one another in those things that are not visible, if you have not some good reason to believe otherwise: Now this way of arguing have I made use of. The Moon, say I, is inhabited, because she is like the Earth; and the other Planets are inhabited, because they are like the Moon; I find the fix'd Stars to be like our Sun, therefore I attribute to them what is proper to that: You are now gone too far to be able to retreat, therefore you must go forward with a good grace. But, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, if you build upon this resemblance or likeness which is between our Sun and the fix'd Stars, then, to the People of another great Vortex, our Sun must appear no bigger than a small fix'd Star, and can be seen only when 'tis Night with them. <UP>Without doubt</UP>, Madam, said I, it must be so: Our Sun is much nearer to us, than the Suns of other Vortex's, and therefore its Light makes a much greater impression on our Eyes, than theirs do: We see nothing but the light of our own Sun, and when we see that, it darkens and hinders us from seeing any other light: but in another great Vortex, there is another Sun, which rules and governs, and, in its turn, extinguisheth the light of our Sun, which is never seen there, but in the Night, with the rest of the other Suns, that is the fix'd Stars; with them our Sun is fastned to the great arched roof of Heaven, where it makes a part of some Bear or Bull: For the Planets which turn round about it, <NCP>(our Earth for Example)</NCP> as they are not seen at so vast a distance, so no body doth so much as dream of 'em: All the Suns then are Day Suns in their own Vortex's, but Night Suns in other Vortex's: In his own World or Sphere every Sun is single, and there is but one to be seen; but every where else, they serve only to make a number. May not the Worlds, reply'd the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, notwithstanding this great resemblance between 'em, differ in a thousand other things; for tho' they may be alike in one particular, they may differ infinitely in others.</P071>

explanations: The French presents a declarative chain of logic as an apposition. The English translation restructures this into an explicit "if...then" conditional statement, simplifying the cognitive load by making the logical structure more patent and easier to follow.

The French "sont faits comme" (are made like/work like) is an abstract statement about the nature of mathematical arguments. The English simplifies this by making it more concrete and relatable to human action: "People reason alike," specifying *who* performs the action.

The translation simplifies the complex French modal and negative construction ("ne sçauriez... que ne faille") into a more direct imperative followed by a consequence ("Allow... yet... you must grant"), enhancing readability by simplifying sentence structure.

The French "qu'il faudra que vous luy accordiez aussi" (that it will be necessary that you grant him also) uses an impersonal construction ("il faudra que") with a subjunctive. The English simplifies this to a more direct modal verb construction: "to which you must necessarily assent."

The impersonal French pronoun "on" (one) in "qu'on ne leur donne" (than one gives them) is replaced by the more direct and personal "you" in "than you give 'em," simplifying the sentence by making the agent explicit and direct.

The French "s'il n'y a rien d'ailleurs qui m'en empesche" (if there is nothing otherwise that prevents me from it) is abstract. The English translation simplifies this by making the condition more concrete and specific: "if you have not some good reason to believe otherwise," which is easier to grasp.

The translation simplifies the French impersonal "il faut" (one must) to the personal "you must". It also replaces the idiomatic "franchir le pas" (take the step/plunge) with the more literal "go forward," using more common vocabulary and making the logical connection explicit with "therefore."

The translation simplifies "infiniment plus de force" (infinitely more force) to the less intense "much greater impression." "Infiniment" (infinitely) is reduced to "much," and "force" (a potentially more abstract or scientific term for light's impact) is replaced by "impression" (a more common term for light's effect on the eyes), using more common vocabulary and reducing intensity.

The concise and somewhat metaphorical French "il efface tout" (it erases/blots out everything) is simplified by expansion into a more descriptive and literal explanation of the effect: "it darkens and hinders us from seeing any other light," reducing textual density for enhanced clarity.

The single strong French verb "domine" (dominates) is simplified by being unpacked into the phrase "rules and governs." This explicitation uses more common verbs to clarify the scope and meaning of "domine."

The French uses the impersonal pronoun "On" ("On l'attache" - One attaches it). The English translation simplifies this by using a passive construction with a specific subject: "our Sun is fastned," making the agent implicit but the subject clear, thus removing the indefinite "On."

The French uses the impersonal pronoun "on" twice ("on ne les voit point," "on n'y songe seulement pas"). The English simplifies these by replacing them with a passive construction ("they are not seen") and a specific subject ("no body"), making the phrasing more direct.

The concise French phrase "ils sont les uniques de leur espece" (they are the only ones of their kind) is simplified by being expanded and restructured into "every Sun is single, and there is but one to be seen." This explicitation breaks down the meaning, reducing density and making it more readily understandable.

The abstract and dense French philosophical phrase "un fond de ressemblance ne laisse de porter des differences infinies?" (a basis of resemblance nevertheless carries infinite differences?) is significantly simplified. The translation uses a more concrete conditional structure ("tho' they may be alike...") and more common vocabulary, replacing the abstract noun phrase and complex verb form with a clearer, more accessible phrasing.

chunks.source_manual: <P092>Assurément, repris-je, mais la difficulté est de deviner. Que sçay-je? Un Tourbillon a plus de Planetes qui tournent autour de son Soleil, un autre en a moins. Dans l'un il y a des Planetes subalternes, qui tournent autour des Planetes plus grandes; dans l'autre il n'y en a point. Icy elles sont toutes ramassées autour de leur Soleil <UP></UP>, & font comme un petit peloton, au-delà duquel s'étend un grand espace vuide, qui va jusqu'aux Tourbillons voisins; ailleurs elles prennent leur cours vers les extremitez du Tourbillon & laissent le milieu vuide. Je ne doute pas mesme qu'il ne puisse y avoir quelques Tourbillons deserts, & sans Planetes, d'autres dont le Soleil, n'estant pas justement au centre, ait un veritable mouvement, & emporte ses Planetes avec soy; d'autres dont les Planetes s'élèvent ou s'abaissent à l'égard de leur Soleil par le changement de l'équilibre qui les tient suspenduës. Enfin, que voudriez-vous? En voila bien assez pour un homme qui n'est jamais sorty de son Tourbillon.</P092>
chunks.target_manual: <P072>It is certainly true, said I; but the difficulty is to know wherein they differ. One Vortex hath many Planets that turn round about its Sun; another Vortex hath but a few: In one Vortex, there are inferiour or less Planets, which turn about those that are greater; in another perhaps, there are no inferiour Planets; here, all the Planets are got round about their Sun, <UP>in form of a little Squadron</UP>; beyond which, is a great void space, which reacheth to the neighbouring Vortex's: In another place, the Planets take their course towards the out side of their Vortex, and leave the middle void. There may be Vortex's also quite void, without any Planets at all; others may have their Sun not exactly in their Centre; and that Sun may so move, as to carry its Planets along with it: others may have Planets which in regard of their Sun, ascend and descend, according to the change of their Equilibration, which keeps them suspended. But I think I have said enough for a Man that was never out of his own Vortex.</P072>

explanations: The concise French 'de deviner' (to guess/surmise), which refers to discerning the unknown differences between vortices, is expanded in English to 'to know wherein they differ.' This explicitation clarifies the implied object of 'deviner,' making the philosopher's intended meaning more immediately accessible and reducing the reader's inferential effort, thereby simplifying comprehension.

The French rhetorical question 'Que sçay-je?' (What do I know?), which adds a layer of philosophical modesty and conversational style, is entirely omitted in the English translation. This simplifies the text by making the transition to the list of speculations more direct and reducing textual density, at the cost of this stylistic nuance.

The French term 'Planetes subalternes' (subordinate planets) is translated using the doublet 'inferiour or less Planets.' This simplifies the vocabulary by providing a more common English term ('less') alongside a cognate ('inferiour'), ensuring comprehension for readers who might be unfamiliar with the potentially more obscure 'subalternes.'

The French 'les extremitez' (the extremities/outer edges) is simplified to the more common and concrete English phrase 'the out side.' This lexical choice uses more frequent vocabulary to make the spatial description more readily understandable.

The French phrase 'Je ne doute pas mesme qu'il ne puisse y avoir...' (I don't even doubt that there may be...) is an emphatic construction with a negating element common in such French structures. The English 'There may be...' drastically simplifies this by removing the speaker's explicit conviction ('Je ne doute pas mesme') and using a more direct, less syntactically complex existential construction. This makes the statement more straightforward but less emphatic and personal.

The concluding French sentence, which includes the transitional 'Enfin,' an engaging rhetorical question 'que voudriez-vous?', and the idiomatic 'En voila bien assez,' is simplified in the English translation. The rhetorical question 'que voudriez-vous?' (What more could you want?) is omitted, reducing stylistic complexity and interaction. 'Enfin' (Finally/In short) is functionally replaced by 'But,' altering the transitional nuance. The assertive French idiom 'En voila bien assez' (That's quite enough) is rendered as the more common, subjective, and softer English phrase 'I think I have said enough.' Overall, this simplifies the structure and tone, making the conclusion more direct but less stylistically rich and nuanced.

chunks.source_manual: <P093>Ce n'en est guere, répondit-elle, pour la quantité des Mondes. Ce que vous dites ne suffit que pour cinq ou six, & j'en voy d'icy des milliers?</P093>
chunks.target_manual: <P073>It is not so much, reply'd the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, considering what a multitude of Worlds there are; what you have said is sufficient but for five or six, and <UP>from hence I see thousands</UP>.</P073>

target_segments: considering what a multitude of Worlds there are
explanations: The concise French prepositional phrase "pour la quantité des Mondes," which implies a reason or context linked to the preceding statement, is translated into a more explicit and elaborate participial clause "considering what a multitude of Worlds there are." This expansion clarifies the logical relationship and reduces the density of the original phrase by making the implicit connection explicit, thereby enhancing readability.

chunks.source_manual: <P094>Que serait-ce donc, repris-je, si je vous disois qu'il y a bien d'autres Etoiles Fixes, que celles que vous voyez; qu'avec des Lunettes on en découvre un nombre infiny qui ne se montrent point aux yeux, & que dans une seule Constellation, où l'on en comptoit peut-estre douze ou quinze <RW></RW>, il s'en trouve autant que l'on en voyoit <UP></UP> auparavant dans tout le Ciel?</P094>
chunks.target_manual: <P074>What, Madam, would you say, if I should tell you, there are many more fix'd Stars than those you see? and that an infinite number are discover'd with Glasses, which never shew'd themselves to our Eyes: In only one Constellation, where it may be, we count twelve or fifteen, there are as many to be found as usually appear in the whole Hemisphere.</P074>

que l'on en voyoit auparavant dans tout le Ciel
target_segments: where it may be, we count twelve or fifteen

explanations: The French imperfect tense 'l'on en comptoit' (one counted / one used to count) describes a past or customary situation regarding the number of stars counted in a constellation. The English translation 'we count' uses the simple present tense, simplifying the temporal context by presenting the counting as a current or general fact rather than specifically a past practice or baseline. This makes the statement more direct but reduces the nuance of a previously held understanding.

The French phrase 'que l'on en voyoit auparavant dans tout le Ciel' (that one previously saw in the whole sky) establishes a comparison based on past observational limits, with 'auparavant' (previously) highlighting the contrast with new telescopic discoveries. The English translation 'as usually appear in the whole Hemisphere' simplifies this by replacing the specific past temporal marker and past descriptive tense ('voyoit' - saw) with a general present observation ('usually appear'). This generalization simplifies the comparison and diminishes the emphasis on the historical progression of astronomical knowledge that Fontenelle is illustrating.

chunks.source_manual: <P095>Je vous demande grace, s'écria-t-elle, je me rends, vous m'accablez de Mondes & de Tourbillons. Je sçay bien, ajoûtay-je, ce que je vous garde ancore. Vous voyez cette blancheur qu'on appelle la Voye de Lait. Vous figureriez-vous bien ce que c'est? Une infinité de petites Etoiles invisibles aux yeux à cause de leur petitesse, & semées si prés les unes des autres qu'elles paroissent former une blancheur continuë. Je voudrois que vous vissiez avec des Lunettes cette Fourmilliere d'Astres, & cette graine de Mondes (si ces expressions sont permises.) Ils ressemblent en quelque sorte aux Isles Maldives, à ces douze mille petites Isles ou Bancs de Sable, separez seulement par des Canaux de Mer, que l'on sauteroit presque comme des Fossez. Ainsi les petits Tourbillons de la Voye de Lait sont si serrez, qu'il me semble que d'un Monde à l'autre on pourroit se parler, ou mesme se donner la main. Du moins je croy que les Oyseaux d'un Monde passent aisément dans un autre, & que l'on y peut dresser des Pigeons à porter des Lettres comme on fait icy dans le Levant. Ces petits Mondes sortent apparemment de la regle generale, par laquelle un Soleil dans son Tourbillon efface dés qu'il paroist tous les Soleils étrangers. Si vous estes dans un des petits Tourbillons de la Voye de Lait, vostre Soleil n'est presque pas plus proche de vous, & par consequent n'a pas sensiblement plus de force sur vos yeux, que cent mille autres Soleils des Tourbillons voisins. Vous voyez donc vostre Ciel briller d'un nombre infiny de feux, qui sont fort proches les uns des autres, & peu éloignez de vous. Lors que vous perdez de veuë vostre Soleil particulier, il vous en reste encore assez, & vostre nuit n'est pas moins éclairée que le jour, du moins la diference ne peut pas estre sensible, & pour parler plus juste, vous n'avez jamais de nuit. Ils seroient bien étonnez, les Gens de ces Mondes-là, accoûtumez comme ils sont à une clarté perpetuelle, si on leur disoit qu'il y a des malheureux qui ont de veritables nuits, qui tombent dans des tenebres tres-profondes, & qui quand ils joüissent de la lumiere, ne voyent mesme qu'un seul Soleil. Ils nous regarderoient comme des Estres disgraciez de la Nature, & fremiroient de l'horreur de nostre condition.</P095>
chunks.target_manual: <P075>I submit, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, and beg your pardon: You quite confound me with Worlds and Vortex's. I have yet more to tell you, Madam, said I: You see that whiteness in the Sky, which some call the milky way; Can you imagine what that is? 'Tis nothing but an infinity of small Stars, not to be seen by our Eyes, because they are so very little; and they are sown so thick, one by another, that they seem to be one cotinu'd whiteness: I wish you had a Glass, to see this Ant-hill of Stars, and this Cluster of Worlds, if I may so call 'em: They are in some sort, like the Maldivian Islands: those twelve thousand banks of Sand, separated by narrow Channels of the Sea, which a Man may leap as easily, as over a Ditch: So near together are the Vortex's of the Milky way, that the People in one World, may talk, and shake Hands with those of another; at least I believe, the Birds of one World, may easily fly into another; and that Pigeons may be train'd up to carry Letters, as they do in the Levant. These little Worlds are excepted out of that general Rule, by which one Sun in his own Vortex, as soon as he appears, effaceth the light of all other forreign Suns: If you were in one of these little Vortex's of the Milky way, your Sun would not be much nearer to you, and consequently, would not make any much greater sensible impression on your Eyes, than a hundred thousand other Suns of the neighbouring Vortex's: You would then see your Heaven shine bright with an infinite number of Fires, close to one another, and but a little distant from you; so that tho' you should lose the light of your own particular Sun, yet there would still remain visible Suns enough beside your own, to make your Night as light as Day, at least, the difference would hardly be perceiv'd, for the truth is, you would never have any Night at all: The Inhabitants of these Worlds accustom'd to perpetual Brightness, would be strangely astonish'd, if they should be told that there are a miserable sort of People, who where they live, have very dark Nights, and when 'tis Day with them, they never see more than one Sun; certainly they would think Nature had very little kindness for us, and would tremble with horrour, to think what a sad condition we are in.</P075>
