explanations: The French "s'écria-t-elle" (she cried out/exclaimed), indicating strong emotion, is translated to the more neutral "says the Countess," simplifying the dramatic tone of the Marquise's reaction. The phrase "Je vous demande grace" (I ask for mercy/grace) is rendered as the common "beg your pardon", which, while polite, might reduce some of the original's dramatic plea.

The strong French verb "m'accablez" (you overwhelm me/crush me/burden me) is translated to "You quite confound me." While "confound" can imply being overwhelmed, its more common meaning of "confuse" or "perplex" lessens the intensity of the original verb, simplifying the emotional impact expressed.

The French phrase "ce que je vous garde ancore" (literally "what I still keep for you" or "what I still have in store for you"), which carries a nuance of something being held back or a surprise, is simplified to the more direct and common statement "I have yet more to tell you." This makes the speaker's intention more straightforward.

The French conditional and reflexive form "Vous figureriez-vous bien ce que c'est?" (Would you indeed imagine/picture to yourself what it is?) is simplified to the more direct interrogative "Can you imagine what that is?". The emphatic adverb "bien" (well, indeed, really) is also omitted, reducing a layer of nuance for simpler comprehension.

The French phrase "qu'elles paroissent former une blancheur continuë" (that they appear to form a continuous whiteness) is simplified to "that they seem to be one cotinu'd whiteness:". This replaces a more descriptive verb phrase ("paraître former" - to appear to form) with a simpler verb of being ("seem to be"), slightly reducing the precision of the action of "forming."

The formal, impersonal passive construction "(si ces expressions sont permises.)" (if these expressions are permitted/allowable) is simplified to the more direct, personal, and conversational active phrase "if I may so call 'em:".

The original French "à ces douze mille petites Isles ou Bancs de Sable" (to these twelve thousand little Islands or Sand Banks) provides two alternative descriptions. The translation simplifies this by omitting "petites Isles ou" (little islands or), rendering it as "those twelve thousand banks of Sand." This reduces descriptive detail and removes the alternative offered in the source.

The French conditional "l'on sauteroit" (one would jump) combined with "presque" (almost) in "que l'on sauteroit presque comme des Fossez" (that one would almost jump like ditches) is simplified to the more direct statement of possibility "which a Man may leap as easily, as over a Ditch:". This changes the mood from a more nuanced hypothetical to a more straightforward assertion of potential ease.

The qualifying phrase "il me semble que" (it seems to me that) is omitted in the translation of "qu'il me semble que d'un Monde à l'autre on pourroit se parler...". This removes the explicitly subjective framing by the speaker (the philosopher), making the subsequent speculation ("that the People in one World, may talk...") appear more direct or factual, simplifying by removing a layer of personal conjecture. The impersonal "on pourroit" (one could) is also made more concrete as "the People... may".

The concise French phrase "il vous en reste encore assez" (literally "there still remains enough of them for you") is expanded in the translation to "yet there would still remain visible Suns enough beside your own." This explicitation of what "en" (of them) refers to (by specifying "visible Suns") and the addition of "beside your own" makes the meaning clearer and more readily accessible, reducing the inferential load on the reader.

The French negative comparison "vostre nuit n'est pas moins éclairée que le jour" (your night is not less lit than the day) is simplified to the more direct positive comparison "to make your Night as light as Day." This enhances readability by avoiding the mental step of processing the double negative implication.

The French phrase "& pour parler plus juste" (and to speak more precisely/correctly), which implies a self-correction or refinement of speech by the speaker, is translated to the more common and slightly less formal English idiom "for the truth is." This simplifies the metalinguistic comment into a more conventional discourse marker for emphasis.

The translation simplifies the description of the "malheureux" (unfortunates). The French "des malheureux qui ont de veritables nuits" (unfortunates who have true/real nights) is altered to "a miserable sort of People, who where they live, have very dark Nights." This changes "veritables" (true/real), which emphasizes authenticity, to "very dark," focusing on quality and using more common descriptive terms. Crucially, the subsequent vivid French clause "qui tombent dans des tenebres tres-profondes" (who fall into very deep darknesses) is omitted entirely. This significantly reduces the richness and intensity of the original passage and simplifies the sentence structure by removing a descriptive element.

The formal and conceptually rich French phrase "Ils nous regarderoient comme des Estres disgraciez de la Nature" (They would regard us as Beings disgraced by Nature), which carries a strong sense of disfavor, curse, or being outcast by natural order, is simplified to "certainly they would think Nature had very little kindness for us." The latter is a more common, less intense, and more easily understood expression. The verb "regarderoient comme" (would regard as) is also simplified to "would think."

The concise French "& fremiroient de l'horreur de nostre condition." (and would shudder/tremble with the horror of our condition.) is expanded to "and would tremble with horrour, to think what a sad condition we are in.". The addition of the explicative clause "to think what a sad condition we are in" clarifies the cause of the horror, simplifying the statement by reducing the reader's inferential work to understand the full implication of "l'horreur de nostre condition."

chunks.source_manual: <P096>Je ne vous demande pas, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, s'il y a des Lunes dans les Mondes de la Voye de Lait; je voy bien qu'elles n'y seroient de nul usage aux Planetes principales qui n'ont point de nuit, & qui d'ailleurs marchent dans des espaces trop étroits pour s'embarrasser de cet attirail de Planetes subalternes. Mais sçavez-vous bien qu'à force de me multiplier les Mondes si liberalement, vous me faites naistre une veritable difficulté? Les Tourbillons dont nous voyons les Soleils, touchent le Tourbillon où nous sommes. Les Tourbillons sont ronds, n'est-il pas vray? Et comment tant de Boules en peuvent-elles toucher une seule? Je veux m'imaginer cela, & je sens bien que je ne le puis.</P096>
chunks.target_manual: <P076>I do not ask you, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, whether in those Worlds of the Milkyway, there be any Moons; I see they would be of no use to those principal Planets which have no Night, and move in spaces too strait and narrow to cumber themselves with the baggage of inferiour Planets: Yet pray take notice, that by your liberal multiplication of Worlds, you have started an objection, not easily answer'd: The Vortex's whose Suns we see, touch the Vortex in which we are, and if it be true, that Vortex's are round, how then can so many Bowls or Globes all touch one single one? I would fain imagine how this may be done, but cannot think which way.</P076>
source_segments: Mais sçavez-vous bien qu'à force de me multiplier les Mondes si liberalement, vous me faites naistre une veritable difficulté?
Les Tourbillons sont ronds, n'est-il pas vray?
Je veux m'imaginer cela, & je sens bien que je ne le puis.
target_segments: Yet pray take notice, that by your liberal multiplication of Worlds, you have started an objection, not easily answer'd:
and if it be true, that Vortex's are round,
I would fain imagine how this may be done, but cannot think which way.
explanations: The original French uses a rhetorical question ('sçavez-vous bien que...') and a more figurative phrase ('vous me faites naistre une veritable difficulté' - you make a real difficulty be born for me). The translation changes this to a more direct imperative ('Yet pray take notice, that...') followed by a more prosaic statement ('you have started an objection, not easily answer'd:'). This simplifies the sentence structure from interrogative to declarative/imperative and uses less literary, more common vocabulary ('started an objection' for the figurative 'faites naistre une difficulté').

The original French presents an assertion 'Les Tourbillons sont ronds' (Vortices are round) followed by a tag question 'n'est-il pas vray?' (isn't it true?), indicating the speaker's assumption and seeking confirmation. The English translation changes this to a conditional clause 'and if it be true, that Vortex's are round,' which frames the roundness as a premise for the following difficulty. This simplifies the communicative act by transforming a statement seeking agreement into a more straightforward hypothetical condition, streamlining the introduction to her problem.

The original French 'Je veux m'imaginer cela, & je sens bien que je ne le puis.' uses abstract pronouns ('cela', 'le') and an emphatic phrase ('je sens bien que'). The translation 'I would fain imagine how this may be done, but cannot think which way.' simplifies this by explicating the pronouns (e.g., 'cela' becomes 'how this may be done') and reducing the emphatic 'je sens bien que' (I feel strongly that / I am well aware that) to a simple 'but'. This enhances clarity and directness by reducing abstraction and simplifying the expression of conviction.

chunks.source_manual: <P097>Il y a beaucoup d'esprit, répondis-je, à avoir cette difficulté-là, & mesme à ne la pouvoir résoudre; car elle est tres-bonne en soy, & de la maniere dont vous la concevez, elle est sans réponse, & c'est avoir bien peu d'esprit que de trouver des réponses à ce qui n'en a point. Si nostre Tourbillon estoit de la figure d'un Dé, il auroit six faces plates, & seroit bien éloigné d'estre rond, mais sur chacune de ces faces on y pourroit mettre un Tourbillon de la mesme figure. Si au lieu de six faces plates, il en avoit vingt, cinquante, mille, il y auroit jusqu'à mille Tourbillons qui pourroient poser sur luy, chacun sur une face, & vous concevez bien que plus un corps a de faces plates qui le terminent au dehors, plus il <IIM>approche d'estre rond</IIM>, en sorte qu'un Diamant taillé à facetes de tous costez, si les facetes estoient fort petites, seroit quasi aussi rond qu'une Perle de mesme grandeur. Les Tourbillons ne sont ronds que de cette maniere-là. Ils ont une infinité de faces en dehors, chacune des quelles porte un autre Tourbillon. Ces faces sont fort inégales; icy elles sont plus grandes, là plus petites. Les plus petites de nostre Tourbillon, par exemple, répondent à la Voye de Lait, & soutiennent tous ces petits Mondes. Que deux Tourbillons qui sont appuyez sur deux faces voisines, laissent quelque vuide entre eux par en bas, comme cela doit arriver tres-souvent, aussi-tost la Nature <UP></UP> qui ménage bien le terrain, vous remplit ce vuide par un petit Tourbillon ou deux, peut-estre par mille, qui n'incommodent point les autres, & ne laissent pas d'estre un ou deux, ou mille Mondes de plus. Ainsi nous pouvons voir beaucoup plus de Mondes que nostre Tourbillon n'a de faces pour en porter <UP></UP>. Je gagerois que quoy que ces petits Mondes n'ayent esté faits que pour estre jettez dans des coins de l'Univers qui fussent demeurez inutiles, quoy qu'ils soient inconnus aux autres Mondes qui les touchent, ils ne laissent pas d'estre fort contents d'eux-mesmes <UP></UP>. Ce sont ceux sans doute dont on ne découvre les petits Soleils qu'avec des Lunettes d'approche, & qui sont en une quantité si prodigieuse. Enfin tous ces Tourbillons s'ajustent les uns avec les autres le mieux qu'il est possible, & comme il faut que chacun tourne autour de son Soleil sans changer de place, chacun prend la maniere de tourner, qui est la plus commode & la plus aisée dans la situation où il est. Ils s'engrainent en quelque façon les uns dans les autres comme les rouës d'une Montre, & aident mutuellement leurs mouvemens. Il est pourtant vray qu'ils agissent aussi les uns contre les autres. Chaque Monde, à ce qu'on dit, est comme un <IIM>Ballon</IIM> <UP></UP> qui s'enfle de soy-mesme, & qui s'étendroit, si on le laissoit faire, mais il est aussi-tost repoussé par les Mondes voisins, & il rentre en luy-mesme, aprés quoy il recommence à s'enfler, & ainsi de suite <UP></UP>; & on pretend que les Etoiles Fixes ne nous envoyent cette lumiere tremblante, & ne paroissent briller à reprises, que parce que leurs Tourbillons poussent perpetuellement le nostre, & en sont perpetuellement repoussez.</P097>
chunks.target_manual: <P077>You shew a great deal of Wit, Madam, said I, in raising this doubt, and likewise in not being able to resolve it; for in it self the thing is extreme difficult, and in the manner you conceive it, no answer can be given to it; and he must be a Fool who goes about to find Answers to Objections which are unanswerable. If our Vortex had the form of a Die, it would have six squares or flat faces, and would be far from being round, and upon every of these Squares, might be plac'd a Vortex of the same Figure, but if in stead of these six Square faces, it had twenty, fifty, or a thousand; then might a thousand Vortex's be plac'd upon it, one upon every flat; and you know very well, that the more flat faces any body hath on its outside, <UP>the nearer it approacheth to roundness</UP>, just as a Diamond cut facet-wise on every side, if the facets be very many and little, it will look as round as a Pearl of the same bigness: 'Tis in this manner that the Vortex's are round; they have an infinite number of facets on their outside, and every one of 'em hath upon it another Vortex; these faces are not all equal and alike; but here, some are greater, and there, some less; The least facets of our Vortex, for Example, answer to the Milky way, and sustain all those little Worlds. When two Vortex's are supported by the two next flats on which they stand, if they leave beneath any void space between them, as it must often happen, Nature, <UP>who is an excellent</UP> Huswife, and suffers nothing to be useless, presently fills up this void space with a little Vortex or two, perhaps with a thousand, which never in commode the others, and become one, two, or a thousand Worlds more; so that there may be many more Worlds than our Vortex hath flat faces to bear 'em: <UP>I will lay a good wager</UP>, that tho' these little Worlds were made only to be thrown into the corners of the Universe, which otherwise would have been void and useless; and tho' they are unknown to other Worlds which they touch, yet they are well satisfy'd with their being where they are: These are the little Worlds, whose Suns are not to be discover'd but with a Tellescope, and whose number is prodigious: to conclude, all these Vortex's are joyn'd to one another in so admirable a manner, that every one turns round about his Sun, without changing place; every one hath such a turn as is most easie, and agreeable to its own situation: they take hold of one another, like the wheels of a Watch, and mutually help one anothers motion: And yet 'tis true, that they act contrary to one another. Every World, as some say, is like a Foot-ball, <UP>made of a Bladder </UP>, cover'd with Leather, which sometimes swells of its own accord, and would extend it self, if it were not hindred. But this swelling World being press'd by the next to it, returns to its first Figure; then swells again, and is again deprest; and some affirm that the reason why the fix'd Stars give a twinkling and trembling light, and sometimes seem not to shine at all, is because their Vortex's perpetually push and press our Vortex, and ours again continually repulseth theirs.</P077>

explanations: The French "avoir bien peu d'esprit" (to have very little wit/sense) is rendered with the more common and blunt English word "Fool." Additionally, the concise pronominal phrase "à ce qui n'en a point" (to that which has no [answers]) is explicated as "to Objections which are unanswerable," making the meaning more direct and simplifying the anaphoric reference.

The French relative clause "qui le terminent au dehors" (that terminate it on the outside), modifying "faces plates," is simplified to the more direct prepositional phrase "on its outside." Furthermore, the qualifier "quasi" (almost) is omitted from "seroit quasi aussi rond" (would be almost as round), making the English "it will look as round" a more absolute and slightly simplified comparison.

The concise and somewhat abstract French phrase "ménage bien le terrain" (manages the space/ground well) is expanded into the more concrete and culturally familiar image of "an excellent Huswife, and suffers nothing to be useless." This simplifies the original's metaphor by making it more explicit and relatable. The ethical dative "vous" is also omitted, simplifying the sentence by making it more generally descriptive.

The French verbal construction "ne laissent pas d'estre" (literally "do not leave off being," meaning "nevertheless are" or "still are"), which is somewhat formal, is simplified to the more direct and common verb "become."

The French "Ainsi nous pouvons voir" (Thus we can see/understand/conceive) implies a human deduction or understanding. The English translation "so that there may be" simplifies this by shifting to a statement about the possibility of existence, making the sentence more direct about the state of affairs rather than the process of perceiving or concluding it.

The concise French "qui fussent demeurez inutiles" (which would have remained useless) is expanded to "which otherwise would have been void and useless." The addition of "otherwise" clarifies the conditional nature, and "void and" adds emphasis and explicitness to "useless," simplifying by reducing the reader's inferential load.

The French phrase "ne laissent pas d'estre" (nevertheless are) is simplified to the more common verb "are." Concurrently, "fort contents d'eux-mesmes" (very content with themselves) is rendered as "well satisfy'd with their being where they are," which slightly expands and explicates the source of their contentment for enhanced clarity.

The French "Ce sont ceux sans doute" (These are those, undoubtedly) is simplified by omitting the modal adverb "sans doute" (undoubtedly), making the statement more direct. "Ceux" (those) is also explicated as "the little Worlds" for clarity. Furthermore, the phrase "qui sont en une quantité si prodigieuse" (which are in such a prodigious quantity) is restructured to the more concise and common English phrasing "whose number is prodigious."

The French active reflexive verb "s'ajustent" (adjust themselves/fit together) combined with "le mieux qu'il est possible" (the best way possible) is rendered as the simpler passive construction "are joyn'd" qualified by "in so admirable a manner." The complex clause structure "comme il faut que chacun tourne... chacun prend la maniere de tourner, qui est..." (as it is necessary that each turns... each takes the way of turning that is...) is simplified; the explicit "il faut que" (it is necessary) is absorbed, and "prend la maniere de tourner qui est" becomes the more direct "hath such a turn as is...".

The specific French verb "s'engrainer" (to mesh or interlock, like gears) is translated using the more general and common English phrasal verb "they take hold of one another." This simplifies the vocabulary by opting for a less specialized term. The qualifying phrase "en quelque façon" (in some way/manner) is also omitted, making the statement more direct.

The French phrase "il rentre en luy-mesme" (it re-enters into itself, or it contracts) is somewhat figurative. The English translation "returns to its first Figure" offers a more explicit and concrete description of the outcome, simplifying the concept for the reader.

The French sentence structure "ne... que parce que" (verb... only because) is rephrased into the more explicit and arguably easier-to-parse English construction "the reason why... is because." Additionally, "ne paroissent briller à reprises" (appear to shine intermittently/in bursts) is rendered as "sometimes seem not to shine at all," which simplifies the description of the intermittent shining to a more binary concept (shining/not shining).

The French uses a passive construction with a pronominal adverb "en sont perpetuellement repoussez" (and are perpetually repulsed by it/them). The English translation changes this to an active voice construction, "and ours again continually repulseth theirs," which is often more direct and simpler to process as it explicitly states the agent ("ours").

chunks.source_manual: <P098>J'aime fort toutes ces Idées-là, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. J'aime ces Balons qui s'enflent & se desenflent à chaque moment, & ces Mondes qui se combattent toûjours, & sur tout j'aime à voir comment ce combat fait entre eux un commerce de lumiere, qui asseurément est le seul qu'ils puissent avoir.</P098>
chunks.target_manual: <P078>I am in love with these Fancies, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>; I am pleas'd with these Foot-balls, which swell every moment, and sink again, and with these Worlds, which are continually striving and pushing one another: But above all, I am pleas'd to see how this justling keeps up the trade of Light, which is certainly the only correspondence that is between them.</P078>

se desenflent
se combattent
ce combat
le seul qu'ils puissent avoir
target_segments: these Foot-balls
sink again

explanations: The French "Balons" (which can mean balls, playing balls, or balloons) is translated as the more specific "Foot-balls." This choice grounds the imagery in a very common, everyday object, simplifying the concept by making it more concrete and relatable for a general audience, even if it slightly alters the original imagery of inflation/deflation.

The French verb "se desenflent" (deflate/go down after swelling) is rendered as "sink again." This simplifies the vocabulary by using a more common, visually descriptive phrasal construction with basic verbs ("sink," "again") rather than a single, potentially more formal or technical term for deflation.

The French verb "se combattent" (fight each other/combat) is translated as "striving and pushing one another." This simplifies the original by replacing a single, relatively strong verb of conflict with a more descriptive phrase using more common and arguably less intense verbs ("strive," "push"), thereby making the interaction more concrete and less abstractly "combative."

The French noun "combat" (combat, fight) is translated as "justling" (jostling). "Justling" is a more common, less formal, and less intense word, depicting a more chaotic and less "serious" physical interaction than "combat." This simplifies the vocabulary by using a more accessible term.

The French phrase "le seul qu'ils puissent avoir" (the only one they can have) is translated by making the implicit referent explicit: "the only correspondence that is between them." Adding "correspondence" clarifies what "le seul" (the only one) refers to (i.e., the "commerce de lumiere" or trade of light mentioned earlier), thus simplifying comprehension by reducing the reader's inferential load.

chunks.source_manual: <P099>Non, non, repris-je, ce n'est pas le seul. Les Mondes voisins nous envoyent quelquefois visiter, & mesme assez magnifiquement. Il nous en vient des Cometes, qui sont toûjours ornées, ou d'une chevelure éclatante, ou d'une barbe venerable, ou d'une queüe majestueuse.</P099> <P100>Ah! quels Deputez dit-elle en riant! On se passeroit bien de leur visite, elle ne sert qu'à faire peur. Ils ne font peur qu'aux <UP></UP> enfants, repliquay-je, à cause de leur équipage extraordinaire, mais <RW>les enfants sont en grand nombre</RW>. Les Cometes ne sont que des Planetes qui appartiennent à un Tourbillon voisin. Elles avoyent leur mouvement vers ses extremitez, mais ce Tourbillon estant peut-estre differemment pressé par ceux qui l'environnent, est plus rond par en haut, & plus plat par en bas, & c'est par en bas qu'il nous regarde. Ces Planetes <UP></UP> qui auront commencé vers le haut à se mouvoir en Cercle, ne prévoyoient pas qu'en bas le Tourbillon leur manqueroit, parce qu'il est là comme écrasé, & pour continuer leur mouvement circulaire, il faut necessairement qu'elles entrent dans un autre Tourbillon, que je suppose qui est le nostre, & qu'elles en coupent les extremitez. Aussi sont-elles toûjours fort élevées à nostre égard, elles marchent beaucoup au dessus de Saturne. Il est necessaire dans nostre Sistême, pour des raisons qui ne sont rien à nostre sujet present, que depuis Saturne jusqu'aux deux extremitez de nostre Tourbillon, il y ait un grand espace vide, & sans Planetes. Nos Ennemis nous reprochent sans cesse inutilité de ce grand espace. Qu'ils ne s'inquietent plus, nous en avons trouvé l'usage, c'est l'apartement des Planetes étrangeres qui entrent dans nostre Monde.</P100>
chunks.target_manual: <P079>No, no, Madam, said I; Light is not their sole commerce; the Neighbouring Worlds sometimes send visits to us, and that in a very magnificent and splendid manner: There come Comets to us from thence, adorn'd with bright shining Hair, Venerable Beards, or Majestick Tails; these said the <IIM>Countess</IIM> are Embassadors, whose Visits may be well spared, since they serve onely to affright us. They scare only Children, said I, with their extraordinary train; but indeed, the number of such Children is now a days very great. Comets are nothing but Planets, which belong to a Neighbouring Vortex, they move towards the out-side of it; but perhaps this Vortex being differently press'd by those Vortex's which encompass it, it is rounder above than it is below, and it is the lower part that is still towards us. These Planets which have begun to move in a Circle above, are not aware that below their Vortex will fail 'em, because it is as it were broken. Therefore to continue the Circular Motion, it is necessary that they enter into another Vortex, which we will suppose is ours, and that they cut through the outsides of it. They appear to us very high, and are much higher than Saturn, and according to our System, it is absolutely necessary they should be so high, for Reasons that signifie nothing to our present subject. From Saturn downwards to the outsides of our Vortex, there is a great void space without any Planets. Our Adversaries often ask us, to what purpose this void space serves? but let them not trouble themselves any more, I have found an use for it. 'Tis the Apartment of those strange Planets, which come into our World.</P079>

explanations: The French "ce n'est pas le seul" (it/that is not the only one) is elliptical. The English translation simplifies by making the implied subject ("Light") and the concept ("commerce") explicit ("Light is not their sole commerce"), reducing the inferential work for the reader and enhancing immediate clarity.

The French explicitly states two distinct properties: "rounder above AND flatter below." The English simplifies this by rephrasing it into a single comparative statement ("rounder above THAN it is below"), omitting the distinct affirmation of "flatter." This reduces the density of descriptive detail, making the description less specific.

The translation simplifies complex French verb tenses (future perfect "auront commencé" to present perfect "have begun"; imperfect "ne prévoyoient pas" to present "are not aware"; conditional "leur manqueroit" to future "will fail 'em"). "Are not aware" is also simpler vocabulary than "ne prévoyoient pas" (did not foresee). This simplification makes the narrative more direct and easier to follow by reducing temporal complexity.

The French "écrasé" (crushed, squashed) conveys a specific and forceful image. The English "broken" is a more general and less vivid term. This substitution simplifies the original's imagery by using a more common and less specific descriptor, making it more broadly accessible but losing some of the original's descriptive richness.

The French "elles marchent" (they move/travel) indicates dynamic action. The English translation "are much higher than Saturn" simplifies this by replacing the verb of motion with a static description of position ("are"). This removes the element of movement, focusing only on relative altitude and making the concept less dynamic.

The original French directly links the "necessity" to the existence of the "grand espace vide" (large empty space). The English translation simplifies the sentence's logical structure by reassigning this "necessity" to the comets' height ("necessary they should be so high") and then stating the existence of the empty space separately. This restructuring breaks down a complex assertion. Additionally, the more formal "extremitez" (extremities) is simplified to the more common "outsides."

The French "reprochent sans cesse inutilité" (ceaselessly reproach for uselessness) is a direct and strong accusation. The English simplifies this by changing it to a milder question: "often ask us, to what purpose this void space serves?". This reduces the confrontational force of the statement. Furthermore, "sans cesse" (ceaselessly) is softened to "often," lessening the intensity. This makes the criticism seem less severe.

chunks.source_manual: <P101>J'entends, dit-elle. <NCP></NCP>. Nous ne les laissons pas entrer jusque dans le cœur de nostre Tourbillon, & avec nos Planetes, nous les recevons comme le Grand Seigneur reçoit les Ambassadeurs qu'on luy envoye. Il ne leur fait pas l'honneur de les loger à Constantinople, mais seulement dans un Fauxbourg de la Ville. <IIM>Nous avons encore cela de commun avec les Ottomans</IIM>, repris-je, qu'ils reçoivent des Ambassadeurs sans en renvoyer, & que nous ne renvoyons point de nos Planetes aux Mondes voisins.</P101>
chunks.target_manual: <P080>I understand you, says she, <UP>we do not suffer them to come</UP> into the heart of our Vortex, among our own Planets, but we receive them as the Grand Signior doth the Embassadours that are sent to him; he will not shew them so much respect as to let 'em Lodge in Constantinople, but Quarters 'em in one of the Suburbs of the City: Madam, said I, we, and the Ottomans agree likewise in this, that as they receive Embassadours, but never send any, so we never send any of our Planets into the Worlds that are next us.</P080>
source_segments: sans en renvoyer,
ne renvoyons point de nos Planetes
aux Mondes voisins.
target_segments: but never send any,
never send any of our Planets
into the Worlds that are next us.
explanations: The French `sans en renvoyer` (a compact negative phrase with a pronoun and infinitive, literally "without sending any [of them] back") is simplified by restructuring it into a contrasting coordinate clause, `but never send any`. This makes the contrast explicit and uses a more direct verb phrase, simplifying the original's grammatical density.

The French uses the emphatic, multi-part negation `ne ... point de` (meaning "not any ... at all" or "absolutely no..."). The translation simplifies this to the strong negation `never send any of`, which is a more common and direct way to express this level of negation in English of the period.

The French `Mondes voisins` uses the standard adjective `voisins` (neighboring). The translation simplifies this by using the phrase `that are next us`. The vocabulary "next us" is simpler and more direct than "neighboring" (a more literal translation of `voisins`), making the description more accessible.

chunks.source_manual: <P102>A en juger par toutes ces choses-là, repliqua-t-elle, <UP></UP>, nous sommes bien fiers. Cependant je ne sçais pas trop encore ce que j'en dois croire. Ces Planetes étrangeres ont un air bien menaçant avec leurs queües & leurs barbes, & peut-estre on nous les envoye pour nous insulter, au lieu que les nostres, qui ne sont pas faites de la mesme maniere, ne seroient pas si propres à se faire craindre, quand elles iroient dans les autres Mondes.</P102>
chunks.target_manual: <P081>By this, says she, it appears that we are very proud, however I do not yet very well know what I am to believe. These forreign Planets with thei Tails and their Beards have a terrible Countenance, it may be they are sent to affront us; but ours that are of another make, if they should get into other Worlds, are not so proper to make people afraid.</P081>

explanations: The French phrase "A en juger par toutes ces choses-là" (Judging by all these things) is significantly condensed to "By this." This simplification reduces the descriptive detail ("all these things") and phrasal length to a more general pronoun, making the introductory phrase shorter and more direct.

The French "repliqua-t-elle,," (she replied/retorted), using a specific verb of speech ("répliquer") in the passé simple tense, is translated as "says she,". This simplifies the original by using the more general verb "says" (instead of "replied") and by shifting from the literary passé simple tense to the historical present, which can make dialogue more direct, representing a simplification of tense and lexical specificity.

The French conjunction "au lieu que" (meaning "whereas" or "while," expressing contrast) is translated as "but." This simplifies the connection between clauses by using a shorter, more common, and more direct adversative conjunction.

The French uses a negative relative clause "qui ne sont pas faites de la mesme maniere" (which are not made in the same way). The English translation simplifies this structure to an affirmative phrase "that are of another make." This change from a negative construction to an affirmative one using "another" streamlines the description and simplifies the clausal structure.

The French conditional phrase "ne seroient pas si propres à" (would not be so apt/suited to) is simplified to the indicative "are not so proper to," making the statement more direct by removing the hypothetical modality. Furthermore, the reflexive pronominal verb "se faire craindre" (literally "to make oneself feared," meaning to inspire fear) is rendered as the more straightforward and explicit active construction "to make people afraid," simplifying the verb form and using more common phrasing.

chunks.source_manual: <P103>Les queües & les barbes, répondis-je, ne sont que de pures apparences. <UP></UP>. Les Planetes étrangeres ne different en rien des nostres, mais en entrant dans nostre Tourbillon, elles prennent la queüe ou la barbe par une certaine sorte d'illumination qu'elles reçoivent du Soleil, & qui entre nous n'a pas encore esté trop bien expliquée; mais toûjours on est seur qu'il ne s'agit que d'une espece d'illumination <UP></UP>; on la devinera quand on pourra. Je voudrois donc bien, reprit-elle, que nostre Saturne allast prendre une queuë ou une barbe dans quelqu'autre Tourbillon, & y répandre l'effroy, & qu'en suite ayant mis bas cet <IIM>accompagnement</IIM> terrible, il revint se ranger icy avec les autres Planetes à ses fonctions ordinaires. Il vaut mieux pour luy, répondis-je, qu'il ne sorte point de nostre Tourbillon. Je vous ay dit le choc qui se fait à l'endroit où deux Tourbillons se poussent & se repoussent l'un l'autre; je croy que dans ce pas là une pauvre Planete est agitée assez rudement, & que ses habitans ne s'en portent pas mieux. Nous croyons nous autres estre bien malheureux quand il nous paroist une Comete; c'est la Comete elle-même qui est bien malheureuse. Je ne le crois point, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, elle nous apporte tous ses habitans en bonne santé. Rien n'est si divertissant que de changer ainsi de Tourbillon. Nous qui ne sortons jamais du nostre, nous menons une vie assez ennuyeuse. Si les habitans d'une Comete ont assez d'esprit pour prévoir le temps de leur passage dans nostre Monde, ceux qui ont déja fait le voyage, annoncent aux autres par avance ce qu'ils y verront. Vous découvrirez bien-tost une Planete qui a un grand Anneau autour d'elle, disent-ils peut-estre, en parlant de Saturne. Vous en verrez une autre qui en a quatre petites qui la suivent. Peut-estre mesme y a-t-il des gens destinés à observer le moment où ils entrent dans nostre Monde, & qui crient aussi-tost, Nouveau Soleil, Nouveau Soleil, comme ces Matelots qui crient, Terre, Terre. <UP></UP>.</P103>
chunks.target_manual: <P082>Their Beards and their Tails Madam, said I, are not real, they are <UP>Phaenomena</UP>, and but meer Appearances. These forreign Planets differ in nothing from ours, but entring into our Vortex, they seem to us to have Tails or Beards, by a certain sort of Illumination which they receive from the Sun, and which hath not been yet well explain'd. But certain it is, that 'tis but a kind of illumination, and when I am able I will tell you how 'tis done. I wish then, says she, that our Saturn would go take a Tail or a Beard in another Vortex, and affright all the Inhabitants of it. That done, I would have him come back again, leaving his terrible <IIM>Accoutrements</IIM> behind him, and taking his usual place amongst our other Planets, fall to his ordinary business. 'Tis better for him, said I, not to go out of our Vortex. I have told you how rude and violent the Shock is, when two Vortex's justle one another, a poor Planet must needs be terribly shaken, and its Inhabitants in no better condition. We think our selves very unhappy when a Comet appears, but 'tis the Comet that is in an ill case. I do not believe that, say she, it brings all its Inhabitants with it in very good health; there can be nothing so diverting as to change Vortex's. We that never go out of our own, lead but a dull Life; if the Inhabitants of a Comet had but the wit to foresee the time when they are to come into our world, they that had already made the Voyage, would tell their Neighbours beforehand what they should see, they would tell them, that they would discover a Planet with a great Ring about it, meaning our Saturn, they would also say, you shall see another Planet which hath four little ones to wait on it; and perhaps some of them, resolv'd to observe the very Moment of their entring into our World, would presently cry out A New Sun, a New Sun, as Sailors use to cry Land, Land.</P082>

That done, I would have him come back again, leaving his terrible Accoutrements behind him, and taking his usual place amongst our other Planets, fall to his ordinary business.

explanations: The original French uses an impersonal construction ("on la devinera" - one will figure it out; "quand on pourra" - when one can), suggesting a general, collective scientific endeavor. The translation changes this to a personal promise from the philosopher ("when I am able I will tell you"), simplifying the abstract nature of scientific discovery into a concrete assurance from an authority figure. This makes the concept of future knowledge acquisition less open-ended and more directly accessible.

The French phrase "il revint se ranger icy ... à ses fonctions ordinaires" (it returned to take its place here... for its ordinary functions) is a relatively dense and formal construction. The English translation simplifies this by breaking the action into a sequence of more common and active verb phrases ("come back again," "taking his usual place," "fall to his ordinary business"), making the syntax more straightforward and the language more idiomatic ("fall to his ordinary business").

The translation simplifies the French phrase in two ways: first, by omitting the phrase "dans ce pas là" (in that pass/strait/difficult situation), which reduces the density of the text by removing a specific contextual detail. Second, "agitée assez rudement" (agitated quite harshly/rudely) is rendered as "terribly shaken"; "terribly" is a more common and arguably simpler intensifier than the adverbial phrase "assez rudement," enhancing directness.

The French original includes the phrase "disent-ils peut-estre" (they say perhaps) directly within the reported speech of the comet dwellers, adding a layer of speculation and attribution. The translation simplifies this by omitting this explicit speculative attribution and rephrasing "en parlant de Saturne" (when speaking of Saturn) into the more direct and explanatory "meaning our Saturn." This streamlines the sentence and makes the identification of Saturn more immediate for the reader, reducing cognitive load.

The French "qui la suivent" (that follow it) offers a neutral, kinematic description of the moons. The English translation "to wait on it" replaces this with a figurative and anthropomorphic image (moons as attendants). This simplifies the concept by analogy, making the relationship between the planet and its moons more concrete and relatable to a familiar social structure, thereby potentially enhancing accessibility for a lay audience compared to a purely physical description.

The French "Peut-estre mesme y a-t-il des gens destinés à observer... & qui crient" (Perhaps even there are people destined/assigned to observe... and who cry) uses an existential clause ("y a-t-il des gens") followed by a relative clause ("qui crient"). The English translation simplifies this sentence structure to "and perhaps some of them, resolv'd to observe... would presently cry out," where "some of them" becomes the direct subject of "would presently cry out." This creates a more linear and syntactically less complex sentence.

chunks.source_manual: <P104>Il ne faut donc plus songer, luy dis-je, à vous donner de la pitié pour les habitans d'une Comète, mais j'espere du moins que vous plaindrez ceux qui vivent dans un Tourbillon dont le Soleil vient à s'éteindre, & <SC>qui demeurent dans une nuit éternelle</SC>. Quoi? s'écria-t-elle, des Soleils s'éteignent? Oüi, sans doute, répondis-je. Les Anciens ont vû dans le Ciel des Etoiles fixes que nous n'y voyons plus. Ces Soleils ont perdu leur lumiere; grande desolation assurément dans tout le Tourbillon; mortalité generale sur toutes les Planetes; car que faire sans Soleil? Cette idée est trop funeste, reprit-elle. N'y auroit-il pas moyen de me l'épargner? Je vous diray si vous voulez, répondis-je, ce que disent de fort habiles gens, que les Etoiles fixes qui ont disparu ne se sont pas pour cela éteintes, que ce sont des Soleils qui ne le sont qu'à demy, c'est à dire qui ont <IIM>une moitié obscure</IIM>, & l'autre lumineuse; que comme ils tournent sur eux-mesmes, tantost ils nous presentent la moitié lumineuse, & qu'alors nous ne les voyons, tantost la moitié obscure, & qu'alors nous ne les voyons plus. Je prendray bien pour vous obliger cette opinion là, qui est plus douce que l'autre, mais je ne puis la prendre qu'à l'égard de certaines Etoiles qui ont des temps reglez pour paroître & pour disparoistre, ainsi qu'on a commencé à s'en apercevoir, autrement les demy Soleils ne peuvent pas subsister. Mais que dirons-nous des Etoiles qui disparoissent & ne se remontrent pas aprés le temps pendant lequel elles auroient dû assurément achever de tourner sur elles-mesmes? Vous estes trop équitable pour vouloir m'obliger à croire que ce soient des demy Soleils: cependant je feray encore un effort en vostre faveur. Ces Soleils ne se seront pas éteints, ils se seront seulement enfoncez dans la profondeur immense du Ciel, & nous ne pourrons plus les voir. En ce cas le Tourbillon aura suivy son Soleil, & tout s'y portera bien. Il est vray que la plus grande partie des Etoiles fixes n'ont pas ce mouvement par lequel elles s'éloignent de nous, car en d'autres temps elles devroient s'en rapprocher, & nous les verrions tantost plus grandes, tantost plus petites, ce qui n'arrive pas. Mais nous supposerons qu'il n'y a que quelques petits Tourbillons plus legers & plus agiles qui se glissent entre les autres, & font de certains tours, au bout desquels ils reviennent, tandis que le gros des Tourbillons demeure immobile; mais voicy un étrange malheur, il y a des Etoiles fixes qui viennent se montrer à nous, qui passent beaucoup de temps à ne faire que paroistre & disparoistre, & enfin disparoissent entierement, des demi Soleils reparoîtroient dans des temps reglez. Des Soleils qui s'enfonceroient dans le Ciel ne disparoistroient qu'une fois pour ne reparoistre de longtemps. Prenez vostre resolution, Madame, avec courage; il faut que ces Etoiles soient des Soleils qui s'obscurcissent assez pour cesser d'estre visibles à nos yeux, & en suite se rallument, & à la fin s'éteignent tout à fait. Comment un Soleil peut-il s'obscurcir & s'éteindre, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, luy qui est en luy-mesme une source de lumiere? Le plus aisément du Monde, selon Descartes, répondis-je, nostre Soleil a des tâches. Que ce soient ou des écumes, des broüillards, ou tout ce qu'il vous plaira, ces taches peuvent s'épaissir, se mettre plusieurs ensemble, s'accrocher les unes aux autres, en suite elles iront jusqu'à former autour du Soleil une croûte qui s'augmentera toujours, & adieu le Soleil <UP></UP>. Nous l'avons déja même échepée belle, dit-on. Le Soleil a esté tres-pasle pendant des années entieres, pendant celle, par exemple, qui suivit la mort de Cesar. C'estoit la croûte qui commençoit à se faire, la force du Soleil la rompit & la dissipa; mais si elle eust continué, nous estions perdus. Vous me faites trembler, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Presentement que je sçay les consequences de la pâleur du Soleil, je crois qu'au lieu d'aller voir les matins à mon miroir si je ne suis point pasle, j'iray voir au Ciel si le Soleil ne l'est point luy même. Ah! Madame, répondis-je, rassurez-vous, il faut du temps pour ruiner un Monde. Mais enfin, dit-elle, il ne faut que du temps? Je vous l'avouë, repris-je: Toute cette masse immense de matiere qui compose l'Univers est dans un mouvement perpétuel, dont aucune de ses parties n'est entierement exempte; & dés qu'il y a du mouvement quelque part, ne vous y fiez point, il faut qu'il arrive des changemens: soit lents, soit prompts, mais toujours dans des temps proportionnez à l'effet. Les Anciens estoient <IIM>plaisans</IIM> de s'imaginer que les Corps celestes étoient de nature à ne changer jamais, parce qu'ils ne les avoyent pas encore vû changer. <IIM>Avoyent-ils eu le loisir de s'en assurer par l'experience?</IIM> Les Anciens étoient jeunes auprés de nous. Si les Roses qui ne durent qu'un jour faisoient des Histoires, & se laissoient des Memoires les unes aux autres, les premieres auroient fait le portrait de leur Jardinier d'une certaine façon, & de plus de quinze mille áges de Rose, les autres qui l'auroient encore laissé à celles qui les devoyent suivre, n'y auroient rien changé. Sur cela elles diroient, nous avons toûjours vû le mesme Jardinier <UP></UP>, de memoire de Rose on n'a vû que luy, il a toûjours esté fait comme il est, assurément il ne meurt point comme nous, il ne change seulement pas. Le raisonnement des Roses seroit-il bon? Il auroit pourtant plus de fondement que celuy que faisoient les Anciens sur les Corps celestes; & quand même il ne seroit arrivé aucun changement dans les Cieux jusqu'à aujourd'huy, quand ils paroistroient marquer qu'ils seroient faits pour durer toûjours sans aucune alteration, je ne les en croirois pas encore, j'attendrois une plus longue experience. Devons-nous établir nostre durée, qui n'est que d'un instant, pour la mesure de quelque-autre? Seroit-ce à dire que ce qui auroit duré cent mille fois plus que nous, dût toûjours durer? On n'est pas si aisément éternel. Il faudroit qu'une chose eût passé bien des âges d'homme mis à bout pour commencer à donner quelque signe d'immortalité. Vrayment, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je voy les Mondes bien éloignez d'y pouvoir pretendre. Je ne leur ferois seulement pas l'honneur de les comparer à ce Jardinier qui dure tant à l'égard des Roses; ils ne sont que comme les Roses mêmes qui naissent & qui meurent dans un Jardin les unes aprés les autres; car je m'attens bien que s'il disparoist des Etoiles anciennes, il en paroist de nouvelles, il faut que l'espece se repare. Il n'est pas à craindre qu'elle perisse, répondis-je. Les uns vous diront que ce ne sont que des Soleils qui se rapprochent de nous aprés avoir esté long- temps perdus pour nous dans la profondeur du Ciel. D'autres vous diront que ce sont des Soleils qui se sont démeslez de cette croûte obscure qui commençoit à les environner. Je croy aisément que tout cela peut estre, mais je croy aussi que l'Univers peut avoir esté fait de sorte qu'il s'y formera de temps en temps des Soleils nouveaux. Pourquoy la matiere propre à faire un Soleil ne pourra-t'elle pas, aprés avoir esté dispersée en plusieurs endroits différens, se ramasser à la longue en un certain lieu, & y jetter les fondemens d'un nouveau Monde? J'ay d'autant plus d'inclination à croire ces nouvelles productions, qu'elles répondent mieux à la haute idée que j'ay des ouvrages de la Nature. N'auroit-elle le secret que de faire naistre & mourir des herbes ou des plantes par une revolution continuelle? Je suis persuadé, & vous l'estes déja aussi, qu'elle pratique ce même secret sur les Mondes, & qu'il ne luy en coûte pas davantage. De bonne foy, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je trouve à present les Mondes, les Cieux, & les Corps celestes si sujets au changement, que m'en voila tout à fait revenuë. Revenons encore mieux, si vous m'en croyez, repliquay-je, n'en parlons plus, aussi bien vous voila arrivée à la derniere voûte des Cieux; & pour vous dire s'il y a encore des Etoiles au delà, il faudroit estre plus habile que je ne suis. Mettez-y encore des Mondes, n'y en mettez pas, cela dépend de vous. C'est proprement l'Empire des Philosophes que ces grands païs invisibles qui peuvent estre ou n'estre pas si on veut, ou estre tels que l'on veut, il me suffit d'avoir mené vôtre esprit aussi loin que vont vos yeux.</P104>
chunks.target_manual: <P083>You have no reason then, said I, to pity the Inhabitants of a Comet, yet I suppose you will think their Condition lamentable, who inhabit a Vortex whose Sun comes in time to be quite extinguished, and consequently live in Eternal Night. How? cry'd the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, can Suns be put out? Yes, without doubt said I, for People some thousand years ago saw fix'd Stars in the Sky, which are now no more to be seen; these were Suns which have lost their Light, and certainly there must be strange Desolation in their Vortex's, and a general Mortality over all the Planets, for what can People do without a Sun? This is a dismal Fancy, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, I would not if I could help it, let it come into my head. I will tell you if you please, I reply'd, what in this particular is the Opinion of Learned Astronomers. They think that the fix'd Stars which have disappear'd, are not quite extinguish'd, but that they are <UP>half Suns</UP>, that is, they have one half Dark, and the other half Light, and turning round upon their own Axis or Centre, they sometimes shew us their Light side, and afterwards turning to us their Dark side, we see them no more. To oblige you Madam, I will be of this Opinion, because it is not so harsh as the other, but I cannot make it good, but in relation to some certain Stars, because as some have lately observed, those Stars have their Regulated times of appearing, and disappearing, otherwise there could be no such thing as half Suns. But what shall we say of Stars, which totally disappear, and never shew themselves again after they have finish'd their Course of turning round upon their own Axis? you are too just Madam to oblige me to believe that such Stars are half Suns. However I will try once more what I can do in favour of your Opinion; the Suns are not extinct, they are only sunk so low into the immense depth of Heaven, that we cannot possibly see them, in this Case the Vortex follows his Sun and all's well again. 'Tis true, that the greatest part of the fix'd Stars have not this motion, by which they remove themselves so far from us, because at other times they might return again nearer to us, and we should see them sometimes greater, and sometimes less, which never happens. But we will suppose that none but the Little, Light, and most Active Vortex's which slip between the others make certain voyages, after which they return again, while the main body of Vortex's remain unmov'd. 'Tis likewise very strange that some fix'd Stars shew themselves to us, spending a great deal of time in appearing, and disappearing, and at last, totally and entirely disappear. Half Suns would appear again at their set and regulated time. Now Madam, boldly declare your Opinion; Must not these Stars of necessity be Suns which are so much darkned as not to be visible to us, yet afterwards shine again, and at last are wholly extinct? How can a Sun said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, be darkned, and quite extinguish'd, when it is in its own Nature a Fountain of Light? It may be done Madam, said I, with all the ease in the world, if Desc�rtes Opinion be true, that our Sun hath Spots; now whether these Spots be Scum or thick Mists, or what you please, they may thicken and unite, till at last they cover the Sun with a Crust, which daily grows thicker, and then Farewell Sun. We have hitherto scap'd pretty well; but 'tis said, that the Sun for some whole years together hath look'd very pale; for Example, the year after Caesar's death; it was this Crust that then began to grow, but the force of the Sun broke and dissipated it; had it continued, we had been all lost People. You make me tremble, reply'd the <IIM>Countess</IIM>; and now I know the fatal consequences of the Sun's paleness, I believe, instead of going every morning to my Glass, to see how I look, I shall cast my Eyes up to Heaven, to see whether or no the Sun looks pale. Oh, Madam, said I, there is a great deal of time required to ruine a World. Grant it, said she, yet 'tis but time that is required. I confess it, said I; all this immense mass of Matter that composes the Universe, is in perpetual motion, no part of it excepted; and since every part is moved, you may be sure that changes must happen sooner or later; but still in times proportioned to the Effect. The Ancients were <UP>pleasant Gentlemen</UP>, to imagine that the celestial Bodies were in their own nature unchangeable, because they observed no change in them; but they did not live long enough to confirm their opinion by their own experience; they were Boys in comparison of us. <UP>Give me leave, Madam, to explain my self by an Allegory</UP>: If Roses, which last but a day, could write Histories, and leave Memoirs one to another; and if the first Rose should draw an exact Picture of their Gardiner, and after fifteen thousand Rose-Ages, it should be left to other Roses, and so left still to those that should succeed, without any change in it; should the Roses hereupon say, we have every day seen the same Gardiner, and in the memory of Roses, none ever saw any Gardiner but this; he is still the same he was, and therefore certainly he will never die, as we do; for there is no change at all in him. Would not these Roses, Madam, talk very foolishly? and yet there would be more reason in their discourse, than there was in what the Ancients said concerning celestial Bodies; and tho' even to this very day there should appear no visible change in the Heavens, and the matter of which they are made, should have all the signs of an eternal duration without any change; yet I would not believe 'em unchangeable, till I had the experience of many more Ages. Ought we, who last but a moment, make our continuance the measure of any other things duration; 'tis not so easie a matter to be eternal. To have lasted many Ages of Men, one after another, is no sign of Immortality. Truly, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, I find the Worlds are far from being able to pretend to it; I will not do 'em so much honour, as to ompare 'em to the Gardiner that lived so much longer than the Roses: I begin to think 'em like the Roses themselves, which blow one day, and die the next: For now I understand, that if old Stars disappear, new ones will come in their room, because every species must preserve it self. No species, Madam, said I, can totally perish; some perhaps will tell you, that such new Stars are Suns, which return to our sight again, after they have been a long time hid from us, in the profundity of Heaven: Others may tell you, they are Suns cleared from that thick crust, which once covered them: If I should think all this possible, yet I likewise believe that the Universe may be framed in such a manner, that from time to time it may produce new Suns; why may not that matter which is proper to make a Sun, be dispers'd here and there, and gather it self again at long run, into one certain place, and lay the foundation of a new World? I am very much inclin'd to believe such new productions, because they suit with that glorious and admirable Idea which I have of the works of Nature. Can we think that wise Nature knows no more than the secret of making Herbs and Plants live and die by a continual revolution? I am verily perswaded, and are not you so too, Madam? that Nature, without much cost or pains can put the same secret in practice, upon the Worlds. I now find, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, the Worlds, the Heaven, and celestial Bodies so subject to change, that I am come to my self again. To come the better again to our selves, I reply'd, let us say no more of these Matters. We are arrived at the very roof and top of all the Heavens; and to tell you whether there be any Stars beyond it, you must have an abler Man than I am; you may place Worlds there, or no Worlds, as you please: 'Tis the Philosopher's Empire to describe those vast invisible Countries, which are, and are not, or are such as he pleases to make 'em: It is enough for me, to have carried your mind as far as you can see with your Eyes.</P083>

Quoi? s'écria-t-elle, des Soleils s'éteignent?
Les Anciens ont vû dans le Ciel des Etoiles fixes que nous n'y voyons plus.
N'y auroit-il pas moyen de me l'épargner?
que comme ils tournent sur eux-mesmes, tantost ils nous presentent la moitié lumineuse, & qu'alors nous ne les voyons, tantost la moitié obscure, & qu'alors nous ne les voyons plus.
ainsi qu'on a commencé à s'en apercevoir, autrement les demy Soleils ne peuvent pas subsister.
Mais que dirons-nous des Etoiles qui disparoissent & ne se remontrent pas aprés le temps pendant lequel elles auroient dû assurément achever de tourner sur elles-mesmes?
Vous estes trop équitable pour vouloir m'obliger à croire que ce soient des demy Soleils: cependant je feray encore un effort en vostre faveur.
Ces Soleils ne se seront pas éteints, ils se seront seulement enfoncez dans la profondeur immense du Ciel, & nous ne pourrons plus les voir.
En ce cas le Tourbillon aura suivy son Soleil, & tout s'y portera bien.
font de certains tours, au bout desquels ils reviennent
mais voicy un étrange malheur, il y a des Etoiles fixes qui viennent se montrer à nous, qui passent beaucoup de temps à ne faire que paroistre & disparoistre, & enfin disparoissent entierement

Que ce soient ou des écumes, des broüillards, ou tout ce qu'il vous plaira, ces taches peuvent s'épaissir, se mettre plusieurs ensemble, s'accrocher les unes aux autres, en suite elles iront jusqu'à former autour du Soleil une croûte qui s'augmentera toujours, & adieu le Soleil.
Nous l'avons déja même échepée belle, dit-on.
C'estoit la croûte qui commençoit à se faire

Presentement que je sçay les consequences de la pâleur du Soleil, je crois qu'au lieu d'aller voir les matins à mon miroir si je ne suis point pasle, j'iray voir au Ciel si le Soleil ne l'est point luy même.
Ah! Madame, répondis-je, rassurez-vous, il faut du temps pour ruiner un Monde.

Toute cette masse immense de matiere qui compose l'Univers est dans un mouvement perpétuel, dont aucune de ses parties n'est entierement exempte; & dés qu'il y a du mouvement quelque part, ne vous y fiez point, il faut qu'il arrive des changemens
Les Anciens estoient plaisans de s'imaginer que les Corps celestes étoient de nature à ne changer jamais
Avoyent-ils eu le loisir de s'en assurer par l'experience? Les Anciens étoient jeunes auprés de nous.

Si les Roses qui ne durent qu'un jour faisoient des Histoires, & se laissoient des Memoires les unes aux autres, les premieres auroient fait le portrait de leur Jardinier d'une certaine façon, & de plus de quinze mille áges de Rose, les autres qui l'auroient encore laissé à celles qui les devoyent suivre, n'y auroient rien changé.

Sur cela elles diroient, nous avons toûjours vû le mesme Jardinier, de memoire de Rose on n'a vû que luy, il a toûjours esté fait comme il est, assurément il ne meurt point comme nous, il ne change seulement pas.

Le raisonnement des Roses seroit-il bon? Il auroit pourtant plus de fondement que celuy que faisoient les Anciens sur les Corps celestes; & quand même il ne seroit arrivé aucun changement dans les Cieux jusqu'à aujourd'huy, quand ils paroistroient marquer qu'ils seroient faits pour durer toûjours sans aucune alteration, je ne les en croirois pas encore, j'attendrois une plus longue experience.
Seroit-ce à dire que ce qui auroit duré cent mille fois plus que nous, dût toûjours durer?
Il faudroit qu'une chose eût passé bien des âges d'homme mis à bout pour commencer à donner quelque signe d'immortalité.

ils ne sont que comme les Roses mêmes qui naissent & qui meurent dans un Jardin les unes aprés les autres; car je m'attens bien que s'il disparoist des Etoiles anciennes, il en paroist de nouvelles, il faut que l'espece se repare.

Il n'est pas à craindre qu'elle perisse, répondis-je. Les uns vous diront que ce ne sont que des Soleils qui se rapprochent de nous aprés avoir esté long- temps perdus pour nous dans la profondeur du Ciel. D'autres vous diront que ce sont des Soleils qui se sont démeslez de cette croûte obscure qui commençoit à les environner.
mais je croy aussi que l'Univers peut avoir esté fait de sorte qu'il s'y formera de temps en temps des Soleils nouveaux.

Pourquoy la matiere propre à faire un Soleil ne pourra-t'elle pas, aprés avoir esté dispersée en plusieurs endroits différens, se ramasser à la longue en un certain lieu, & y jetter les fondemens d'un nouveau Monde?
J'ay d'autant plus d'inclination à croire ces nouvelles productions, qu'elles répondent mieux à la haute idée que j'ay des ouvrages de la Nature.
Je suis persuadé, & vous l'estes déja aussi, qu'elle pratique ce même secret sur les Mondes, & qu'il ne luy en coûte pas davantage.
De bonne foy, dit la Marquise, je trouve à present les Mondes, les Cieux, & les Corps celestes si sujets au changement, que m'en voila tout à fait revenuë.
aussi bien vous voila arrivée à la derniere voûte des Cieux

explanations: The French phrase 'Il ne faut donc plus songer... à vous donner de la pitié' (One must therefore no longer think... to give you pity) is simplified to the more direct and personal 'You have no reason then... to pity'.
The French 's'éteignent' (extinguish themselves/go out) is translated to 'be put out', which is more common and simpler vocabulary than 'be extinguished'.
The formal term 'Les Anciens' (The Ancients) is simplified to the more vernacular and relatable phrase 'People some thousand years ago'.

The concise French question 'N'y auroit-il pas moyen de me l'épargner?' (Wouldn't there be a way to spare me it?) is rephrased into the more colloquial and structurally simpler statement 'I would not if I could help it, let it come into my head.'
The French repetition 'tantost... tantost' (sometimes... sometimes / at one time... at another time) is simplified to the more straightforward sequence 'sometimes... and afterwards'.

The phrase 'autrement les demy Soleils ne peuvent pas subsister' (otherwise the half-Suns cannot subsist/exist) is simplified to the more common expression 'otherwise there could be no such thing as half Suns'. Additionally, the impersonal 'ainsi qu'on a commencé à s'en apercevoir' (as one has begun to notice it) is made more direct with 'as some have lately observed'.
The translation simplifies by omitting the adverb 'assurément' (certainly) from the French clause 'elles auroient dû assurément achever de tourner', reducing textual density.

The French 'vouloir m'obliger à croire' (to want to oblige me to believe) is simplified by removing 'vouloir' (to want), resulting in the more direct 'to oblige me to believe'. Also, 'je feray encore un effort en vostre faveur' (I will make another effort in your favor) is rephrased to the more colloquial 'I will try once more what I can do in favour of your Opinion'.

The future perfect verb tenses in French ('ne se seront pas éteints', 'se seront seulement enfoncez') are simplified to present state ('are not extinct') or simple past participle ('are only sunk'), making the description more immediate and easier to grasp.

The future perfect 'aura suivy' (will have followed) is simplified to the simple present 'follows'. The somewhat formal 'tout s'y portera bien' (everything there will fare well) is simplified to the common, concise idiom 'all's well again'.

The French 'font de certains tours, au bout desquels ils reviennent' (make certain turns/rounds, at the end of which they return) is simplified in its connective phrasing to 'make certain voyages, after which they return again'; 'au bout desquels' is slightly more complex than 'after which'.

The introductory French 'mais voicy un étrange malheur, il y a des Etoiles...' (but here is a strange misfortune/problem, there are Stars...) is recast and simplified to ''Tis likewise very strange that some fix'd Stars...' integrating the 'problem' more smoothly. Also, 'à ne faire que paroistre & disparoistre' (to do nothing but appear and disappear) is simplified to the more concise 'in appearing, and disappearing'.

The French 'Prenez vostre resolution...; il faut que...' (Take your resolution...; it is necessary that...) is simplified by changing the direct assertion of necessity into a guided rhetorical question 'boldly declare your Opinion; Must not these Stars of necessity be Suns...', which prompts agreement.

The descriptive French phrase 'se mettre plusieurs ensemble, s'accrocher les unes aux autres' (several put themselves together, hook onto one another) is condensed and simplified to 'unite', reducing descriptive detail.

The specific French idiom 'Nous l'avons déja même échepée belle' (We have already even had a narrow escape) is simplified to the more general and slightly less vivid expression 'We have hitherto scap'd pretty well'.
The French 'commençoit à se faire' (was beginning to form/be made) is simplified using more common vocabulary 'began to grow'.
The specific check 'si je ne suis point pasle' (if I am not pale) is simplified to the more general and common phrase 'to see how I look', though the context implies checking for paleness.
The translation simplifies the utterance by omitting the explicit reassurance 'rassurez-vous' (reassure yourself / don't worry) present in the French sentence, reducing its length.

The French 'dont aucune de ses parties n'est entierement exempte' (from which none of its parts is entirely exempt) is simplified to the more concise and common English phrasing 'no part of it excepted'. Also, the cautionary 'ne vous y fiez point, il faut que...' (don't trust it, changes must happen...) is simplified to the assertive 'you may be sure that changes must happen...'.
The French periphrastic construction 'étoient de nature à ne changer jamais' (were of a nature never to change) is simplified by using the single, common adjective 'unchangeable'.

The rhetorical question 'Avoyent-ils eu le loisir de s'en assurer par l'experience?' (Had they had the leisure to assure themselves of it by experience?) is simplified into a declarative statement 'but they did not live long enough to confirm their opinion by their own experience', removing rhetorical complexity. Also, 'jeunes' (young) is simplified to the more vivid and colloquial 'Boys'.
The phrase 'de plus de quinze mille áges de Rose' (more than fifteen thousand Rose-ages) is simplified by omitting 'de plus de' (more than), reducing a small detail of quantity.

The French 'il a toûjours esté fait comme il est' (he has always been made as he is / has always been as he is) is simplified to the more idiomatic and common English phrasing 'he is still the same he was'. Also, 'il ne change seulement pas' (he only does not change / he doesn't even change) is clarified and simplified to 'for there is no change at all in him'.

The French question 'Le raisonnement des Roses seroit-il bon?' (Would the reasoning of the Roses be good?) is simplified to 'Would not these Roses, Madam, talk very foolishly?', using more direct and evaluative vocabulary. The complex verbal construction 'quand ils paroistroient marquer qu'ils seroient faits pour durer toûjours' (even if they seemed to indicate that they were made to last forever) is simplified to '...should have all the signs of an eternal duration'.

The specific French rhetorical question 'Seroit-ce à dire que ce qui auroit duré cent mille fois plus que nous, dût toûjours durer?' (Would that be to say that what had lasted a hundred thousand times longer than us, must always last?) is simplified by being replaced with the general maxim ''tis not so easie a matter to be eternal.', reducing rhetorical complexity and omitting specific numerical detail.

The complex French conditional sentence 'Il faudroit qu'une chose eût passé bien des âges d'homme mis à bout pour commencer à donner quelque signe d'immortalité.' (A thing would have to have passed many ages of man, end to end, to begin to give some sign of immortality.) is simplified into the direct negative assertion 'To have lasted many Ages of Men, one after another, is no sign of Immortality.', significantly reducing structural complexity.

The French 'ils ne sont que comme les Roses mêmes qui naissent & qui meurent dans un Jardin les unes aprés les autres' (they are only like the Roses themselves that are born and die in a Garden one after the other) is simplified using the more common and vivid idiom 'which blow one day, and die the next'. Also, 'il en paroist de nouvelles' (new ones appear) is simplified to the colloquial 'new ones will come in their room'.

The somewhat formal French phrasing 'Il n'est pas à craindre qu'elle perisse' (It is not to be feared that it perishes) is simplified to the more direct 'No species... can totally perish'. The specific verb 'se sont démeslez de' (have disentangled themselves from) is simplified to 'cleared from'. The phrase 'qui commençoit à les environner' (that was beginning to surround them) is simplified to 'which once covered them', reducing the nuance of an ongoing process to a completed state.

The French construction 'qu'il s'y formera de temps en temps des Soleils nouveaux' (that there will form themselves in it from time to time new Suns), with its pronominal verb and word order, is simplified to the more direct active voice construction 'it may produce new Suns'.
The French phrase 'en plusieurs endroits différens' (in several different places) is simplified to the common, less formal idiom 'here and there'.

The French correlative construction 'J'ay d'autant plus d'inclination à croire... qu'elles répondent mieux...' (I have all the more inclination to believe... because/as they correspond better...) is simplified to a more direct cause-and-effect structure 'I am very much inclin'd to believe... because they suit with...'.

The compact final French clause '& qu'il ne luy en coûte pas davantage.' (and that it costs her no more for it.) is rephrased, expanded for clarity, and integrated as the simpler, common phrase 'without much cost or pains' modifying Nature's action.
The introductory French phrase 'De bonne foy' (In good faith / Truly) is omitted in the English translation, simplifying the utterance by reducing its length slightly.
The somewhat literary/poetic French 'la derniere voûte des Cieux' (the last vault of the Heavens) is simplified using more common vocabulary: 'the very roof and top of all the Heavens'.

The French construction 'C'est proprement l'Empire des Philosophes que ces grands païs invisibles...' (It is properly the Empire of Philosophers, these great invisible countries...) is somewhat elliptical. The English simplifies this by making the function of the empire explicit: ''Tis the Philosopher's Empire to describe those vast invisible Countries...'.

chunks.target_manual: <P084>Well, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, I have now in my Head, the System of the Universe: How learned am I become? Indeed, Madam, said I, you are pretty knowing, and you are so with the advantage of believing, or not believing any thing I have said: For all my pains, I only beg this favour, that when ever you see the Sun, the Heaven, or the Stars, you will think of me.</P084>

target_segments: Well, says the Countess
and you are so with the advantage of believing, or not believing any thing I have said:
For all my pains, I only beg this favour
that when ever you see the Sun, the Heaven, or the Stars, you will think of me.
explanations: The French "Quoi!" (What!), a strong interjection expressing surprise, and "s'écria-t-elle" (she cried out/exclaimed), a vivid verb, are translated to the much milder "Well," and the more narratively neutral "says the Countess." This simplification reduces the original's expressive intensity and makes the Marquise's reaction less dramatic, enhancing ease of reading by using more common and less forceful expressions.

The translation simplifies this complex French sentence. Firstly, the phrase "de pouvoir ne rien croire de tout ce que je vous ay dit" (of being able to believe nothing of all that I have told you) is restructured into the more straightforward binary choice "of believing, or not believing any thing I have said." Secondly, the translator omits the final clause "dés que l'envie vous en prendra" (as soon as the desire/whim takes you). This omission shortens the sentence, reduces its informational density, and removes a specific nuance about the arbitrary nature of the Marquise's potential disbelief, simplifying the overall statement for easier comprehension.

The French "recompense de mes peines" (reward for my pains/troubles) implies an earned compensation. The translation "For all my pains, I only beg this favour" simplifies this by substituting "recompense" with "favour." "Favour" suggests a kindness freely given rather than an earned right, thus softening the transactional nature of the request and using a more common term for a polite entreaty, which simplifies the implied social dynamic.

The original French uses a sophisticated grammatical construction "de ne voir jamais... sans songer à moy" (literally, "of never seeing... without thinking of me"), which employs a negative logic to convey a positive continuous action. The English translation simplifies this complex syntax into a more direct and easily understood positive conditional clause: "that when ever you see... you will think of me." This enhances readability by using a more common and straightforward sentence pattern.
